113321112.content:
The stable girls grooming leaves you relaxed, and you content yourself with the plentiful food and water. It's a boring existence, but your demands are simple. Afternoon passes into evening, and evening darkens into night.

It's only a Father Dulu enters the stables, that you even recall how this all started. Whinnying, you realise how far you've adapted into the equine life. Just another docile filly in the stable. You concentrate on restoring yourself, while he's here, while you're still aware of your previous life.... and how you ended up here.

Concentrating on the spells, you try mouthing them under your breath. But that comes out as meaningless horse blubbering, your lips flapping uselessly. But, you feel the tingle of magic starting to work, your consciousness more alert than any other time in the stables.

You rush the incantation, repeating silently inside your head. You want to restore yourself, with Father Dulu witnessing it, and being there to praise you....

A niggling thought at the back of your head, taunts you. Maybe, the docile life of a filly, IS what you want. Maybe he can leave, and you can relax... Food is plentiful, the water clean, and the grooming joyous.

1133211123.content:
You realise you aren't concentrating, as Father Dulu is walking, shaking off the apathy, you focus on the incantation, repeating the chant inside your head, as you picture returning to humanity.

Father Dulu's steps start to fade, as he passed towards the stable exit. Desperation makes you drive the incantation, faster inside your head, the thoughts of an equine life intrude once more, as you are distracted by the exotic musk of a stallion reaching you. Nostrils flaring, you snort, the sound filling the stable, your muzzle still firmly equine. Your grip on the human image wavering, as you see Father Dulu is about to leave.

You can feel your will weakening, the aroma of the other horses calming you, and the appeal of a simpler life, tugging at you. Swallowing a whinny, you complete the incantation, as he turns.

A crack, like thunder fills the stable, echoing deafening in the tight confines. A cocoon flaring around you, and blown off, as your body transforms.

"Father Dulu." You bellow the words, high and proud. A human voice not a whinnying bray. His head snaps around, and he instantly spots you in the stall.

Coughing, you clear your sore throat, your strained voice not sounding right. Other sensations crash over you, one after another like a tsunami threatening your calm.

Firstly, you feel far too tall. Looking over the stall dividers, you look down on Father Dulu. Your height should be about equal, but you tower over him. Almost two feet taller than you should be.

A glance downwards shatters that hope, as you see an immense bust filling your vision. You've been restored to humanity, but your filly sex has followed you.

Shifting uncertainly, you can't feel proud of this mistake. You cradle your bust, as if owning up to your mistake. The heavy breasts overflow your hands. Your shuffling feet tell another story, as you hear them scrape against the cobbles. Turning this way and that in the confines of the stall, you see you aren't a giantess.

The long equine torso extends behind you, a broad ass, and a swishing tail flicking agitatedly from side to side. You're a centauress!

1133211124.content:
He leaves after a while.

Your very tempted to relax. Being a filly, being pampered and worked, is seductive.

So you keep up your incantation in your mind, holding onto your previous life. You want to be human....and the idea of eating oats or chomping on grass enters your mind...and feels good.

And you banish it. You continue fighting for several hours, until after sunset.

At last the stable girl comes in. As you ignore the fresh hay while your stomach rumbles, she stares at you, then puts her on your muzzle, then puts her hand around your mane.

"Easy girl," she whispers.

You concentrate on her form, the curve of her back, her budding breasts, and the warmth of her embrace.

You want to be human, and her form is a blueprint. One moment, you're a horse. The next you have the same budding breasts, and your hair is shoulder length. It's not blonde like hers, but chestnut like you had as a filly. She is younger, but only a little, than you were.

But now, there are differences, your not perfect, but you could be sisters about the same age.

She holds you, and her touch is warm and welcoming. You want to be welcoming and warm, and as you think it you become so.

"Shh--- she whispers, "My name's Ivy. Let me go back to the house and get some spare clothes. Then we'll go in and meet Ma and Pa."

"Okay."

Reluctantly, you separate from her embrace. Quietly she walks out of the barn, while you huddle to keep warm in the cool evening.

Shortly, she comes back with clothes that are obviously one of her changes of clothes. They fit you perfectly.

Holding hands Ivy takes you out of the barn.

"What's your name?"

"Janus Aeduuard-Kettlewell Meade," you say in a girlish voice.

She gives you a sly smile.

"How about Jenny Meade from now on."

"Okay." You can't help but agree with her, realizing as you do that the magic that made you agreeable content as a filly makes you agreeable to her suggestions. You're too tired to mind. Besides, Jenny Meade seems to suit you.

She takes you to the farmhouse where you meet Ivy's parents and her older brothers. They feed you as you tell your story. You find yourself telling the truth because you don't your friend Ivy to think less of you. Besides, her brothers or rather brother Will seems to distract you, filling your stomach with butterflies messing with any attempt to deceive.

Ivy's Ma and Pa, Ma and Pa Erics, exchange a look. After a slight nod from Ma, Pa addresses you.

"You need to be at that school on Monday, that's five days from now. We'll take you there Sunday when we go into town. In the meantime, you help Jenny with her chores. That should give you both more time seeing as Ivy has no sisters or such to spend time with. Sound good to you?"
1133211124.title: Something else...

11332111241.content:
"Sounds fine to me. Thank you."

Ivy squeals in delight. John the older brother who is not Will rolls his eyes at his little sister's reaction. Ma gives Pa a 'hope you know what you're doing' look.

Will looks at you evenly and meets your eyes. You look back, trying to look as much as grown-up as a twelve-year-old can be. He nods approvingly.

The next four days are the happiest and free-ist of your entire life so far.

After waking up, eating, feeding, and taking care of the horses, it's midmorning. and you and Ivy have until midafternoon to explore. You picnic by a stream, then go to the crest of the hill where some older boys are skinny dipping. You find yourself staring, fascinated like any girl about to become boy crazy.

You go riding or rather racing each other. The Erics are horse traders and good at it. You go into town the second day and are introduced as "cousin Jenny" and play games and go into the copper piece store and buying candy. You gossip, braid each other's hair, share jokes. On the third day you're finishing each other's sentences.

There's more to it than that of course. You're changing and learning, very quickly. By the second day your posh accent has become a country twang. The first day your only passable with the horses, second day your competent, and the third day you have that same gentle touch that Ivy had when she held you. You don't give girls clothing a second thought after the first night and enjoy sharing a loft with Ivy where you two giggle easily together. She's the best friend you've ever had.

It's so different from the formality and the demands of your father, the strict decorum, and the distance between you and the boys your age.

The last night Pa takes you aside on the porch. You sit companionably for a while and look at the stars.

At last and with difficulty he talks about his time as a wizard soldier. He talks of being in strange lands doing things he isn't proud of and people he killed, not in combat but in massacres. I wouldn't trust a horse to him.

He talks about how the cause was wrapped in patriotism, but that it only benefited a few noble houses, while many died.

He talks of Father Dulu, how he reveled in violence, and how his students became monsters, including his dearest friend, whom he had to put down. He has tears in his eyes as he speaks.

You give him a hug and hold him for a long time, feeling his scratchy beard on your forehead.

"You don't need to go back. You'd be Cousin Jenny," he says. " Grow up, fall in love, hold your children." His words are a whisper, barely holding on to his composure. "Grow old with us. When you don't show up, they'll just assume you've failed your test."

Which you would have. But do you care?

The question hangs in the air.

Maybe, being this kind man's daughter, IS what you want. You can be a sister to Ivy who is the dearest friend you've had. They have a good life here, even if Will makes you jittery in a weird way. It would be joyous.

11333.content:
"You almost lost control at a few points." Father Dulu's tone is cautious, but he does appear impressed.

"You were aiming to become a centaur?" he asks.

"Yes, Reverend Father. I felt it important to make a good first impression." your voice cracks as you speak. You feel your mane cascade down your spine, a traditional feature of all centaurs.

He pauses for a second, appearing uncertain how to proceed.

"You do realise that you need to have a clear image in your mind of exactly how you wish a transformation to complete..."

"Certainly father..." You run a hand over your body, in case you have horns or some other non-centaur feature.

"That you need to put aside modesty and concentrate even if it makes you uncomfortable... else the magic will take it's own path..."

"Please, father... In what way have I failed..." you sound a little more panicked than you want, but clearly he's trying to hint at something.

"Centauress, not centaur. Your equine half is a filly." he says.

Twisting in disbelief, you try to check out your own nethers....

You feel a churning, rippling sensation in your torso as the magic reaches towards it's conclusion. Your nipples swell, and swell, growing in sensitivity as they do. The feeling is oddly arousing, and you have to restrain your hands from reaching to caress them. You find you are panting in a husky but feminine manner.

Just as it feels irresistible you feel the pressure mount and mount. Without warning your breasts develop beneath the enlarged nipples and areolas.

Your shirt presses forward trying to contain the new flesh. The buttons start to gap, allowing the breasts to become visible to Father Dulu, you are embarrassed, and try to cover your chest with your arms. In the hope that'll contain or at least cover the problem.

But in the haze of hormones, you didn't feel your arms change too. They are thinner and less muscular, a smoothing layer of fat keeps them looking feminine.

Your eyes boggle as you try to estimate what size your new bust is. A difficult task with your inexperience and this view isn't one that you are used to either. But, they are too large to be held or even covered in your arms. They bulge over the top, and are squeezed out the bottom too.

As you feel the tingle of the magic flee your finger tips.... you feel a lot less cocky and self-assured.

Father Dulu floors you with one more question.

"Is your equine half house-trained?" his eye-brow rises.

Your mouth flaps silently before you close it, with a click of your teeth.

"If you prefer I can induct you as sorceress... or a wizard?"

114.content:
You had to go within the depths of the college, toward what represented the college of the Grey order. Rare are the students who actually dares to follow the cold dark ways of the order, after all. Rarer were whose that would actually study necromancy per say, given, unlike Vicissitude, the toll of using necromantic means had effects that only few could resist, let alone remain a living being.

Even if by nature, Vicissitude is often considered as evil, given most of the results end up in bad actions, it is actually neutral, as they affect the body with magical means, such as blessing of luck, and curses of weaknesses. And, generally, whose dealing with the undead commonly lose the ability of casting the good-sided parts of the Vicissitude spells.

The college, on its own, looks like some kind of underground castle, with actually quite a few torches, most of them lit, with access to what you got to know are crypts, rather often paired with a somewhat present of rotting meat. And while it is wide, signs scattered on the walls helps the newcomers and students to get around without getting lost.

As a new student, you had been tasked to go at one of the numerous library, to meet the main professor. Due to the lack of confirmed necromancers and potential teachers, compared to the other orders, thoses of the grey order often wise attend classes of multiple grades. Rumored as being among the most watchful, they have the full right of excluding students of the order, be it by inadequacy, incapability, non-respect of the rules, or simply that they became mindless undeads (Generally, they are thrown in the crematory.).

You meet up with other new students and some older students in what seems a mix of a library and a classroom. In front of a desk, on which can be found some bones and a human head, stands a woman in a dark cloak. Her cloak is wide, but reveals her feminine assets on her chest, as well as delicate, but creepily white, while looking they'd belong to a living being, feet. Having golden eyes, and well broomed long hair, you wondered if she was really a wizard. Let alone a necromancer.

Whispers and even a laughter could be heard from the other new students, while the professor grins and speaks up, 'Hello, students, and welcome to the newcomers to the grey order. I am professor Yamaw for thoses who doesn't know me, and will be one of your teachers for what i hope will be a fruitful study of seven years. Or the first one to burn you to a crisp.~ Accidents can always occur, after all.. But nevermind that, you will? We're not here to kill you, but to teach you the manners to living through the underestimate possibilities of the afterdeath. And.. Given some of you already lost focus.. Let me show a warning and possibility.. It could be quite painful, after all.~'. She pulls the left sleeve of her robe off, revealing what looks like a bone arm, except you could swear it was stolen from a lizard. 'As you know, necromancy gives you potential control over flesh and bones, and.. If you got the need to remplace a limb off, you can seek Dr. 'Lizard arm', is which myself!'. She giggles. 'Know that i also have a knack for breaking bones.. Especially from unruly little idiots..~'.

All the new students, including you, weeps in fear, while most of the older ones prefers to dodge the professor's gaze, visibly not really tempted to try their luck, or to feel her wrath. Eventually, your fear change into apprehension, as you grab the stub of what was left of your left arm.

When you were younger, you had quite the cold personality, while not quite disobedient, you weren't certainly among the most prudent, so much you strained where you shouldn't.. One day, you cot attacked by a hungry feral wolf. Given you managed to flee before he'd jump on you, your wound weren't directly mortal, but you wouldn't have survived, if it was for the lucky apparition of an undead that punched and made the wolf flee. It was controlled by a mage in grey, and even if he didn't quite smelled good, he still took the time to fleshcraft what was left of your arm, so it wouldn't bleed or infect. You wondered back then that why he didn't used your arm, given the wolf didn't quite managed to eat it away, but you suppose that it was stolen by the same mage that helped you..

The professor speaks up, 'Alright all. Here's the main rules. And quoting them back would certain not harm anyone: No harming the standing undeads nor living beings, outside of duels and certain circumstances. No reanimation with souls without authorization. Soulless constructions and golems are, on the other hand, fine, as long as the first rule is respected. And no rituals, even if you might eventually learn more about thoses. Especially the lich ritual. Thoses are exclusively reserved for grade 6 or higher, and never, *EVER* within the college. We are respecting a certain neutrality, and if you are caught disregarding our neutrality and/or rules, you risk getting excluded without further notice, and might get into painful situations. Like me breaking your bones.~ I heard broken limbs are the best way to make a human scream..~'.

One of the older students mutters, 'Lizard arm struck again, distilling fear in the newcomers..'. The visage of the professor harden up, like she was angry, 'What did you said?'. 'N-nothing!'. 'I prefer that~. Now, fellow students, guide the newcomers to the storage, the class still start soon.'.

The students move out, and you were about to, too, when the professor stops you, 'Not you. Not now.'. A chill goes through your spine, 'Y-yes, professor..?'. 'I've notice that you lost an arm. And given you're not skilled enough to repair it yourself, i'm willing you help you, this once. And don't worry.. I won't harm you. Yet~'. 'T-that's kind..'. The professor giggles, then leads you aside. 'You can refuse if you want. And if you want, i can pick parts for you. Your arm will be as good as new!'. 'A-and what if i want to choose..?'. 'Your choice.~'. 'Even an arm like your..?'. 'Oh, sure, cutie!~ But regardless of what you do, you'll follow class like the others!'. 'Y-yeah..'.

You remember Nut telling you that emotions could make a spell of break it. As you speak out the last words of the spell you open your eyes to see the effect. You're surprised to see...
11511.title: Area illusions

11512.content: You thought area illusions are too big after thinking it through and soul tinkering may be somewhat out of your reach, maybe with something smaller you should begin. A person or a object would suffice enough, but what will you choose?
11512.title: Objects/ people illusions

115122.content:
A person would be challenging enough, and maybe give you the respect you deserve. You could try to make an illusion of a human, but that would make it too easy. Then you remember a book you had read back at the orphanage. It was one of the biggest books you ever had read there, but what it made so special was that it contained illustrations of the different races of your world. You would look through the book for hours, reading on where to find them, what their culture was based on, the gods they worshipped.
All those memories fade away as you stare at the face of Nut. You had to pick out a race, but you can't think of anything. Out of habit you feel your ear, your too long ear. Then you think of it, maybe an elf would be impressive enough?
115122.title: A person

choices: A combination of the elf and Anne
A combination of a tree and an elf
1151221.content:
You then resolve on an elf. You cough a bit as you try to get the attention of your fellow classmates.

"I will demonstrate the illusion of an elf," you solemnly announce to the room.

"Yeah, probably his mother," Sweet Anne shouts. Sweet Anne got her nickname because she is the exact opposite of a sweet girl, insensitive, rude, a trouble maker, everything the Goddess forbids. Even though Anne doesn't look too bad with her long blond hair and a smile that almost never fades from her face, she is still the most obnoxious girl you have ever met.

"Anne don't try my patience," Nut tells her. "Just go for it," he instructs you.

You then concentrate, you close your eyes and try remembering the spell. While you recite the spell, you have to think clearly of the person. You have to remember every detail, what kind of shoes, their hair, chest size. You probably wouldn't have it right the first time but you try it anyway. Thinking about the elf you saw in the book, you still remember her sitting against a tree, with her cute ears and those eyes that would pierce you when you looked at them.

Your classmates mumble as you feel the magic coming from your hand. You don't dare to open your eyes, it would probably ruin your concentration. You then concentrate about her midriff, her belly looking soft yet stern and...

"Ouch!" You feel something hitting you. You look around and see sweet Anne grinning with chewed paper on her desk. She would make pieces of paper fly in the air and then hit you right in the face. The previous day she had hit you again while you were just reading, you hated her so much.

"Keep your focus, Mead!" Nut says. You look over and saw the shape of your illusion changing. You had to focus on the elf, but then you feel another wad of wet paper hit you again. You would love to make her pay for it, but realize that she's doing it to make you lose your concentration.

You feel the magic fading as the spell completes; you open your eyes to see the spell hasn't worked as it should. Instead of the elf sitting against an imaginary tree, .... was sitting there.
1151221.title: Elf it will be.

11512211.content:
The entire class was speechless as you were all looking at Anne. "What are you all looking at?" She asked confused. When she looked down at herself she saw what had happened. Her entire body had changed. Her shoes were gone, displaying her changed little feet. Her legs were longer and skinnier. Her waist could be seen and just as you imagined it in the book, Anne's waist was looking soft yet stern. Her face had undergone some changes as well, you were delighted to see she had pointy ears. Her bone cheeks were more visible, her mouth, eyes and hair were just the same although her hair looked more golden.

"Excellent work Mead." Nut said coming forward. I didn't expect you to target Anne there, but she surely was the perfect subject. You were happy to get the compliment, you felt yourself a bit drained too. "You can sit down now." He told you waving at your bench.

"Professor, aren't you forgetting something?" Anne asked.

"No, not that I can think of, alright class we will all give mister Mead feedback about his performance and not just the bad points." Nut continued.

"Professor, I'm still looking like an Elf weirdo." Anne said.

You heard some mumbling going on in the class, although everyone made fun of your Elf mother, discriminating Elves wasn't funny. You even saw an Elf classmate of yours looking angry at Anne.

"Anne, if you badger the people you now half represent I don't think you deserve to go back to normal." Nut said getting serious.

"I know, I know but can I please return back to normal." Anne pleaded.

Nut shook his head. "I would love to turn you back, but I'm not the wizard who put the spell on you. Only Mead can turn you back." He pointed at you.

"I-I'm not going ask that idiot for help."

"Fine, but then you're going to be stuck like this forever." Nut said.

"Forever? What do you mean? An illusion spell usually wears off in a few hours." Anne asked surprised.

"Yeah, that's normally the case. But Mead was demonstrating a copy illusion spell in front of us which requires a wizard to undo it himself, otherwise it will still remain there. But because you made Mead lose focus he combined the Elf woman he saw and you into one illusion you might say."

"No, this can't be." Anne said getting nervous.

The other kids were silent and you could hear a few whispers, nobody wanted a fate as worse as that.

Anne got up and moved towards your desk, she got on her knees and looked down as she said: "Please change me back Mead."

You were surprised as what she has done. Anne would never go down on her knees for someone, but looking like an Elf must be something she really didn't want. Although you didn't agree with that opinion, somehow she looked as stunning as the Elf woman you saw in the book.

You considered turning her back, she wasn't the worst bully you had, but then you looked Nut in the eyes. You saw in his eyes telling you not to do it. It would be the perfect punishment for Anne, teaching her not to be rude about others.
11512211.title: A combination of the elf and Anne

115122111.content:
You couldn't resist a girl in trouble, even if the girl pesters you the whole time. "Fine I'll change you back." You tell her with a shrug.
"That's nice of you Mead." She says a little shy standing up again. The whole class mumbles as you were never that nice. You can see Nut looking a little disappointed but you give him a wink only he sees.

You stand in front of the class again and focus on the spell to break the illusion. Anne stood in front of you, closing her eyes hard, hoping that the nightmare would be over soon. But you had one little surprise for her in store.
You focus on changing her back but decide to let one part of it stay with her. The illusion would break in a few hours but you wouldn't tell Anne that. She deserves something for all her pestering. You focus so that her... stay the same.
115122111.title: Change her back.

choices: Seek the help of a senior wizard
Try to break the illusion yourself
11512212.content:
"Oh no, Sir! I'm sorry."

Nut stands in front of the class, his body hidden beneath your botched illusion. His arms are up-stretched, fingers splayed and split into many long, thin branches weighed down by a thousand green leaves that rustle in a non-existent wind. His body is female, naked and elven with small breasts dappled beneath the shade of his foliage. His skin is dark, woody brown, with the midriff you had pictured as being so soft mottled with bark. Part way down his legs, his thighs merge into roots that snake through the classroom beneath desks and between the floorboards. The face however is still the bearded, middle-aged face of Professor Walmut.

"Not to worry, Mead," Nut says encouragingly, ignoring the snickering of the class. "Targeting aside, you've demonstrated a very successful illusion, including full sensory immersion. It...genuinely feels like my feet are rooted to the spot," he grunts, wriggling his body as he tries to loosen the deep roots sunk into the ground. "In fact I can feel the cool breeze blowing through... my leaves... Very, ah... yes, very pleasant... in... fact."

"S-sir?"

"Mmhh?" he murmurs. "Oh! Of course, the dispel spell!" He begins to struggle, his branches rustling but his arms remaining locked in their skyward position as resolutely as if they actually were made from wood. "Ngh! If only I could move my... move my... my arms... I..."

His words trail into nothing and his face grows dreamlike and distant.

The classroom falls silent. Anne, seeing an opportunity, bounces a ball of paper off Nut's head, but it does nothing to bring him back from whatever imaginary forest he is currently planted.
11512212.title: A combination of a tree and an elf

11513.content: You thought about doing some replace illusions or perhaps some soul tinkering. Both were a little bit higher advanced than someone of your age should but you were practicing a lot after time.
11513.title: Other illusions/ Soul tinkering.

choices: Jean is singing like a bird.
Jean looks normal, or is he?
115132.content:
Soul tinkering was one of the most difficult forms of magic in your order. Making someone forget everything or put someones soul inside a soulstone required much practice. Luckily you had that.

"I'm going to demonstrate in front of you, taking out a living essence," you tell the class proudly.

Everyone mumbles after hearing that.

"Can you really do that, Meade?" Nut asked you.

"Sure I can," you tell him proud. I'll take out the essence of something simple like this bird. You tell him as you point at one of the practice birds Nut keeps. The bird is in a cage on the desk, singing all the time. You then concentrate on the spell, you make the necessary moves and then pull out the essence of the bird. It's like a little cube, but unlike a human which displays human thought, the bird's thoughts are blank.

"Impressive, Meade." Nut congratulates you. Now please return it back." You see the bird has changed colors, it's white as a sheet quite as a mouse. You are about to send it back, but then someone throws a piece of paper at you. You turn around and see Jean, the bully of this class laughing. His long brown hair, covers his rat like face. Without thinking you point at him, cursing him. And then before you know it the essence of the bird now flies directly at him. Before you or Nut can stop it, the essence enters Jean's body. A sudden bright flash occurs before you can see the result. What happened?
115132.title: Soul tinkering

choices: Try the spell out on someone.
1151321.content:
The whole class is staring at Jean who is sitting on his table and singing like a bird. His body looks fine so far, but then you notice how thin his legs had become just like the bird. As someone pointed at Jean, Jean suddenly flapped his arms like a bird trying to take off. Sadly his arms weren't covered in feathers so he hit the ground very hard. The whole class had to laugh about it, even Nut had a little smile on his face as he saw his worst student hitting the ground very hard. One of the boys even had a worm with him which he fed to Jean. To all your amazement Jean just swallowed the worm whole.

"Impressive Meade, Nut said as he instructed two students to hold Jean as Nut performed the spell to extract the bird essence. "Normally the soul who was transferred inside would be considered the weakest and would pass the host it's soul. I'm not sure its' thanks to your talent or that Jean has a rather weak soul and my bird has even a stronger than his."

"Thanks professor." You say quite proud of yourself, even if Jean made it possible.

Nut then extracts the essence of the bird and pulled it back inside the bird. At once the bird got back it's colors and sang again like before. Jean also woke up at that same moment. "Yuck I feel like I ate dirt or something. The whole class had to laugh, and Nut called everyone back to attention. Nut gave you a plus and as you sat down, you heard the people talking about you. This time in a good way to be said.

After class is finished Nut is holding you back and makes you promise not to use that spell again. But as wizards use exceptions most of the time, he tells you, you can use the spell only when the need arises.

As you step outside you wonder if that need would be now or later.
1151321.title: Jean is singing like a bird.

1153.content: How about exploring the castle? You would do that often in your free time. Might as well do that now. Or visit your friend Roland, the salesman who comes often to the castle to sell his wares.
1153.title: Go somewhere else

choices: Go up to the girl's dormitories.
11531.content:
You think about exploring the castle, going to class would remind you too much about Vadicus. No way, you would go there. Being in your room would also be good, but too risky someone might catch you. No, going through the castle would look like you have important business and people wouldn't disturb you.

You set out through the castle, it's a pretty big one, magically enhanced. You don't see the reason why they couldn't just build it bigger. The castle is build on an ancient pool of magic, the place just glows of magic, allowing students to tap even deeper into their magic. But it wasn't the safest place always outside and inside. Outside the school lies a big forest, and if you don't know the location of the castle you are forever lost in there, captured by one of the creatures who live there or you might end where you once began for the lucky ones.
Inside the castle it wasn't that safe either, who would ever think otherwise with so many students roaming around. Lucky most of the incidents were not that big, some bruises or in your case your head being plunged. Although it hadn't been this way always, from the seniors you've heard the ghost stories of students who wander around the castle at night and the next day they are found they are lying on the ground with just a smile on their face, their soul been ripped out from their bodies.

A bit of hogwash you think , that would never happen. Unless.... You wake up from your thoughts. You are in front of a couple of stairs, one going up and the other going down. The stairs that go up, are to the girl's dormitory. You haven't been there but now would be a good time to try it. The stairs going down are the ones leading to the dungeon, the deepest parts of the castle. Not many people go there, at least not without a good reason. You remember Vadicus bragging to his friends going there once. You're really in a mood to show him that you have more guts to go there at once. Which way should you go?
11531.title: Explore the castle

choices: Look at some of the cages.
115312.content:
You follow the stairs down, making as little noise as you can. While you are not afraid at first, you're less sure of your decisions as you are going deeper into the castle. Torches light the way downstairs and each of them go out as you pass near them. You can only press forward to see what is hiding down here.

As you reach the foot of the stairs, it's a bit dark, in front of you a big room emerges containing cages. As you step inside the room you see the torches on the wall light up. As each one of them light up after the other, you can't believe what's inside these cages. They are all sorts of creatures, ranging from Fey to Orcs to even changelings. You are wondering what they are doing down here. Some of these races have the same rights as humans. Then you notice a book lying on a desk in a corner of the room.

Luckily a torch was hold up above the desk so you can read the book. As you read through it, you discover it's a journal. The room you are standing in was build in the days of the old. An experiment was conducted, the wizards of old tried to change fate by taking over the bodies of others. While they were first using human bodies, some of the wizards wondered if any of the other races genetics would empower magic abilities. So that's the reason these creatures are here, being test subjects. At the last page you notice a spell being written, it's the one the wizard's of old had used. You could always use it, and so you tear off the page from the journal and stuff it in your pocket.

As you are about to leave you look at the different cages, perhaps you could take a look at the different species. Who knows? Maybe you could try the spell yourself. On the other hand you don't want to be caught here.
115312.title: Go down to the dungeon.

1153121.content:
You decide to take a look at some of the species being hold here. A little peek never hurts. You walk through the gaps between the cages. You are a bit scared the people inside will see you, but it seems the wizards have been using some sort reflective glass. You can see some of them looking in your direction but never where you are currently standing.

The first of the species living in here, looks like one of the vorelves. It's pretty dark in there, but you can see a pair of hungry eyes looking at you like a snake on it's prey. You occasionally see something of a yellow tail sweeping rather quickly out of the shadows. Near the cage you see a button with a picture of some meat next to it. You push the button and from above the cage a piece of meat comes down the cage. It just happens in a few seconds as you see the vorelf leaping out of the shadows making it's jaw even bigger and swoop up the piece of meat in one move and moving back to the shadow's again. You wonder if you should examine it up closer.
1153121.title: Look at some of the cages.

choices: Tell them, it would not hurt.
Don't tell them, they are not to be trusted.
1153122.content:
You don't want to mess with any of the things in here. You better get out of here. You run up the stairs not caring if someone hears you. You just want to get out of here. As you're near the top of the stairs you can hear some mumbling. You think there might be students just hanging outside the door. This would be perfect, they would see you leave the dungeon which would make them ask you what you were doing down there. Making up some story about how you heard something behind the door and how you investigated the dungeon would show them how brave you were. That would make them respect you more. So you decide to just not run but walk the last few steps outside. You slowly open the door and walk outside not knowing what you would face.

Outside you can see a couple of boys talking to each other as they see you leaving the dungeon. "Hold on mate, where do you think you're going?" The largest one asks you. "Just heading to class." You excuse yourself. "No way, we saw you leaving the dungeon." Another big guy asks you. "Yes I did, so what?" They all looked at each other.

"Did you found something there inside?" The largest guy asks you.

"I-I..." You wonder if you should tell these guys what you found down there.
1153122.title: Go upstairs again.

choices: make you an offer you can't refuse.
play with you a little bit.
11531221.content:
"I found this," you tell the group of boys as you pull out the page with the body swap spell. "What is it?" A scrawny little kid asks. "It's a body swap spell of course, you can switch bodies with it."

"You idiot of course we know." The largest guy tells the scrawny kid.

Something clicks in your mind as it all becomes clear to you. If these guys must have used the body swap spell. Then that would mean they...

"Good guessing mate." The largest boy smirks as he grabs you. "Only a little too late, don't you think?" The last thing you see is his fist heading for your face before everything turns black.

When you wake up you have major headache. Like you hit your head against a stone wall or something like that. And why can't you move your arms? When you open your eyes everything looks a little foggy. You can make out some figures in front of you. When your vision clears up you can see those are the boys you talked to. "Nice to see you waking up. Enjoyed your little nap." He asks bitter sweet.

"Who are you?" You ask looking around yourself. You can see you're back in the dungeon.

"We, we're just a couple of boys enjoying our education here. Well actually a couple of girls to tell you the truth." He says pointing at the rest of his gang.

"I'm Morn, or actually Morgana, ugh disgusting name." He explains. "We were a couple of witches studying here, when we discovered this dungeon. As we found out what it was about, we decided we wanted permanent education."

"So that means, you're...." You ask.

"Yes, we're rather old. More than a couple of hundred years old I'm afraid." Morn smiles as he tells you.

"And we know everything bout you Mead. Quit a lot." Morn tells you. "Enough to know that you could become one of the greatest magic users of these times. And so that is why we're going to ...
11531221.title: Tell them, it would not hurt.

choices: They win, expelling you from your body
They lose - their powers and knowledge become yours
115312211.content:
"And so that is why we're going to make you an offer you can't refuse." A wisp of something like smoke escapes from the side of his mouth. As he talks, it grows into a torrent of strange, silver mist that spill between his lips. "See we're taking your body. With your powers added to our own, we'll be the most powerful magic user this world has ever seen." He grins, looking round at the other boys who have gathered in a circle around your immobile body. "We still can't agree if we're gonna use it to rule or just for fun, but when we become One we'll know."

He tilts his head back, his mouth falling open to release a cohesive cloud of glowing mist which hangs in the air in front of you. The other boys do the same and you watch as their souls flow into one another, forming a single, pulsating ball of brightly burning light. One by one, their bodies drop to the stone floor, lying still.

The souls swarm towards your face, reaching out with silver tendrils. You squeeze your mouth and eyes shut, but you can feel it, feel them, flowing like freezing cold water into your eyes, nostrils, ears, and mouth. Your body convulses against its restraints as it becomes host to an entire coven.

They're inside you, fighting to remove your soul from your own body. Already you can feel your grip loosening - your fingers and feet are numb, your vision fading. Instinctively you fight back, but it's a losing battle. There are many of them and only one of you. The world feels like you're sensing it from the end of a long,dark tunnel as your grip on your physical form loosens.
115312211.title: make you an offer you can't refuse.

choices: Take over one of the bodies left.
Fly your way out of here.
1153122111.content:
You feel torn from your body, which is what is happening. You're suddenly blown out of your body, like a cannon. You're floating in the air, trying to find your center of gravity.

"Well, I'll be." You hear a voice suddenly mumbling. You look around and see your body standing there with a smug on his face.

"Hey, that's my body!" You scream although your voice sounds a bit more wailing now.

"Correction, it's our body now. And with just a few years of practice, one of the most powerful magi of them all. And this of course too." Your body said as it held it's groin. You noticed your voice sounded a little lower when your body said it.

"In due time, now let's go. And remember Janus, you can't take over this body again so I suggest you learn how to take over another one." And with that your body laughs as it moves up the stairs.

You're in a kind of a pickle here. What to do now? You always wanted to float around, but not like this. You find it incredible that you find yourself so calm, like these things happen all the time. Well first thing you have to do is get out of here. But how?

You could take over one of the bodies the witches have left you. Mind you they are not the most powerful, but it would be better than nothing.

Another thing you could is try to get this flying under control. Perhaps you could explore the castle a bit, and who knows what you might discover.
1153122111.title: They win, expelling you from your body

11531221112.content:
You shiver as to think about taking one of the bodies the witches inhabited. Who knows what they did to them? You're better off as this form for now.

You think as how to move around like this, there's no ground underneath your feat but maybe it's like swimming? You try out a few strokes and to your surprise you move forward. How more powerful the strokes are, how faster you move. You soon shoot out as a rocket through the roof of one of the towers as you take a bird's eye view of the castle. From up here it looks so little, so insignificant. You then look around, you can see the forest surrounding the castle. A little bit further you see a little village and in the distance you think you can see a tower. You could stay here for hours. But then something tingles, you feel yourself shivering even though you are a spirit. It feels like it wants you gone from here. You don't feel safe anymore up here in the air, like a cloud suddenly blocked all the sun light.

You decide it's better to enter the castle again. With even more powerful strokes you are quickly inside the castle again. Seeing where you are, you believe you are near the girl's tower. Grinning a little, you think it wouldn't be bad if you could take a peek inside. After all no boy has entered that tower since it was build. You are about to make your way when you see Vadicus coming round the corner of the hallway. You are almost afraid he will see you, but he doesn't give you a look at all as he goes to the nearest bathroom. This would be a good opportunity to get back to him for the things he did to you.

What to do? You think.
11531221112.title: Fly your way out of here.

choices: You go and listen to what the girls say about you.
115312211121.content:
What were you thinking? Why should you let such a simple thing as revenge ruin your chance to be the first one up that tower. No way you will let that happen. You hover your way up to the entrance of the girl's tower and float in awe as you realize this could be it. You take a deep breath of air and float your way inside. Normally you would feel a shock going through you but now you just float to the other side of the door. You punch in the air, shouting yes! when you suddenly hear some noises. You quickly hover to the ceiling as you just see a couple of girls leaving the tower.

"Did any of you hear that?" The blond haired girl asked the other two.

"Yeah, must be the sound of another moron trying to open this door, clearly they don't learn their lessons very well." The red headed girl answered.

They all laugh as they open the door and walk away. Well they wouldn't laugh if they knew what was happening.

You then fly up to reach the highest point of the tower. Ouch! You banged your head against the ceiling. Strange, why would the ceiling be blocked off while the door was open. You quickly look down where you are. It seems like the common room for the girls. You saw a few girls practicing their magic, others were chatting in a corner with each other while others were sleeping off. You have to admit it's a lot cleaner here than by the guys, there are even a couple of vases with flowers. In the corner of your eye you spot the washrooms. You grin perverted as it was the ideal spot to see the girl in their natural habitat. You make your way over until you suddenly hear your name being spoken by some of the girls. Should you listen in on them?
115312211121.title: Visit the girl's tower.

1153122111212.content:
You are intrigued about what the conversation is about, but there is something about possible seeing a girl undress herself that changes your mind. You fly through the wall into the girl's bathroom. The room looks similar to the boy's washroom, although the stench is less in here. Something was drawing your attention below you. The washroom door opened and a couple of mean looking girls were coming through. From their looks on their faces you know they meant business. They don't look familiar to you, but judging from their age they must be in a higher class than you. They continue their way towards one of the stalls where they stand.

"Margaria, it's us, the fun squad." The meanest girl says knocking hard on the door.

You can hear a soft cry coming from the stall and the other girls begin to giggle.

"Ah little Margaria all alone in here, no one coming to rescue you." The mean looking girl answers in a sweet but icky voice.

"We're here because you haven't finished our homework yet, we need to have it by tomorrow. So if you don't want such a lovely introduction to the toilets as the first day, I hope you have it by the end of the day."

The girls then take off, still laughing as they leave the washrooms. You feel yourself getting angry, here there was a girl just like you being bullied by a girl just like Vadicus.

You wonder if you should go after the bullies or make contact with Margaria.
1153122111212.title: You go to the washrooms.

choices: "I know how you could be one."
11531221112122.content:
You decide to stay and talk with Margaria. You know how it feels to be bullied, having someone to talk to helps. You go flying down and making sure she isn't doing anything you float in front of her as she's crying looking down.

"Hello." You just say.

"Huh?" Margaria looks up and sees you floating in front of her. She looks totally shocked, like she has seen a ghost. You and her just stare at each other, until you hear water flowing really quiet. You realize it's Margaria peeing from shock and you have to laugh a little about the noise. It seems catchy as Margaria begins to laugh too, and soon you are both laughing hard. It takes a while to get all serious, but by then Margaria doesn't seem scared of you any more.

"Who are you?" She asks curious.

"I'm Janus, you are Margaria right?"

She nods. "How do you know?"

"I overheard that bully talking to you, sorry about that."

Margaria looks away. "Don't be, it-it's just how it is every day."

"Don't you have anyone who can help you?" You ask her.

She shakes her head. "I don't have many friends only my best friend Kylee and she's in the same grade as me. I tried to talk about it with one of my teachers but every time I try those girls show up. I just don't know what to do."

She begins crying again, you don't know what to do so you just let her cry it out. After a few minutes she's only sniffing.

"I-I guess you don't have that trouble."

"Not any more." You reply thinking about your morning encounter with Vadicus.

She looks at you and smiles. "I wish I could be a ghost, never having to fear to get bullied again."

You say....
11531221112122.title: Go talk with Maragria.

choices: "A strange blight came across the crops."
"The children complained of the shadows moving."
"Young Jed returned from the forest with familiar scars."
12.content:
You watch as the flames flicker in the fire. The village bustles with activity around you, the village elder is sent for, and one of the men takes your horse to the stable. The children play running and chasing one another around, while their mothers watch. They are practically hovering over the children, but with an eye darting towards the edge of the forest you guess that the shadow creatures have returned.

The elder waves a little uncertainly, he is happy to see you but less so that he had to call you.

"Sit down, Joshua." you indicate another wooden stool by the fire. He looks disappointed and surprised.

"Are there more coming?" he asks uncertainly, his voice is firm. However he doesn't want to offend you. His hands are restless in his lap.

"I can call for reinforcements if that is needed." you assure him.

One woman offers you a tankard of tea, before offering the other to Joshua. Politely you thank her, but keep your attention on Joshua. He is glad to keep his hands occupied.

"Please take your time, start at the beginning and tell me every detail." You smile confidently and lean forward to listen intently.

His voice is a little whispery, and you want to ask him to speak up but you don't want to interrupt him.

"It started a week ago.....
12.title: A Sorcerer working for the protection of mankind.

choices: "Take me to where you saw them last."
"I'd like to stay the night and see if they reappear."
121.content:
"It started a week ago, on the eve of the harvest festival - now there's a cruel joke. A strange blight came across the crops. The plants, they were corrupted, wilting and rotting before our very eyes. By the morning, our entire harvest was nothing but filth."

"It affected everything?"

"Aye! Turnips, 'taters, corn... It's not unknown for one crop to suffer, maybe two, but not all of them and never so fast."

"Were they duped?" you ask. It was common for con men to target these outlying settlements. They would use a rudimentary spell to duplicate a wagon of seed, then sell it cheap to unsuspecting farmers. The seed would grow just fine for a while, until the life-sustaining magic that had created them faded. The crop would swiftly die, often leaving the farmer in dire straights.

Joshua's bushy white eyebrows twitch at your half-accusation. He avoids your gaze. "N-no. No no. They were good crop seed from last year!"

You give a slight sigh, like a disappointed parent. The elder is many times your age, but you could be four hundred years old for all he knows, an impression you like to reinforce. "Joshua, need I remind you it is a criminal offense to lie to a wizard going about his duties. Were the seeds you used to grow these crops legitimate?"

"We... were assured by the Goblin-" he mutters quietly, defeated.

"A Goblin's word is worth even less than their wares; you must know that." Another sigh and a stern glare. "I should hope you haven't brought me all this way on a mere matter of faulty grain, Joshua. Do you have samples of the blight?"

"My granddaughter does- Ilia!"

A young woman steps forward. Like all the people of this village, she has a plain face, with dull brown hair cropped short and a thin, wiry body, though she looks better fed than the others. A piece of silver glitters around her neck. It is the symbol of the Goddess; the same symbol, you notice, that adorns the surface of a clay pot that she pushes into your hands.

She sits back and watches you closely with an expression of open distaste, her eyes flitting occasionally to the bowl in your hands. With a smile, you realise she is expecting your unholy body to burst into flames at the merest touch of her holy symbol. These religious types always do.

Twisting the bowl in your hands to shift around the blighted ears of corn that sit in it, you can see nothing out of the ordinary. They are shriveled, with brown-black kernels like rotten teeth and leaves that are dry and yellow as old parchment. "This appears to be regular blight."

"Bu-but it didn't spread like it!" Joshua exclaims, growing agitated. He can see he is losing you. "It was fast... faster than anything I've ever seen before. Faster than we could tear it out. Faster than we could burn it. It was unnatural! You have to believe me!"

"I believe you," you assure him. But you don't. He has a desperate look to him. This is a remote village, a reclamation project settled less than forty years ago when the then-King decreed an program of rebuilding the lands lost to the creeping wild. It has no wealth and few neighbors to trade with if it had. They are relying on you to report back to your superiors with a conclusion of occult interference, which would necessitate that their liege lord deliver aid to see them through the winter months. If not, the blame will fall squarely on their shoulders and they will be left to fend for themselves.

But backwaters like this are always losing their harvests and involving the church or the study with false claims, tying up much needed manpower. Normally a wizard wouldn't have been sent this far out on so trivial a matter, but since this is your first case they're starting you off small. Besides, there's a nuance to their claim, an additional fact that is worth a cursory investigation.

"There was something else to your story. Tell me about these shadow creatures," you request.

"They've been seen around the village for months now,", Ilia interjects before Joshua can speak. "They were in the fields the night before the crops died, dozens of them. Nobody dared go out there, except me. They're like smoke. You can only see them when they move, and only out the corner of your eye; they disappear when you look at them straight."

"Did they appear to be doing anything in the fields? Were they interfering with the crops?"

"They were doing the work of demons," she says bluntly. "Drawing hellrunes in the soil. Polluting our land with magic. And I fail to see what a wizard can do to help. This isn't a job for a wizard. They should have sent a priestess."

"Ilia..." the elder tries to quiet her.

"But they should! A priestess could consecrate the ground in a day. Magic isn't any use against magic. It only makes things worse."

"Ilia, stop!" Joshua gasps. "Aye, a holy woman could clear the blight, but what good is that to us with winter at our doorsteps and our stores empty? With magic we can replace what we've lost."

"I'm afraid conjuring food is not the reason I'm here," you interject, keeping your voice level, even while smarting from the suggestion that your powers, years of training and finite toll be spent on such menial work. "These shadows, however, are."
121.title: "A strange blight came across the crops."

1211.content:
Ilia's look is sullen as she leads you from the fire, though not half as dismayed as the expression on the elder that you leave behind. You leave the village, following a well-worn track that leads down to an area sheltered from the cold north winds by the hills and the sparse woodland.

You smell the pungent rot of the blight long before you can see it, and hear it even sooner, though only when you see the thick, swirling cloud of flies that hangs over the fields do you figure out the source of the high, relentless buzz. Ilia hesitates at the edge of the corruption, clutching at her necklace for comfort. You have to pull your cloak up over your nose to get closer, but even still your throat burns and your eyes water. Fat, black flies hit your face.

The colours are inverted: the crops and hedgerows reduced to brown stumps while the soil is bile green, with the consistency of cream cheese. Where you stand, a few feet from the edge of the corruption, the soil is healthy and brown, a transition far too sudden to be natural.

"This is where you saw the shadows?"

Ilia shakes her head and points out across the fields to the epicenter of the blight. You figured as much.

"Looks like a standard mark of corruption," you choke out. "Area of effect, maybe half a mile radius. Standard... standard stuff. Should just be a case of erasing the mark. Right... uh... here goes..."

A tentative step forward and your foot sinks deep into the soft soil, dragged down with wet slurps of escaping swamp gas. In a moment, you're up to your knee. You try to pull free but your leg might as well be set in stone for all the good it does you. Your free leg scrapes deep grooves in the grass.

Ilia's arms slide under your armpits. Your combined effort wrenches you free, though not your boot which is swallowed up by the fettid earth. "Mother protect us," Ilia gasps as the two of you land on your backs. "They said wizards were supposed to be smart. What was your plan, to walk across?"

The corruption penetrates deeper into the topsoil than you thought. You reconsider your approach. From the air perhaps? You don't like the look of the air traffic, but at least birds don't have much in the way of a sense of smell.

12111.content:
You kick off your remaining boot, unclasp your cloak and drop it to the floor. The tough leather cuirass that all wizards are expected wear beneath it takes considerably more time to remove. Unbuckling your sword and sheathed wand, you lay them on your cloak and kick off your trousers. Down to your underclothes, you unsheath the wand, holding it awkwardly with the toes of one foot.

"You may want to look away, my lady," you say to Ilia.

She seems unperturbed by the sight of you standing there, near naked and shivering, and folds her arms with a stubborn look. "I've delivered babies before, you know. Baby boys. It's nothing I haven't seen before."

"If you say so, my lady," you smile, willing the spell into life.

For the briefest moment, you hang in the air, caught halfway between human and animal, joints twisted into hideous conformations, every inch of skin blistering with erupting feathers, fingers shrunken to nubs, lips swollen into a soft, fleshy beak. It is a brief moment, but enough to make her lose her dinner.

"Told you to look away," you laugh, but all that comes out is "Squaawk!"

You wobble unsteadily on your new legs, adjusting quickly to the form's centre of balance as you were trained. Happy that the wand is clutched securely in your talons, you flap your broad wings and rise (a little awkwardly) into the air. You've never really loved bird forms, disliking their weak, fragile bodies and alien, malicious minds, but the feeling of flight is an undeniable pleasure. Rising higher, you barely even feel the flies, now the size of tennis balls, that batter against your wings and head. Ilia is soon a small speck on the land.

From the air, it's easy to confirm your suspicions; the blight spreads out below you in a perfect circle, which means at its centre should be....

Folding your wings back, you swoop low, braking to hover a few metres above the Mark of Corruption that has been burnt into the soil, a circular inscription standing out black among the yellow-green muck. Carefully you fly lower, finding it harder to maintain stability amongst the warm, moist, sour air being belched up by the ground, but you're soon close enough to make out the language in which the Mark has been inscribed. It is...

"I'd like to stay through the night and see if these shadows creatures reappear. If so, I will do my best to remove them from your land, and will send word to your lord to send aid. If not... well, it may be your granddaughter had it right, perhaps this isn't work for a wizard. Perhaps a farmer would be more appropriate?"

"I assure you, sir, the creatures will come!" Joshua exclaims, wringing his hands.

You have him worried, but you don't much care - to think, bringing you out all this way to the backside of beyond on a simple matter of duplicated grain. Everyone knows there's a reason you don't buy from goblins; you always run the risk of buying duplicated items. Sooner or later the magic sustaining them breaks down, and so does your purchase. That's all this is, a simple matter of faulty goods. These "shadows" are nothing more than a fabrication.

"May you excuse me," you say, rising from the fire. "I intend to rest before the night's sentry."

"Of course. There is accommodation prepared for you. We are a humble people, but I pray you find it comfortable."

You thank him as a man of the village steps forward to take your bags and escort you to one of the rudimentary huts that lies on the edge of the settlement.
-----------
The elder watches the wizard leave, concerned and angry. His granddaughter stares into the fire, untroubled. Trembling, he points an accusatory finger at her. "Y-you impudent child! You should not have angered him! You should not have spoken at all!" he hisses. "Now we will all starve and it's all your fault!"

Her surprise is brief, turning quickly to outrage. "My fault?! All I said was the truth!"

"Truth will not feed us when the snows come, granddaughter. Truth will not keep our young ones warm in the dark, cold months. That man is a god and you choose to insult him!"

"How dare you say that? He is no god. That is blasphemy."

"With one wave of his hand, he could solve all of our problems, and more. With another, he could smite us from the earth. He has more power in his little finger than your Goddess has in her body."

The two glare at each other across the fire. Ilia suspects she would have hit him already, were he not so old. "We will not starve," she states resolutely. "The Mother provides."

Slowly Joshua nods, his gaze flitting down to the silver pendant that hangs around her neck. "Aye... Perhaps she will..."

She follows his gaze, her eyes growing wide as she realizes his intention, her hand clutching the precious pendant tightly. "This is not yours to sell, old man. Mother left it to me."

"You may find explaining that to starving men difficult, my child. If you wish to keep it, you should seek to persuade the wizard to aid us. And if he cannot be persuaded, we will have to make sure he doesn't leave. Our plight will become his plight, once winter sets in."

"Persuade him?" Ilia scoffs. "Enlighten me, how do you persuade a "god"."

Joshua hesitates, aware that he is about to cross a line. Sadly it is a line they may have to cross if they are to survive. "It is simple, my dear..."

"I will need time to consider this matter," you announce with as much gravitas as you can muster. It seems to give the villagers some reassurance as they disperse to do... whatever it is the common folk do with their time. Joshua brings forth a flagon of weak ale, presenting it as a great gift, before removing himself from your sight.

Blight and shadows - they could be symptoms of almost anything. Alone at the fire, you take a stick and begin to doodle out a few hypotheses in the sandy dirt.

Shades of undeath birthed from the bodies of unburied dead? Unlikely, considering the small settlement has a priestess.

Burnt out fire elementals holding on as smoke on the wind. It would not explain the shadows but not the blight.

Demon souls pushing through reality from the other side, manifesting as hazy figures. Possible. But again the presence of a priestess should ward away such incursions, assuming she is performing her rituals right.

Fetchlings? Nah. Fetchlings weren't malicious but they were mercantile. If they saw starving villagers, they'd be selling them food by now.

Cheap seed and jumpy villagers. You underline that one with your stick.

Across the miserable landscape, grey clouds are rolling in. Away from the village a dip in the land shields the fields from the weather. Villagers mill about the edge of the rotten brown expanse as if lost. Some are even splitting open the decayed husks as though expecting to find ripe grain inside.

The whitish gown of the priestess draws the eye. Ilia is marching towards the field, dragging a lanky youth behind her. He seems bemused and brow-beaten, carried along by her harsh tongue more than her strength.

"Stop whining and drink this," she snaps, pushing a bowl of something to the boys lips.

He obeys. Annoyingly, whatever he's offered is clearly much stronger than the swill given to you, as the lad immediately staggers as if drunk. The priestess lifts a handful of dirt, smearing it down his cheeks and forehead. She straightens a chaplet of green grass on her head and begins to incant, though sounding to stammer and fumble some of her lines. Taking the addled boy by the hand, she leads him between the rows of withered crop, discarding her gown as she goes.

The specifics of such things lie beyond your area of expertise, but you recognise a pagan fertility rite when you see one. The old ways still hold sway in these remote lands. You raise a flagon to the lad's good fortune, assuming that the priestess isn't required to kill him upon consummating the ritual. Evidently you didn't raise it high enough - a minute later, Joshua is racing towards the field, bellowing his daughter's name. As he dives in after the pair, a thick black cloud of flies feasting on the decay buzzes into the air.

Flies, you write in the dirt, driving the stick in as the fullstop. Frightened villagers mistaking a swarm of flies for shadow figures. That's all this is. The others will mock when they learn the details of your first mission.

From the fields comes the sound of coitus interuptus of a sort, as Joshua bellows, "Ilia! No! Not the baker's boy! Got off him right now! What will your grandmother think?!" and Ilia begins screeching at him like a banshee.

"I haven't finished yet!"

"Well you're finished now, young lady! Remove yourself from... his person at once!"

"You can't stop me!"

12133.content:
You sigh to yourself as you hang your head low, taking another swig from your flagon, before promptly discovering that it is empty. Discarding it quickly - you simply toss it aside onto the ground - you stand up stretching your limbs, feeling as if though you had just went through a petrifying spell. It seems that the crops are not the only thing that is a disaster in this town, they need better craftsmen as well.

Stroking your chin - your beard still hasn't sprouted yet - you ponder whether you should instantly hop into the saddle of your horse and gallop all the way to the capital. After all, it's just a swarm of flies and a regular blight here. These villagers are simply wasting your time and you do not care whether they die out or not.

But then again, your fellow graduates...

You remember your time at the academy's graduation. Drunk on success - and on fine wine - you boasted about how your first mission will be a grandiose adventure, filled with magic battles, demons, and charming women. You hold your head within your hands. How could you have done such a shameless act?! How can you now return back like this? You'd be laughed out of the city by your peers.

No, a wizard must do his duties, even if it's only for his own sake. Perhaps you would stumble upon something mystical and solve that instead? It certainly would up your reputation quite a bit. You steady yourself as you hear the door opening, with accompanying shrieks. Joshua slowly trots in, dragging Ilia by her arms as she kicks her legs and squirms.

"Let go of me! I will solve our village's problems, not this blasted wizard!"

"Shut your mouth!" Joshua yells angrily at her, turning to get a brief look at you, hoping you aren't offended. "Get back in the kitchen. Now!"

Ilia stomps her foot, visibly irritated, but obeys her father as she moves to her household duties, cursing under her breath while rubbing her arms. It seems that her grandfather's influence still remains, albeit barely. He turns to you, sweating beads.

"W-why don't you stay here for the night? We will have soup ready for you and--"

"No thank you. I'd best be going," you tell as you roll your eyes. He definitely desperate. Probably hiding something.

"Wait, please, stop---"

"Do not get me wrong, old man. I must see what all these nightly creatures are all about."

Joshua visibly relaxes as he slumps his shoulders, relieved that you aren't planning to leave. Unfortunately for him, you aren't planning to help either, as you have already come to the conclusion that the harvest failure is solely the result of the villagers' negligence. Dark shadows? Blight is too fast? What ridiculous nonsense. It's quite obvious that they are trying to con you.

Heading outside - the sun is already setting - you look around as you head to the fields... or rather, the forest behind the fields. If there is anything to find in this backwater region, it would be there. Walking at a slow pace - flying is solely restricted for combat purposes to conserve mana - it takes you around an hour to reach the place. The sun has already set, so visibility is low, but that's nothing to a wizard like you. Lighting a small flame on the tip of your index finger, you enter the dense forest, hoping for adventures, and excitement.

Unfortunately, it seems that you are out of luck. As you walk through the woods, it becomes quite obvious that only small animals, like squirrels and birds, actually live here, and that you will not engage in any battle with a mythical monster tonight.

"Curses!" You scream as you tumble into a river. As it was too dark, you didn't notice the cliff end beneath your feet, and you tumble into the river below. Why are you so unlucky today? Feeling extremely nauseous, you slowly wade out of the river. Luckily, you reach the shore, as your little flame was extinguished by the gushing water. Hmm, you really are feeling light-headed right now. Did you catch a cold...?

Finally on the shore, you decide that it is time to head back to the village, when suddenly something flickers on the edge of the cliff, which is illuminated by moonlight. A shadow! And it is a big one too. It quickly disappears, but you quickly give chase as well. Rounding the corner of the cliff, you are astonished to find...

A twig snaps to your left. You spin around, barking the wands command word. Seeing movement in the brief flash of light, you turn and fire again, blasting the lower part of a tree into splinters. The upper half crashes down. As the noise fades, you can hear only the blood pounding in your ears.

Remember your training. Control your breathing. Think rationa-AAH A GHOST!

Atop the cliff rises a shadowy figure, raising its arms and uttering a bloodcurdling "wooOOOoooOOO."

You fire wildly, taking chunks out of the cliff but catching the monster in the torso. It collapses with an all-too-human cry.

Your heart sinks as you climb the cliff. Joshua is laid out in the dirt. The brown hessian blanket around him has been shredded, along with most of his chest. The blood is pouring out between his fingers. "It's all my fault," he sobs. "I was the one who dealt with the goblin. I knew better but we had so little money. Now the village starves because of me." With every word, more blood trickles down his lips. "I thought if I could get you here, make you think there was a monster, that you would be able to help," he says bitterly. "Ilia was right about your sort."

"Ilia, of course. A priestess can heal you!" you cry with hope. But as you turn to scramble back down the cliff, Joshua snatches at your clothing. The blood soaks through to your skin.

"No, please stay. I don't have long left, and I... I don't want to die alone."

"But I can be fast," you say desperately. He shakes his head. "Why would you want me to stay? I just shot you."

"Beggars can't be choosers, I suppose... Now there's a life summed up," he chuckles grimly. His weak fingers slip away and he sinks back, staring up at the moon, no longer even caring to stem the bleeding.

Years of training never prepared you for this. You pat his shoulder, searching for something comforting to say. "The, um, journey doesn't end here, I guess. Death is just another path... or something. One that we all must-"

Joshua closes his eyes. "If I pretend to be dead, will you let me die in peace."

"Sorry."

For a while you just sit there in silence, his breathing getting weaker and weaker until it has almost gone. Then suddenly you say.

"Joshua."

"..."

"Are you dead?"

"...not yet..."

"Perhaps there is something we can do. You know.... to save the village."

"...talk faster, boy..."

"Okay, like you said, if I can show that there was a monster here, your lord will be expected to send aid as recompense. I can use my magic to change you, make you into a hideous beast, just before you die! Something really dangerous! Then I can skin you and take your hide back as proof!"

"...I don't want to die a monster..."

Joshua gives something between a groan of disgust and a death rattle. "Aye... alright, do it."

A glimmer of arcane energy flows down your arm. Placing your hand on his chest, you will it into him. He shudders. The mangled flesh beneath your palm starts to soften and bubble like warm candle wax.

"Now focus, Joshua. Think of the most terrible creature you can think of and fix it in your mind. Now start to move towards it. Feel yourself flowing into it, becoming it..."

It works! The frail malrnourished human form of the village elder becomes less distinct with each passing moment, ripening with thick musculature and sprouting terrible claws and tusks. You can practically see his bestial skull hanging over your fireplace already!

Then a single tear rolls down his cheek and his monstrous lip quivers. "Ilia, my sweet daughter... Let my last thoughts be of you..."

"No! Focus! Don't think about her! Think monster thoughts!"

It is too late. The changes shift, the form becoming smaller, slimmer, more curvaceous, an arcane amalgamation of his daughter and the original template, that of...

"- as an escort, yes." Your dick perks up again - so you were going to fuck him after all. "To escort you through your dangerous travels." You wince, your confused dick feeling bruised and abused. "I've never fought before. Truth be told I don't even know if I could bring myself to hurt another man but it seems to me that one look at this ferocious body would discourage most attackers."

He looks to you hopefully, the light of the moon reflecting in his big, teary eyes and you groan. "Fine," you say sullenly. "I'll take you under my protection to the capital. After that, we shall see." Most likely your superiors will simply demand he be put down before he has to chance to pop out a brood of weird demon-elf babies. "Take your clothes off."

"Can I still wear this?" he asks, gesturing to the simple hessian-sack he had used to create the 'shadow figure'.

Begrudgingly, you nod. His clothes you tear into long strips and use to bind his wrists. Your frustrated dick had almost given up hope, but twitches into life as you craft a crude leash out of the longest piece and a collar to tie about his slender neck. "Now remember, you're my prisoner so you do as I say. When we get to the village, don't speak. Don't even look at the others, even if they're friends and family. Especially if they're friends and family."

He sniffs and nods. "Can you tell my daughter one thing? Tell her that with my last breath, I forbade her from marrying the baker's boy."

"Uh. Sure."

"And I wanted a proper funeral. Tell her that. None of this pagan nonsense so likes so much."

The man on watch approaches you, drawing a rusty iron blade and uttering a prayer at the sight of Joshua. "Cor blimey, look at the claws on that thing! It's a venomous elf like from the tales!"

With your most dramatic voice, you say, "Do not be afeared citizen, for I have captured the monster that has afflicted this land. Alas, in the skirmish to subdue her, your elder, Joshua, was slain. She shall be taken to the capital immediately, where the king's justice awaits."
