121332312.content:
You lightly elbow Joshua in the back and then, remembering your audience, add a “Take that!” for good measure.

Thankfully, he gets the message and straightens up to his unimpressive full height, adopting an impassive expression on his face. You coached him for a brief second on the ‘bestial-but-proud’ angle: hicks love that sort of thing — maybe enough to not lynch the both of you. Or, well, him.

Frustratingly, his lip still quivers lightly. You elbow him again with a greater modicum of force, but all that seems to do is bring tears to his eyes. You barely refrain from cursing: shapeshifting was a delicate process that takes years of practice to manage anything beyond a senseless lump of flesh, and you had put a good swell of magic in the hands of an amateur. It was your mistake, really. His thoughts should have been of the dead and purely hypothetical blight-fiend that this podunk town concocted, but instead, he thought of his prissy daughter. Now, his years of wisdom were likely being tempered by the capricious whims of teenage girlhood, perhaps accompanied by the petulance of Illia, if the gods truly hated you.

And this cock-and-bull nonsense about venomous elves, you append. And now you have to ensure that he doesn’t get killed for a week or two. Joy.

You yank the leash gently to wipe the miserable expression off his face, but it just seems to intensify. His hands flex, and his large sharp claws inch out from his sheaths.

“Heel, foul beast!” you cry, planting a foot into the small of his back, pushing him forward into a patch of soft mud. The dirt-encrusted glare that he shoots back at you is enough to make his watery blue eyes somewhat intimidating, at least judging by the murmur of the crowd.

But the illusion is shattered as Joshua props himself up on his taloned hands, the sexless burlap sack losing its former quality as it clings to his sizable prow. You surreptitiously cast your gaze across the mob, whose murmurs have taken on a distinctly lascivious quality, judging by the male elbows jostling male sides, and the disapproving gazes of peasant women towards either the pitiful elf or their leering husbands. You bite back a sigh as his sharp mitts slip on the mud, squashing his chest forward with a gasp that doesn’t sound anything close to monstrous.

The men of the crowd seem to be embroiled in a serious discussion on whether taking the blight-fiend that killed their elder as a concubine would be an appropriate honor to his memory or not. You’re mulling over the best spell to disperse the crowd with minimal casualties. You’re not going to give up your only sign of a completed job to some superstitious yokels, after all.

“YOU FOOLS!” sweeps across the crowd, dispelling any talk of elf trafficking, and even the small sigils you were tracing behind your back. Every head turns to the cacophonous source; Illia, who is standing upon a stump, arm outstretched towards the murmuring crowd. She’s garbed in a hemp robe that’s been crudely striped with berry juice and tree sap to resemble the uniform of the Goddess’ priesthood, along with lumpy woven chapeau perched loosely atop her head.

“Do you not see what this creature is doing?!” she cries, stepping forward in front of the mob, gesturing to her transmogrified father. “This monster has woven a spell of lust over you, to cloud your vision and tempt you to sin!”

She grabs a stick off the ground and jabs Joshua in the tit, sending him back with a yelp, arms draped protectively over his chest.

“This beast, and its curse, can only be truly exorcised by the Goddess’ chosen!” she declares, waving the wood around like an aspergillum. “Not by those with… impure motives.” She glares at the male population of the mob, who shamefully avoid her eyes.

“That’s right!” you add, stepping forward and stretching an arm in front of the ersatz holy woman — much to her apparent disgust. “She shall be taken to the city’s highest church, and, uh, strung up and all that.”

The tension in your shoulders relaxes as ripples of uncertainty thrum through the crowd. Priggish priestesses could work wonders among the uneducated; better note that down for future ventures in the countryside.

“Worry not, for I too, shall accompany him!”

wait no.

You whirl towards Ilia as the crowd murmurs uncertainly. She flashes a smug smile in your direction before once again addressing the crowd. “We shall leave come sundown!” A non-existent tear is wiped from her eye. “I shall return one day, my people, I swear this!”

And without much fanfare nor heed for the now-sniffling crowd, she turns on her heel and makes off towards her hut. You quickly follow suit, jerking your captive after you.

Catching up with the petite Ilia is no trouble at all, but your similarly-statured prisoner stumbles and trips over the uneven terrain. You can’t help but stare at the variety of shakes and wobbles that stem from his attempts to get up.

“You dragged my daughter into this.” he snarls. “The sole reason I let you do this—” A gnarled hand traces his nubile form. “— to me, and you recruit her.”

It’s not his petulant snarl-cum-pout that gives you pause, nor the ears flattened against his head, but the rather large claws slowly emerging from their blackened sheaths.

Still, you can’t help yourself.

“Your daughter dragged herself into this!” you hiss. “First, she saves your prodigious ass from that sorry display, then she casts herself as the lead role of this mummer’s farce! My time was spent making sure a little milksop of an elf didn’t start weeping!”

Your dagger-staring competition is interrupted a shriek from the subject of your argument; “Are you consorting with the beast, warlock?!”

A quick “No,” is grumbled, and you set off towards the now-one-person hut, pulling Joshua a bit more than you have to.

1213323121.content:
The hut is an interesting sight: half the hut is adorned with the symbols of the Goddess, the curved silver lines adorning every pot, plate, and the thin blanket placed over a pile of straw. The rest of the hut is notably bare; not even a spare plate rests upon the ramshackle table. The sight appears to be unusual to even its former occupant, whose mouth hangs lightly open with ramrod straight ears.

Illia busies herself with a rucksack, shoving bits of wizened fruit and an assortment of hierogram-emblazoned clothing into the ragged thing. She shoots you a smug glance in between objects. “I would think that ‘our’ savior’ would be above the charms of such a wretched creature.”

“I was just… teaching her what’s what,” you murmur distractedly as you look around the hovel. “You’ve certainly moved on quickly.”

Illia stops her packing to shoot a glare over her shoulder. “I certainly miss my father, you heartless oaf.” A robe is stuffed in with a particular amount of venom. “But I know he’s in a better place at the very least — I made many a prayer to that effect.”

Tears sparkle at the edge of Joshua’s eyes. Quickly, as Illia’s back is turned to you both, you flick a pointed ear. He manages to stifle the instinctual yelp and pivots his head towards you, stormy visage on full display, but, fortunately, reads the clear message on your face. He slowly turns to face forward once again, gnawing a lip to keep his expression still.

The rustle of clothes and light setting of the moldy timbers are the only sounds that ripple through the hut. You make busy with one of the plates, examining it primarily to avoid conversation with the zealous girl. Joshua tries to keep his movements to a minimum — every sharp movement draws the pernicious eye of his daughter, evoking a choked gasp from the elf-cum-elder every time, to Illia’s quiet satisfaction — and eventually settles on picking the mud from his burlap garb. Your feigned inspection takes less and less of a priority as Joshua continues his preening; and you’re eventually more or less just staring at the transmogrified elder, paying especial attention to every unintentional hike of fabric, and the flash of creamy skin that it reveals.

“Ogling an animal, I see. How typical of a wizard.”

Joshua stops his ministrations at once and stares at you with open disgust, covering himself in a display of feminine modesty that you’re fairly certain he didn’t possess two hours ago. You cast a quick gaze at his bust that, due to its size, is merely squashed against his chest rather than hidden by his monstrous mitts, then turn your gaze to the upstart.

She’s practically doubled over in silent laughter, mouth curved into a mocking grin that you fervently want to wipe off her face.

“Is there something wrong with monitoring a dangerous monster, girl?!” you intone, sweeping an arm out for dramatic effect. It doesn’t seem to take.

“You know as well as I that the monster wouldn’t dare to attack in a place like this,” She makes her own grand gesture at the clumsily painted holy symbols on most of the walls. “I’ve held more rituals than I can count in here; it’s practically sainted ground!”

She strokes a wall fondly, not noticing the vague look of outrage building on Joshua’s face. Just as quickly, she produces a bundle of cloth and hurls it at the offended elder, who squawks in alarm.

“Go get the beast-thing dressed — maybe when it’s in human clothes, your perverse lust shall dissipate.”

You stride out of the house, elder in tow, not dignifying her outrageous remark with the witty response that you were thiis close to formulating. Joshua leaves the house with little complaint, but halfway on your trip to a nearby secluded glade, he grabs the hemp rope out of your hands.

“I can’t believe you,” he gasps, in a tone that is eerily reminiscent to Illia’s. “I’m a man! You’re a man!” Despair flits across his pretty face for the nth time that day. “Oh Goddess, she was right about you people…”

“I was checking for irregularities in your form, man!” you whisper-shout, looking over your shoulder for any wannabe observers. “That spell that hit you was about, er, circle nine! You don’t want to end up a pile of bones and sinew now, do you?!”

You know it’s a lame excuse the second it leaves your lips and judging by Joshua’s squint, he does too. Thankfully, the fact that you are the only wizard in this discussion gives you enough plausible deniability to stave off any explicit doubts. Still scowling, Joshua snatches the bundle of clothing and starts off towards a particularly dense clump of trees.

“Wait!” you cry, extending a hand towards him. “Don’t you think you need help with that…?”

“I’ll be fine.” he pronounces icily. “Stand guard.”

Defeated, you lean against a tree and scan the horizon. Eugh, no one would come here unless they particularly liked the smell of dung. With a sigh, you summon up some Light essence and exert your will onto a nearby thrush, sending it to alight on a nearby bough and transferring your sight to it shortly thereafter.

You watch Joshua shrug off his sack and struggle to squeeze his round bits into the ill-fit garb.

'Trousers and jerkins, with only a thin shirt underneath, probably his old stuff,' you note wryly.

Still, a heavy sense of resignation weighs down your heart. The faux-priestess had set back your ‘immortal-elven-slut’ plan by a couple of decades, at the very least.

121332313.content:
"Kill it!"

"Burn it!"

"String it from a tree!"

Ilia, tears streaming down her face, hurls a rock at Joshua who cowers away behind you. "Murderer! The Goddess demands justice! I demand justice!"

"And you shall have it!" you shout back, though your voice hardly seems to carry over the horde of villagers that surround you. Only your rapidly diminishing wizardly authority is stopping them from tearing you and Joshua apart. At a time like this, how you wish you had a Staff of Booming to silence the crowds like the senior professors did for their students.

"He is protecting the beast!" Ilia screams. "Look how she hides behind him - they have forged an unholy pact!"

A gasp of outrage ripples through the crowd as the look from the half-clad bestial beauty to you.

You're losing them, you think in panic. Don't even justify that with a response. "Food!" you blurt desperately. The starving villagers hush for a moment. You seize your moment. "Your lord has been remiss in the protection of your lands. This creature-", with that you give a yank of the leash, sending Joshua face first into the mud, "-must be brought before him, so that he might be shown his failure and reminded of his obligations to you, his subjects. Then and only then will he send food and supplies to see you through the coming winter. Without it, you will all starve and Joshua will have died in vain." The crowd retract slightly. Ilia however is picking up another rock, on the verge of launching into a crowd-inflaming tirade. You race to cut her off. "Then I shall take the monster to the capital for her punishment to be meted out. And let me tell you that the tortures of the city folk are terrible most indeed. So terrible even that I hesitate to speak them to your innocent ears." Ilia's throwing hand hesitates but doesn't fall. "Nails! Burning nails in both eyes! And her skin shall be flayed with thorny whips and her eyelids peeled with a... sort of peely thing. And a rusty poker shall be inserted into her... her... y'know... anus."

A number of women in the crowd gasp, covering the ears of children they had previously thought were merely attending a family-friendly lynching and hurrying them away.

"Then she shall be given over to three Orcs of large girth, one for each hole. And finally... I will... um... wee on her?"

The crowd has heard enough, dissipating in disgust. Only Ilia remains. She meets you with a steely stare, still weighing up her rock. "Go then. But if I ever find out that you lied to us, that you kept my father's murderer as a filthy familiar or something, I will pray for you to die."

An uncontrollable snort of laughter bursts from your nose. "Truly terrifying. I pray it never comes to that. Now, my prisoner has a long journey ahead of her. Fetch her some clothes."

Her nostrils flare in rage. With an impotent stomp of her foot, she turns and marches away.

Joshua sniffles behind you and you can feel him trembling even on the end of the leash. You make a show of dragging him through the village to where they stabled your horse. His friends and family kick mud and spit as he passes, and by the time he reaches the barn he is sobbing and filthy. The horse likes the sight and smell of him even less, and it takes minutes to quell the animal enough to allow Joshua onto its back. You climb up behind him. "At least you died a hero," you console him.

Ilia throws the bundle of clothing at the horse hard enough to almost unseat you as you gallop out of the village. Once safely away from the pitchfork-wielding, you dismount to allow the shivering Joshua to dress himself. He looks back at the distant dim light of his home as he pulls on the woolen garments.

"I fear I will never see it again."

"Well I certainly hope I never see her again," you mutter.

You ride a little more and camp for the night. The following day the rains roll in. The next six days are huddled in the saddle against the unrelenting rain, swaddled in drenched clothing, the countryside a featureless grey blob. You see not a single traveler upon the roads. At night you camp in the shelter of trees or rocks, huddled together for warmth.

Only on the second night do you consider getting a little more than warmth. As you slide closer to the sleeping elf, nestling your body nicely between his thighs, his claws slide out from their sheaths, though he remains snoring throughout. You begrudgingly remove your throbbing erection from his vicinity, and grumble yourself to sleep.

It's stretching the truth but the look of admiration on his pretty face is too much for you to pass up. For such a lowborn man as he, the thought of such authority must seem magic all itself.

"Wh-what else can you do with that?" he whispers.

You smile. It is only early evening but you're both weary and saddle-sore. "Where would you like to sleep tonight."

"In a soft bed with a warm meal."

Joshua stares at the town, ten times the size as his village and thirty times as populated. He points to an inn that stands three stories tall, carved out of a single huge tree trunk. Golden firelight spills out of the glass paned windows.

"A delfemon is an extinct species of elves that used to think very much like humans. It is speculated that the brains and thought processes are very similar to that of humans. It mainly consumed meat, but it is classified as an 'omnivore', one who eats both meat and vegetation. It went extinct over 10000 years ago. Only one skull of this species had ever been found. Before that, they were considered to be myth, and rightly so. It is said that only 100 or so of these creatures had ever existed. Such low numbers are speculated to be a result of their body producing very low sex hormones. Just one is able to take on an army of tens of thousands..."

You gasp. What the heck?! There's no way this can be possible. It shouldn't be possible! According to the First Law of Conservation of Mana, a being can only turn another being into one with equal strength or lower. You couldn't possibly be this powerful... right? Then... Joshua? You shake your head. It was all nonsense. Your companion simply pulled an image out of his head without thinking about anything. There's no way he could be a delfemon. No way. You won't believe it.

1223.content:
The journey to Kvoss takes three days from Nalond, and the slow, steady boatride up the North-Western Aqueduct makes a pleasant respite from the dangers and duties of wizarding. It is made particularly enjoyable by the boatman, a half-troll who speaks barely a word of the common tongue as the long miles slipped past. No remarks of 'so you're a wizard then?' or 'so what's your business in X?' to spoil the peace.

Only once does he register your presence, fixing you with a hard glance the moment you dip a hand into the crystal-clear waters. "They chop hand off," he barks, his gnarled fist tightening around the thick wood of the oar. Kvossians are very protective of their water, as well they should be. It is the lifeblood of their city, and of the arid countryside that it supplies for a hundred miles around.

So precious are they that all eating and ablutions are performed away from the aqueduct, at one of the sluices-cum-guard-towers dotted every few miles. Terraces of vibrant, green plantations line the hills around each sluice - fruit, tobacco, tea, and grapes - a stark contrast to the hot, arid landscape beyond. At each of these stops, wrapped and bound bundles or the occasional keg are loaded aboard the small boat until it sits quite low in the water and the half-troll begins to sweat to make headway against the slight current.

At last Kvoss comes into sight just as evening is drawing in. Much like the plantations, Kvoss is built against the slope of a mountain in a series of terraces, but instead of crops there are buildings, each made of the local white sandstone. As the boat draws nearer over one of the 9 viaducts that emerge from the mountain, you begin to see the bath-houses, the summit palace, and the spacious villas with their rooftop gardens, all jutting out like the staircase of a giant.

The air here is humid and fragrant. There is a noticeable heat emanating up through the bottom of the boat too and the water begins to steam as you grow closer, freshly hot from the heart of the mountain. The aqueduct nears a level about halfway up the mountain and the half-troll’s boat comes to a berth in a boathouse. Porters dressed in little more than ornate loincloths hurry forward to unload the cargo, and a flurry of coin and tiny scrips of paper exchange hands. You clamber off the boat and once the hubbub has died down, you palm one of the porters a few copper in exchange for the direction of The Inn of the Prancing Ponce.

“Ahh, you want the fourth or third level, right next to the central cistern. Down two levels,” the man says cheerfully. “Say, you wouldn’t be a wizard, would ya? What’s your business in Kvoss then? Here to solve those murders, eh?”

You quickly depart.

Lanterns are being lit and despite the ill rumours that have been coming from Kvoss for months, there remains a atmosphere of joviality as you descend the broad, paved streets to the fourth level. Men, women and children emerge from their homes to walk the streets to eat, drink, and socialise. It seems peculiar coming from Lightgarde, where most law-abiding citizens would be inside by the drawing of night, but here the men openly adorn themselves with gemstones and bulging coin-purses, while the women wear fine silks. Each person seems to have their own, exotic perfume, until your senses are dizzy. The displays of wealth diminish as you descend one layer and then the next, though they never go away.

The Inn of the Prancing Ponce extends over two levels and occupies six floors. It’s many balconies ring with laughter and music, and the sounds of perhaps a bawdier entertainment coming from the lower floors.

I stand out like a sore thumb, you think as you step inside and forge towards the bar between revelers in their loose, colourful clothes, while you yourself are dressed in a dusty, heavy, woolen travelling cloak. Halfway in, your foot lands in water. There is a small channel of running water in the floor that winds between the tables, seemingly carrying empty cups and bottles back to the bar.

The barman is distracted, staring off at something with his brow furrowed, so you order wine from the barmaid in the vain hope that holding a cup of alcohol might help you blend in. Then you turn to the room and begin to look for your contact within the throng. Somebody who looks out of place. It isn’t long before you spot...

“By the lords, now she’s smoking,” the barkeep mutters to himself, his gaze still fixed in a concerned expression upon a table over in the corner, which draws your eye. Dense curls of smoke almost conceal a figure there. They are dressed in a dark green cloak much like your own with the hood pulled up over the face and a long smoking pipe emerging from the shadows around the mouth. A ugly-looking mastiff gnaws at a bone at their feet.

There’s my man, you think, shouldering your way through the crowd. They had arrived several days before you to investigate the rumours of murder and disappearances in the area, and your orders are to meet and assist. The smoke is acrid and thick - the sort of cheap, strong stuff that only a person with the immortal constitution of a wizard would dare inhale - and it has done an excellent job of clearing an area of empty space around the corner table. A thick cloud of it pours languidly out of the hood as the figure pushes it away from their face.

“P-praepostor Scraif,” you stammer, as the smoke disperses from around the man’s face. All of a sudden, it is like being back in school.

Stefan Scraif’s eyes widen in surprise. “Praepostor… I haven’t been called that in thirty years... I remember you… no, don’t tell me, it’s on the tip of my tongue.”

“I was three years below you. You were my tutor in second year. It was your job to, uh, whip me if I broke house-rules.“

“No hard feelings I hope, old chap” he says, though there is the slight curl to the corner of his mouth that might be a smirk. His mismatched green and yellow eyes dart up and down you, and he snaps his fingers in recollection. “Mead! James Mead. Of course, I never forget a, uh, face.”

“Close enough, sir.” You extend a hand to shake but remembering the formal greeting between wizards, you swing the handshake up into a clumsy salute. “Journeyman Sorcerer Mead, Crimson 4th circle, Golden 3rd circle, Jade 4th circle, Grey 3rd circle, Light 2nd circle, reporting for assignment, sir.”

You wait patiently for him to respond in kind with his own ranks but he merely takes a long pull on his pipe. “If you’ve finished announcing your presence to the entire tavern, why don’t you take a seat.”

“Shit, sorry, sir. I didn’t realise we were undercover.” You quickly park yourself on the seat. You notice he too is perfumed, like the locals - a strongly masculine cologne of leather and sandalwood underneath the overpowering pipesmoke. “Sorry for saying shit just then. I’m just- it’s great to finally be working with another sorcerer, I always looked up to you in college. You were an inspiration.“

“Is that wine?”

“I-t’s a prop. I was trying to blend in. I-I would never drink on duty. Absolutely not.” You instinctively flinch, recalling the sting of the birch after all these years.

Stefan tilts his cup towards yours. “The barkeep won’t serve me. I haven’t had a drink in three days. Nothing stronger than fruit juice at least.” He taps the rim of his cup against yours impatiently.

“Is… is this a test? There was that time in second year you caught me sneaking out after hours to the tavern...”

He scowls. “Yes, I birched your arse red for it, and I’ll do it again if you don’t top me up.”

Half of the wine goes into his cup and shortly after goes down his throat. He wipes his mouth with the back of his hand, and begins to immediately eye the remaining half in your cup. You set it down and push it across the table, and he gulps it down like a man dying of thirst in a desert. He gives a satisfied gurgle in the back of his throat. “Fighting monsters is thirsty work, eh?” he says with a wink. With two fingers in his mouth, he gives a shrill whistle and gestures the barmaid across.

“We’d like to order now,” he barks.

“Of course,” the barmaid smiles sweetly, before turning to you. “What would you like.”

“Bread, soup, wine.”

The barmaid nods, and turns her gaze to Stefan. “And what would your daughter like to eat?”

Age works different for wizards than it does to mortals. As immortals, they do it at their own leisure, some taking centuries to mature to middle-age, others growing straight into silver-haired old men with flowing beards in their teenage years.

Somewhere in his mid-teens, Stefan’s aging had halted, and stayed there for the past thirty years, not aging a day from the last time you saw him.

A tall, thin man barges past as you push through the crowd to Stefan's corner table, a pretty girl tucked within the crook of his arm beneath the folds of a black cloak. "There there, my sweet, hold tight to me, I'll keep you safe. Just a little darkness, is all. Let's get you somewhere warm, hmm?"

The table was empty. No sign of Stefan Scraif save for the dissipating swirls of his pipesmoke and a half full cup. Where the blazes had that blasted versi gotten to?

...wait...

With distinctly more urgency and physical force, you forge through the patrons to the tavern door. Upon the street, the bulky shape of two figures beneath the dark cloak moved clumsily but hastily towards an alley between two buildings.

You dart after them. The gaunt gentleman looks back with alarm at the sound of your footsteps. He bristles, spitting some slur in the local tongue as you seize Stefan by the forearm and pull him free from the man's embrace. Stefan falls into you, barely conscious, blind drunk.

The man surveys you with a beady, glittering eye. "I was simply making sure the little lady got home safe."

"She'll be plenty safe with me," you retort sharply, showing him the first two inches of steel from your scabbard to demonstrate. Evidently he does not feel the need to see the rest of the sword; vanishing swiftly into the dark. It is a relief - with your left arm struggling to hold Stefan's dead weight, you did not fancy your chances in a duel had he decided to push his claim.

You slam the sword back in its scabbard. Two versi! Why is it always me that gets these assignments?

"Can you not support yourself?" you ask. Stefan merely moans into your chest. His hands clutch your cloak tightly but his legs only buckle with each step, dragging across the cobbles. You tighten your grip to take more of his weight. The immediate temptation is to lift him completely into your arms to carry him as one might a damsel in distress, but to do so to a man and a peer would be a humiliation. A wizard is far too proud and powerful a being to be lugged about like a bride on her wedding night.

How had he allowed himself to become so inebriated in the short time that you were up in the room? Versi men are slight in stature, sure, but by all accounts they're the match of their mundane counterparts when it came to physical constitution and capacity to handle their drink. Furthermore, it is a professional disgrace for a wizard to willingly get themselves into such a state. Sure, wizards drink. Many drink heavily in fact. But alone. A wizard losing possession of their faculties in a crowd could bring about the death of dozens with a single gesture.

"Pray I don't file this in my report," you mutter down to him.

His head lolls back and rolls in circles, his eyes fluttering open and closed independently of one another. There is sweet citrus upon his breath that takes you back to distant days in potion class. Gripping his chin, you hold his head steady. As his pink lips part, the scent beneath the wine and cheap pipe-weed is unmistakable - maiden's end. He's been drugged.

"Well one of you was certainly in for a surprise this evening," you say darkly, gripping him tighter so as to drag him with renewed haste to his room. Your fingers struggle to find modest purchase, briefly tightening about the soft flesh of his right breast before shifting upwards to underneath his armpit. Not that he would mind necessarily, had he been conscious - versi males are said to regard their breasts more as fleshy battle armour for their heart and lungs rather than anything sexual, with especially endowed men viewed as being more impressive warriors. Yet it certainly makes you uncomfortable.

At a barked command, the halfling girl scurries ahead of you to unlock the door. Scraif's rented room is spartan by wizard standards, cheap. A thin slit of a window for light, and a hay-stuffed mattress and a basin of water for furniture. You lay him down on the bed. His fingers still clutch tightly to your clothing even in his stupor.
1223121313.title: Stefan is stone-drunk.

choices: to Stefan angrily shouting at a halfling girl for her offer of abortifacient tea
to Scraif standing over you, spells primed, demanding to know what happened.
to Stefan still under the effects of the drug, at least somewhat.
to a rapping on the door that somehow comes across as impudent.
12231213133.content:
You sigh and pry your former prefect’s hand from your cloak, finger by finger. He lets out a high cantankerous moan at the disruption, but you pay him no mind, choosing instead to gather the thaumic energies of Gold and Light.

Maiden’s end was an alchemic ingredient — a distinctive pink root, to be exact — that teetered on the cusp of illegality. Sales of it were accompanied by a mutual winks and tacit agreement to not discuss the transaction. It affected the mind primarily, dulling the tendency towards independent thought to the point of blissful obedience. It was mostly accepted and permitted in prisons, where ruthless criminals would have their food and drink so saturated with the stuff that they would walk to the chopping block and bare their necks with dumb smiles.

But its namesake and more-widely known usage was in bars and brothels, of course. Any whore or guileless wench that didn’t recognize the telltale fruity scent might find themselves leaving the establishment over a brigand’s shoulder, tittering at the futures of depravity being whispered into their ear.

All in all, a massive inconvenience for you. Stefan could be deprived of his higher faculties until noon or two days after that, depending on the dosage. And though you would like to put some faith in Scraif’s abilities to detect common types of poison - something everyone learned well by second year at the academy; it’s all too likely that puffing cheap pipeweed had dulled his sense of smell and taste to the point of insignificance.

He was lucky that he was drunk, you suppose; a morally uninhibited and practiced mage at someone’s beck and call was a fearsome thing. Better they mistake him for a maiden than realize his potential.

“You’re lucky you’re pretty.” you mutter quietly, smirking gently. You reflexively flinch at the twisting from the mattress: comparing Praepostor Scraif to a ‘topside wench’ would get you a caning if you were lucky; a session as spell practice if you weren’t.

It’s no matter, you suppose. Even if he heard it, he’ll forget it soon enough. You carefully slide the dark woolen cloak off his shoulders and start fiddling with the buttons of his jerkin. It’s embossed with intricate designs of winding chains and savage river-creatures, as is the Kvossian custom, but one primarily reserved for nobility, not stall-sold to a traveler.

‘It’s secondhand,’ you realize belatedly. Light scuffs and scratches stand out against the dark patterns. Either he had cozied up with a noble family, or more likely, he had spent the majority of his allotted funds to purchase something befitting a man that fit his slight frame. A shame he didn’t read up on local traditions before he came; this kind of jerkin is worn by boys on the cusp of manhood and shrugged off just as their shoulders start to broaden. Secret sniggering and masked pointing must’ve followed him as he frog-marched recruits down the streets; all directed at the girl who wanted to be a man.

You shake off the small pang of sympathy stirring in your chest, grit your teeth and eventually manage to dislodge the buttons from their too-tight niches. Every second you wasted now was a minute of work. The cloth shirt is considerably easier to remove, with a sharp “Up.” sending Stefan’s arms above his head with a drunken whoop.

The fact that he was lucid enough to follow monosyllabic commands should worry you, but you continue about your task relatively undistracted. It’s quite hard to be fully focused with the upper half of a nubile young woman smiling beatifically at you, eyes half-lidded, alabaster breasts heaving with every syrupy breath.

Channeling Light energy, you press your left hand to the side of his skull. His body stiffens ram-rod straight and his breath hitches.

“Dream well,” you intone, and his body relaxes once again, stupid smile curving his lips again. It’s not so much for him as it is for you; drawing toxins out of a body tended to be incredibly painful, but a steady channel of Light could overpower all earthly sensations, the more entrancing, the better.

Now for the tricky part. You place your hand palm-down on the soft skin of his stomach, just bordering his ribs and focus Gold into it, willing all traces of maiden’s end to concentrate in his gut. Momentarily, he lets out a whimper and nuzzles his head into your hand, nearly disrupting your focus.

It’s mind-numbing, dangerous work; a lapse in concentration could collect one of his vital humours, and coalescion spells vary drastically from subject to subject. The only sign of progress are Stefan’s soft coos and pitched moans from the literal gut-wrenching pain being morphed into light pleasure. You’re glad that Stefan, seemingly doesn’t share the libido of his (and yours, unfortunately) ward; a spell of this sort didn’t bode well with a squirming patient.

Your hand is slick with sweat against his soft skin by the time you’ve collected enough to be satisfied. Your Gold spell has concentrated a small pitted ball of the drug in his stomach, no bigger than an eyeball and levitating precipitously above a lake of bile. If there was any left, he’d have to sleep it off.

You risk a glance at the window. Light has began to dance across the horizon, splitting the sky with orange. It’s a source of consternation and slight relief: the former because you’ve spent the balance of the night fondling your former prefect, and the latter because the small lantern you had was woefully insufficent

This part was much easier in comparison, but still demanded a degree of prudence. Slowly, you draw a finger up his abdomen, appreciating the comparatively cool flesh. As you pass through the valley of his cleavage, a shiver wracks his slight form and a choked gasp escapes his lips. Calamitously, he starts to shift, scything a leg across the other and throwing an arm across his midriff, nearly dislodging your hand.

“Stop it!” you hiss.

He stops his squirming abruptly with a small gurgle, breasts slightly swaying on his chest. You let out a held breath and continue the journey upwards, past his collarbone and into his lily-white neck.

Scraif gags lightly, his eyes fluttering open. Gold and blue meet your stormy grey as you draw the pink marble up his throat, his body convulsing in reverse-peristalsis. It’s with a grin that you reach into his mouth, dance your fingers around his uvula and grab the rosé marble, releasing

It splits the weak daylight like a prism, scattering small motes of light against the walls and ceiling. You grin ruefully at the thing: this distant cousin of a penny-sweet was probably stronger than the dreck they passed around in the Alchemists’ guild.

You stow it in a pouch on your person and risk a look at your impromptu patient. Worryingly, his eyes are still following you, vacant smile still playing at his lips.

You purse your own in frustration: you hadn’t gotten all of it. But the deep wave of exhaustion sweeping over you dulls whatever inclination you have for reflection on your work. You had never been good with channeled Light spells, and keeping it up for four hours had taken a toll on you.

You stagger over to the nearest corner, lean against it, take another look at the topless Versi a few feet away from you, and close your eyes. Stefan’s breaths are the last things you hear before falling into a deep slumber.

You awake…
12231213133.title: Draw the poison out

122312131332.content:
An itinerant adventurer, rough sleep is no stranger to you. The tavern room may be unheated, but the warm lining of your cloak has shielded you from snow and wind before. The wattle and daub under your back is lumpy, but a feather bed compared to the nights you spent on the obsidian wastes of Mount Rothediac.

So you sleep quite soundly, until a dry, rasping cough jolts stirs you. You open your eyes to see that your magic has, well, done it's magic. Stefan is sat up on the mattress. One palm pressed his temple, his other hand about his throat, from which comes a hoarse croak. His hangover must be legendary, his throat parched, but having a stone the size of an eyeball drawn the wrong way up his gullet is something else.

With his eyes still squeezed shut against the shaft of sunlight through the slit window, he rolls over on to his front, groping blindly for the handbasin of water sitting beside the mattress. His nubile chest shifts quite fascinatingly as he stretches himself out in search of a drink.

As he does so, his hand grazes against the crumpled pile of his discarded jerkin and cloak. His hand flit down to his bare chest, and he gives a deep, shuddering intake of breath. Slowly, as if dreading what they might see, his bleary eyes open and fixate upon you, his entire beautiful body freezing in shock.

"I wouldn't talk if I were you," you state sternly. "It'll only hurt."

He draws the jerkin to his chest as if to hide his breasts. A strange display, from a man, of what could almost be feminine modesty, although it is certain that he's been socialised in our ways in his time outside his country. Yet the rest of his posture, as he rises from the matress, is anything but feminine. The fist holding the jerkin is clenched tight, trembling with what you might think was rage if the room wasn't so cold. His eyes flash dangerously and his jaw is set. If you didn't know any better, you could swear he was about to punch your lights out.

"No doubt you're feeling sore. I tried to make it pleasurable for you, of course," you say, unable to hide the smugness of a job well done. "But it was very large, and you certainly didn't make it easy, fighting me the whole time..."

All at once, it is as though the air has been drawn from the room. The winds of magic, the currents of thaumic energy that flow through the world imperceptibly to mortals, are suddenly draining towards a central point, Scraif, starving the local area of the fundamental energy wizards needed to function.

The only other time you'd seen wizards draw so much into themselves was when witnessing magi preparing themselves before the casting of potent, draining spells. And Scraif is a sorcerer like you - he doesn't know any spells of that level, the Orders make sure of that.

The only other reason why a wizard might do such a thing would be if they were preparing to fight another wizard - choking their opponent of the energy needed to fight. This is conjecture - wizardly combat being a school of learning reserved for sanctioned and trusted agents of the academy, and like powerful arcanum, it is certainly an education deprived of sorcerers ever since the calamitous Sorcerer Wars of centuries past.

Conjecture formulated in the fraction of a second you have to consider unfolding events, but accurate nonetheless. With a crackle of golden energy, a ripple of force bursts from Scraif, blasting the straw mattress into whirling chaff and slamming you back against the wall. Scraif has evidently had a different upbringing. At some point he's learned to defend himself against his fellow wizards.

"You're just like all the rest," he snarls, as he...
122312131332.title: to Scraif standing over you, spells primed, dem...

choices: ... walk over to Scraif and awkwardly try to comfort him.
... remind Scraif of his job and duty to try to perk him up a bit.
... are interrupted by a wide-eyed Rodrigo at the door.
... are interrupted by a member of the tavern's staff that is very angry/scared.
1223121313325.content:
You stagger to your feet and fill your lungs with the thaumically depleted air. You’ve escaped the decadent courts of the Bishanian queen and the twisted prison-tower of Erolus with a few clever words and a small feat of prestidigitation; surely you could handle your former prefect solely with the prior!

On the other, more worrying hand, Stefan’s fair face seems to be twisted into a masque of hate, his unoccupied hand tracing sigils in the magically-variegated air concentrated around him.

“Th—” Your voice splutters out into a hoarse whisper, spurred by the dead air. before you manage to collect yourself. “There’s no shame in what happened, Scraif, any sorcerer could’ve GLK.”

The remainder of your quite-impressive speech is interrupted by what feels like an iron bar bent around your throat — a spin on Perroso’s Manacles, once again collapsing you against the wall, hands scrabbling at your neck. Stefan advances towards you, stomp by floor-rumbling stomp, the hand holding the jerkin white-knuckled.

“No more of your fucking traitorous words, Meade,” he growls, spitting your name like a curse. “I should’ve known last night, with your ‘Yes sir, Praepostor!’ and ‘How full would you like your cup, Praepostor?’”

A small part of you wants to protest his inaccurate recollection, but that’s far from your greatest concern. Your right hand’s fingers are still occupied by the invisible binding around your neck, nails gouging indentations in the construct. Wizards were a vain and volatile sort, fair, but a reaction like this to a two helping hands was far beyond the pale! True, Light magic feels invasive at the best of times, but any visions he might have endured should have been wholly positive, and furthermore, completely self-created. Your mind races, furiously trying to cobble statements of placation communicable through one-handed gestures.

He leans towards you, extending a hand that positively burns with magic. Your gaze inadvertently dips to the valley of flesh crushed against the jerkin, and he stiffens straight as if struck.

“Gods, you’re sick.” he hisses, his voice heavy with unidentifiable emotion. He advances towards you once again, hand once again glowing with contracted Crimson.

Fortunately, the counter-incantation you’ve been scratching into the manacle takes, and the force dissipates from your neck, the raw skin greedily sucking in the wisps of magic that remain. Scraif jerks backward, his anger morphed to terror, and a fair bit of magic returns to the air.

“Get the fuck away from me!” he screeches, slinging bolts of unrefined energy at you, letting the jerkin fall to. Fortunately, countering those was a central part of a first year’s education, and you do so with ease. He scoots back against the wall and pulls his knees to his chest, body quivering.

In turn, you lay your back against the wall opposing his and slide down, a wave of relief washing over your body. Scraif doesn’t make a move in response; you imagine that channeling a least an entire room’s worth of thaumic energy through one’s form must be draining. His eyes are sharp flinty slits, though, and they dance through the room, falling on everything but you.

You’ve seen conduct like this in wild animals, and bedraggled survivors of leveled towns: scratched and savage, ready to claw at anything-or-one. It’s the mirror image of last night’s Scraif, cooing and shooting winsome smiles at anyone who met his eye. You’re not sure which one you prefer, honestly, and adding the image of your second-year praepostor and the wannabe-besot from last night doesn’t make your choice any easier.

You clear your throat; this air wouldn’t do for whatever was next to come, whether it be writing a report or attempting cooperation. “Scraif, do —”

“How’d you do it.” he interrupts, his voice dry and flat like old parchment. “Just tell me how you got me here, then leave. Please.”

Your mouth opens and closes like a Kvossian trout. Goddess, did he think that you were the one that drugged him? Was that what this tiff was about? Your face reddens to a ruddy sheen at the unspoken slander.

“What the hell are you on about, man!?” you bluster. Scraif’s eyes widen in response and he tries — and fails — to further flatten himself against the wall.

“I came downstairs after putting the boy to sleep to find you hanging off a stranger’s arm and you’re upset at me for extricating you?” All color has drained from Scraif’s face, and his mismatched eyes are fixed firmly on the ground.

“Do you think that I would’ve worked on you all night —” He squeezes his arms tighter around his calves and his eyes sparkle with horrified tears. “— on my own volition? You needed it, Scraif; elsewise I’d have you making moon eyes at me still!”

“You’re a bastard and a liar, Meade!” He tries to rise to his feet, but his legs fail him and he collapses, leg splayed out, his delicate form exposed once again. “I would never do — I haven’t—”

“You damn well did, Scraif!” you shout back. Flexing your fingers, you once again fill yourself with the unpleasant sensation of Gold, letting it give shape to your memories. A small rectangle wobbles in the center of the room, a collection of your memories of last night flitting through it.

Stefan watches with increasing horror at the images that flit across” covering his mouth at the sight of his lazy smile and fluttering eyelashes; choking back a sob at his enthusiastic observance of your command; hiding his face with his legs as his illusionary doppelganger lovingly rubs itself against your hand. You shift your gaze away, to give him some sense of privacy

You dispel the illusion with a flex of your fingers and a roll of your neck. Scraif still has his head hidden — he knows just as well as you that a mere second-circle Light mage doesn’t have the skill to alter their own recollections. You allow a smile on your face as you stare up at the ceiling; he should be nice and contrite now.

But Scraif is no better off than a few minutes ago: he’s wrapped his tunic around his upper body like a blanket, his leather jerkin discarded to the side. His body shakes intermittently with the force of contained sobs and small tear-stains are spreading across the legs of his pants. Pangs of regret stir in your chest: you didn’t think he’d take it this badly.

“Get out.” he intones in a muffled voice. “This damn city — this damn kingdom’s won. I'm poisoned."

You stumble to the door, risking a look back at the figure who, for all intents and purposes, looked quite the delicate waif.

Your hand on the doorknob, you…
1223121313325.title: ...breaks down in tears

choices: Enjoying a breakfast of danger, followed by a brunch of peril
A watchman leads you to the scene of the crime
Rodrigo returns, though remains terrified of you for the rest of the day
Rodrigo returns, back to his normal upstart self
12231213133253.content:
Your hesitate with your hand on the half-twisted door handle, Scraif's sobs ringing in your ears. You should say something, though you're not sure what. Nothing too patronising, that would only make things worse... something that says, even though he doesn't have to share exactly what has happened to him in his life, you understand, you sympathise, and you're here if he needs help or simply to talk.

You begin to speak and receive a mouthful of door for your trouble as it is violently shouldered open by a frantic Rodrigo. A thin bedsheet wrapped haphazrdly about his frame, he resembles a priestess in a diaphanous gown, though the double-headed battleaxe clutched in his left hand ruins the illusion. It looks oversized and unwieldy for his frame, though he swings it with ease towards the corners of the room as if seeking out a threat. The metal of the blade is a lustrous, blood-red colour - some rare alloy of mysterious properties perhaps, or just the gaudy affectation a freshly graduated teenage wizard might request of their blacksmith.

"What is the meaning of this intrusion?" you bark, lightly sidestepping as the axe swipes nearby.

"Boss, my third eye is seriously tingling, if you know what I mean, and I don't mean the one in my pants. I think somebody is throwing some serious energies around."

"Yes," you state icily. As the axe swings wildly again, you neatly seize the haft and his attention. "We were."

"Oh." His gaze moves around you to fall on the slumped, sniffling, half-clothed versi on the floor and his eyes go wide as dinner plates. He stares up at you, accusing but afraid. "Wh-what did you do to him?"

This is a refreshing change from the impudent youth of last night. Fear is almost as good as respect. "The same thing I'm tempted to do to you," you hiss. "Bursting in to a superior's chambers unannounced. The sheer nerve." With a hard shove on the axe, you send him tumbling backwards out of the room. It wouldn't do to have him see Scraif's state for too long - the boy might never respect the praeposter again after witnessing the tears rolling down his cheeks. "Get dressed. We have a mission."

You follow him out. His face is pale, his eyes are unable to look away from the sad figure of Scraif as you close the door behind you. He hefts his axe, a flicker of defiance passing over his face. "Do you have something to say, recruit?" You force a leery grin. "Perhaps you'd like to discuss things in private." He swallows hard and shakes his head silently, skulking away.

Using such implied threats doesn't sit well with you, but it is effective and typical among the culture of the colleges. With all those massive egos and powerful individuals trapped together in an single institution, a strict hierarchy enforced by systems of fear and dominance is the only hope of creating any semblance of order, the only way to stop the place blowing itself apart with spiraling rivalries. Wizards there are either predators or they're prey; the weak forced to service the strong, or collected as no more than etheric batteries or back-up bodies for the upper echelons. You know teachers who accepted the positions only for the opportunities offered to them for hand-selecting and grooming promising students.

Thank the goddess you're in the field, away from all that. But for Rodrigo, it's the only culture he's known for most of his life. If you don't bring him to heel soon, he'll start looking at you as his next meal.

Waiting in the common room for your ward, you roll a small platinum coin across the counter to the innkeeper to ease your conscience. "Have the woman in room six transferred to finer accommodation. Anything she wants, she gets." Hopefully a day of comfort will straighten Scraif out. It must be the stress...
12231213133253.title: ... are interrupted by a wide-eyed Rodrigo at t...

choices: "If you must know, I didn't lay a finger on the man," you state
Ask him how life is for a versi in a strange land
122312131332534.content:
The central cistern is a massive, wedge-shaped construction of white sandstone that juts from the side of the mountain like the tail fin of an enormous fish. It extends almost from the top of the mountain-city to the very bottom, carving the city in two were it not for the tunnels built through it that allow pedestrians and carts to pass through.

While the viaducts leading away from the city receive their water directly from the mountain, the water that issues from the volcano is almost boiling, far too hot to be immediately used by locals, and so is held and cooled within the cistern prior to use. Gouts of steam issue from the upper levels like smoke from a blacksmith's furnace.

High above, dozens of channels emerge from the walls, carrying freshwater over rooftops to distant parts of the city, the villas of the wealthy and powerful, and the larger inns, but there are also troughs built into the cistern at street level, municipal fonts available to all. The water gushes from a barred, ornate circular pipe several feet in diameter- fresh, free... and ignored by everybody on the street. The locals are giving it a wide berth as a matter of fact.

"You say this is where they found the bodies?"

The recruit has been giving you the stink-eye since the tavern, and had insisted on bringing that absurd axe with him, despite the strange glances from the locals. "Uh huh, that's what we were told. The water was tasting weird for days, then one morning they found the pipes clogged with corpses."

"How many?"

"Clogged. Nearly a dozen, they think. The guards had to cut them into little pieces to get them out."

You step up to the font and run your hand under the flow. The water is quite cool, and refreshing in the dry heat. You run a cupped handful through your hair and take a mouthful, swilling it around. It tastes perfectly like water. A local gives you a filthy look when you spit it on to the cobbles - water is almost divine to them, a sin to waste it.

"The guards didn't happen to save any of the bodies, did they? I'd like to inspect them."

"What part of 'little pieces' do you not understand? Those bars are inches apart - those bodies were tomato soup by the time they got them out."

"They didn't think to cut the bars first?" you scoff at the ingenuity of local law enforcement.

"Look at the bars..." Your initial assumption was that the bars were iron, but of course iron would have rusted long ago. On closer inspection, the dull grey metal has a light green sheen - adamantine. "This place is like a temple to these people, or a vault. It's really well protected. Every exit sealed. Nobody gets in."

"Not even wizards?"

"Why do you think we've been holed up in a tavern for days? Nobody sets foot in there without the Lord's permission, and good luck getting that. And you know how Scraif is - he won't even let you go for a piss without a permission slip."

Stretching up on your tip toes, you are able to peer in through the bars down the broad pipe that disappears into steam-filled darkness. You strain your eyes for any sound. You sense the recruit standing close to your elbow as he mutters, "I don't blame you for what you did to the guy. If you ask me, he had it coming. Somebody should have broken him in years ago." At your sharply raised eyebrow, he adds, "come on, the guy has been living here for thirty years. He should know how things work by now."
122312131332534.title: Rodrigo returns, back to his normal upstart self

choices: ...abruptly cast a shrinking spell on him and push him through the bars
...are deeply concerned about the young man's learning environment
1223121313325342.content:
"And you know how 'things work'?"

"I make things work for me," he says boastfully, puffing out his chest. "I've been here since I was 12. I might not be the smartest in my class, but I quickly learned what I am to you people. Sure, the first few years were rough, but I adapted eventually."

"I'm truly sorry to hear that," you say sincerely and gently, "but this can wait until after we resolve the matter of the dozen dead bodies."

"I just need to know where we stand, if we're working together. I don't care what you do with Scraif; as far as I'm concerned he's your property now. But if you get bored of him, decide to move on to me, we'll find some sort of arrangement."

"'Arrangement'? Do you come to arrangements with all your superiors?" You find it hard to make eye contact with the boy, filled with a mixture of great sympathy and disgust for the life he has lived and the compromises made as a versi living in Tryzantium lands, and you focus on the outlet pipe, staring fixedly into the depths. Though the water is cool, waves of steam still vent this way from deeper in the monumental construction. Staring through the white clouds and shadows, a misshapen object can just about be seen deeper in the pipe. Alas, the bars are set close together and adamatine, resistant to most forms of magic.

You try to brush him aside, silence his coy words. "In any event, you delude yourself to think I'd show even the slightest interest in you."

"I don't think so. I'm twice the man Scraif is." He steps up behind you, his arms slip lightly around your bicep, drawing your upper arm between his soft breasts as he rests his chin on your shoulder. "Which means I'm twice the woman in your eyes. That's how it works, isn't it?"

You want to shake him off, to scold him as you did last night, but it is one thing to face him when he is calling you a slut with his dick in his hands, and another thing entirely when he is pressing his deceptively feminine form against you while whispering honeyed words in your ear. "See this axe? A gift from archmage Widogast. We both got something we wanted. Like I said, I'm open to arrangements. I doubt I could stop you if you got the urge, but I'd at least like to be raped on my own terms."

12231213133253422.content:
Snaking an arm around the youth's slender waist, your fingers reach to grasp his shapely backside. By what whimsical rationale had the gods blessed the versi males with such ample padding, you wonder. A portable cushion for long hunting trips perhaps? For that matter, why were true women so endowed in that area? The recruit seems to anticipate your caress with resigned satisfaction.

"You versi sure are a handful," you say.

A bolt of golden energy crackles from your palm into the recruit's backside, who gives a yelp and a leap into the air. He doesn't land. His body, clothed and weapons contract in on themselves in a heartbeat. Your hand placement was top notch - a doll-sized Rodrigo falls into your palm.

"That was a dirty trick!" his mousey voice pipes up at you.

You rock his world. His hands grip your index and little fingers tightly as he bellows in terror as the minor movement nearly unseats him from his perch.

From tip to tiny toes, Rodrigo now stands less than a foot in height. It is all you can do to resist the urge to 'aww' as he glowers up at you. What the hey. With the index finger of your other hand, you ruffle the hair on his little head. The angry brandishing of his toothpick sized battleaxe lets you know you will only get to do that once.

Pushing your arm through the adamantine bars, the minute recruit is deposited onto the floor of the water pipe. The water level and the curvature of the pipe is low enough that he can walk albeit awkwardly above the waterline on the curved ceramic surface of the bottom half of the pipe.

The crumpled dark shape in the distance is still there, shrouded in steam. "Wh-what the hell do you want me to do?" he asks fearfully. Your fingertips, large as battering rams, give him a shove in the appropriate direction.

Rodrigo stands motionless in the entrance of the grate, face etched with worry as he stares into the steamy depths. You stifle a sigh. You couldn’t trust a greenhorn with reconnaissance, you suppose.

You shove the recruit a bit further down the pipe with a flick of your index to his rear, then wrap the selfsame finger along with your middle one around a bar of the grate. A quick spark of light was all it took before you started to shrink, yourself.

A familiar plummeting sensation situates itself in your stomach as the world stretches around you. The bar, no thicker than the barrel of a smoking-pipe, grows to the size of an oak, and your two finger grip quickly necessitates both hands.

Rodrigo’s face is consternated rather than impressed as you pull yourself up, choosing instead to cross his arms and pout rather than help his superior.

You make another mental note to include ‘impetuous’ in your scathing report. Or maybe ‘insubordinate’ would do. ‘Feckless’ was always a good one.

“Whydja have to send me in here, if you’re just gonna come along?” he whines. He rolls his eyes dramatically and tightens his crossed arms, huffing all the while, but you can see his slight shoulders relax. The little scamp was nervous, after all.

You stretch a crick out of your neck and peer into the darkness. The object’s is still hazy through the fog, with no sharp corners or edges to define its shape. You heave a quick sigh and resign yourself to the trek. Although…

“Right, recruit, lead the way.”

“W-what?” You hope you do a better job hiding your exasperation than he hides his fear.

“I’ll be behind you every step, boy.” You conjure a small burst of flame demonstratively.

Rodrigo sags in disappointment, but refrains from further complaint. He moves his shaky hands in familiar gestures, summoning a small orb of light, illuminating only the barest distance ahead of you. His other hand hefts his battleaxe, arm lined with light Jade, to enhance his strength, you assume.

You’d never admit it to the whelp, but you are slightly proud — you’d probably take point in a similar fashion. Well, with less fearful trembling, but still. In your hand trembles a dull purple orb of arcane energy, dull enough to not pique the recruit’s attention. If you’re unlucky enough to encounter any rodents of unusual size, it’ll be a red mist before the recruit musters up enough nerve to strike the thing.

But as you walk down the pipe, no furry things attempt to harass you — the talk about Kvossian hygiene isn’t just that, apparently — and your attention naturally falls to the figure carefully tiptoeing across the metal like an anxious showhorse. You observe the sashay of his wide hips for a few seconds, musing on the purpose of such feminine adornments. Was it for a lower centre of balance? To hide more muscle fibre underneath soft, pliable padding?

You shake your head. It’s best not to be caught doing anything that could be construed for ogling, lest Rodrigo start another round of clumsy (ambition-laden) flirting. It’s a wonder that he’s managed to navigate the Academy’s twisted paths of backroom dealing and hidden motives mostly unscathed; you’ve seen more talented wizards fall to more deviant demeanors.

There exists, in the public eye, a certain stereotype of sorceresses, of voluptuous beauties with low-necklined robes and waves of shimmering secondary-coloured hair. The truth was usually far away. A good amount of the women that make it through the Academy’s sexist rigors either glamour themselves into wrinkled crones and move to the edge of some podunk village to serve as an enigmatic apothecary; or simply go to the more matriarchal Erolus.

Any average citizen gaping at the beauty conjuring shows of dazzling light would likely be horrified to learn that the figure they were ogling was, more often than not, a man.

There’s nothing particularly wrong with the shapeshifting itself: one of the most effective journeymen you know is almost always in the form of a female fairy — he said it was easier to find comfortable bedding, and saved him quite a few coppers on food and ale. He never did say why it had to be a girl fairy, though.

It was a systemic system of predation that created these faux-sorceresses. Those talented in Jade and Light magic were taken under the wing of their superiors and given ample praise and gifts, their frequent absences from class excused through letters and assurances of ‘private tutoring’. Their ability to change shape would be honed, though the idea of learning any other kind of practical magic would be eschewed entirely.

You’d be left with a simpering lapdog of a wizard, a chap who could change into a comely young lass whose proportions dwarf the effete rules of biology, but would balk at the idea of casting your most basic defense spell.

A student you met at enrollment, Lionel Scaffson, went down this sordid path. He was a bulky lad, ‘round six and a half feet tall and weighing more than ten stone. Now, he spent most of his time half that weight and two feet shorter, lounging in a cushy desk in front of some slimy bureaucrat’s office, resting his heavy bust on the enameled wood.

To his credit, it seems as if Rodrigo has escaped the worst of this indoctrination, the ‘kept man’ part of it all; the hefty axe in one hand seemed to be evidence of that. Still, his views on superior-subordinate relations was distressingly unprofessional, and disappointingly transactional.

You could probably train that out of him, you reckon. You and Scraif — er, when he’s ‘better’, you suppose — could show him the sense of accomplishment a job well done brings, and maybe trade out that gaudy axe for a more practical —

“Uh, b-boss? What is th-this?”

You stop a foot short of crashing into your charge. You were so embroiled in thought that you hadn’t noticed the gradual approach of your quarry.

It’s a large golden medallion roughly your current size, a golden chain draped haphazardly on the curved metal surface. That’s not what gave Rodrigo pause though; that would be the design on the medal proper.

It’s an open, diseased mouth, the gums pockmarked with rot and pulsing red with some arcane substance, the teeth either carved out of yellowing ivory or taken from the mouth of some poor sap. The sides of the metal are bone-dry, but the design proper seems to be wet as the real thing, either the work of a minor glamour or bestowed upon the jewelry by forces you don’t want to consider.

Most unsettling of all, in between the teeth where the throat would normally be, sits a single bloodshot eye; the veins a red filigree, the pupil a deep inky black with no sheen or slight reflection of Rodrigo’s conjured light.

“I’m not sure.” you murmur to Rodrigo, but he pays no heed to your belated answer, instead swaying slowly towards the medal.

You stop him short with a yank of his jerkin, and he lets out a squawk, shooting you a look of contempt before he realizes where his feet were taking him. “Thanks.” he mumbles, a look of slight contrition angled at the floor.

“I want a circle four ward on you before you even think about touching that thing.” you command. In seconds, a light shimmering haze surrounds you and the versi youth.

In a display of initative that you’re slightly proud of, Rodrigo starts moving his fingers of his left hand in familiar patterns, outstretching his right towards the metal. You stop him with a lighter hand than before, but his look is no less sour.

“We’re not using magic on this thing,” you say, dragging a finger across the metal’s surface. You can feel a soft vibration of energy even through your ward. “Who knows how the dammed thing’ll react.”

Rodrigo sighs dramatically, a bit of his bravado regained with the protective magic ensconcing him. “Whaddya propose we do then, sir?”

You ignore his tone and wave vaguely at the chain. “We have arms, don’t we?”

Rodrigo sags in disappointment.

Anyone looking into the pipe would see quite the sight: two ersatz oxen dragging quite the odd plow behind the two of them.

1223121314.content:
The ambient chatter of barflies greets halfway down the chairs, which fills you with an odd sort of relief; you were half-expecting Stefan to demonstrate the manifold ways in which he was not a girl to the bartender. That selfsame man stands by a counter near the stairs as you enter the tavern proper, still pulling his mustache like its a lifeline. He opens his mouth to say something as you pass, but a quick sour expression has him thinking elsewise.

Stefan is still seated at the table, but his mind seems to be in another place. His head is slumped facefirst on the table, his long hair forming a silver wreath around his skull. A viscous river of drool slowly makes its way across the wood grain.

You take a seat at the table, unsure how to continue. Waking a wizard was a daunting task; a drunk one even more so. You wince as you recall an incident of your own: after a night carousing with a Erolusian strumpet, you had lit the wig of the brothel’s madam ablaze after she shook you awake. You had paid more than a little extra for that; throwing around the name of the Order to fix slipups rarely ended well.

The silver-tressed head to your right starts to shift around, and you flinch involuntarily. Stefan mumbles, or it could just be a collection of groans and grunts. You lean in closer, trying to catch any words.

“Prae- Er, Sorceror Scraif?” you venture. “I’ve… met the ‘student’.”

Contralto peals of laughter rise from your former prefect’s bowed head. With great effort, Stefan raises his head, still lightly wobbling from the drink. His eyes are bleary and unfocused, but the smile on his face is solidly set.

“You did a lot more than meet ‘im, Miissteeerr Meade.” he slurs. His breath is hot and boozy — he must’ve put a lot away in the time you were gone.

“I’m sorry?”

“Don’t get cute with me, Journeyman.” he grumbles, leveling an accusatory finger at you. That very finger made its way to his left eye, impacting it not with a squelch, but with a tink. It hums softly with magic.

‘A scrying orb, you realize, your face blanching.

“Saw the whoooooollleee thing.” he crows. “Heard it too. Turned the damn thing off after the urchin conjured hisself a fuck, but got it running again just in time for the show~”

You can practically feel decade-old cane stripes start to throb. “I didn’t— That is to say-”

“Oh hush.” he rumbles. You quietly comply.

“That’s the Meade that I sent up there,” he sniggers, waving a delicate hand at you. “‘Yes, Praepostor Scraif? How high should I jump, Praepostor Scraif?’ A pusillanimous, deferential toady, here to steal my last scrap of ‘thority.”

You look askance the tavern for anyone who might be looking, but no eyes meet yours. Even the barkeep has averted his gaze, instead tending to the side of the counter that faces away from the both of you.

“What do you mean?” you ask, the flint-edge of anger creeping into your voice.
“And that’s the man that emerged!” he exclaims, shakily hoisting a cup in mock toast. He clumsily traces a sigil on the table, shifting his stool closer to yours with faint Jade glow. “A chap who’ll take no guff, with a voice ‘a thunder and fist of iron!”

His hand snakes its way below the table and rests on your thigh. Some distant part of your mind is telling you to move away, but dread curiosity and confusion roots you in place. The smile that curves his lips is disarmingly unguarded, his eyes half-lidded and hazy.

“You’re like a dog, snarling at strangers ‘n rolling over for master. My own attack dog.” he murmurs. “Mongrel Meade.”

He leans forward, gently swaying and chuckling lightly as your mouth opens and closes like a Kvossian trout. You scoot backward as far as your seat will allow, all the while trying to gently dislodge his hand, but it doesn’t budge.

Damn Versian strength.

“Scraif, I really do think it’d be best if you—”

“Shhhhhh,” he whispers, pressing a small finger to your lips, and you can’t help but comply. His eyes are feline past the lids half-covering them, and the mixed blue and gold slowly but inexorably approaches.

“S’ good for you that I like dogs.”

You’re really not sure how to take that, but Stefan apparently does as he closes his eyes, his pert lips parting as they approach your own, a nonsyllabic coo escaping from them…

And then, his head falls onto the table with a meaty thunk.

The rest of his limbs follow shortly thereafter. Hissing in sympathy, you cup his chin and lift his head from the wood. His eyes flutter lightly otherwise but remain bleary, and a nasty red welt has started to swell on his forehead.

“Scraif, I—” A sudden coughing fit overtakes you, and Stefan burbles gently in response. You can hear the breath catch in his throat. Eh, sod it. If he remembered his name tomorrow, you’d be shocked.

As slowly and inconspicuously as you can — which is to say, not at all— you slide Scraif into your arms; dipping one arm into the crook of his knee and laying the other one along his spine. It’s not the ideal position to carry a peer, but you’re looking for expedience, not ego-preservation.

To your dismay, Stefan lets out a discontent moan and squirms in your arms until his face is pressed against you bicep. He shifts again, curling his body lightly against your shape.

A deep chortle rises behind you and a heavy hand falls on your shoulder. You whirl around to meet an extraordinarily ugly man, an empty eye-socket red and puckered and his teeth practically orange with Sylphroot.

“Saw this one lurking ‘round the pub fer hours,” he drawls. “Thought she needed a stiff one — and it looks like you’re giving ‘er both kinds tanite!”

He guffaws uproariously at his own joke as you quickly make your way to the stairs, balancing the tasks of head-protection and feet-collision-avoidance. Various knowing eyes and appreciative gazes are extended to you as you navigate the floor, and the rotund bartender avoids your gaze even more assiduously, if that was possible.

Making the way up the stairs is an exercise in side-stepping, and you’re slightly thankful for Scraif’s clingy nature: the arm that he curls around your bicep is a much-needed binding for your squirmy cargo. The sigh you let out is a mixture of consternation and relief: Wizards that get this drunk are like powderkegs serving double-time as candle-holders; messy, with more than a little collateral damage. This tavern got off easy considering he only got… flirty.

You can partially sympathize with him; if you were marooned in Versiland for the better part of a few decades, you’d be more than a little frustrated, in more than one way. Him smokily murmuring your name into your ear is … more difficult to justify. Sure, you stole a few looks whenever you had the fortune to be ended up in the baths at the same time, but you could hardly be blamed for that; the only breast you’d seen before that belonged to some poxy whore in the slums of Tryzantium.

Still, that was your boyhood. You’re both Circle mages, and you’re held to a higher standard of conduct than horny students in the bath; you’ll overlook this one night of indiscretion, provided Scraif conducts himself well on the investigation of… no, wasn’t it the guarding of… hm.

Shit, he didn’t even brief you. Something about murders? You unlock and open the door to your room with more than a little difficulty and dark expression. Rodrigo’s bed seems to be relatively still; he’s either asleep or quite good at pretending, and you can’t quite muster up the motivation to care either way.

You disentangle Scraif’s arm from your own and dump him on the bed without ceremony. As expected — and to your slight relief — he barely stirs, merely emitting another low grumble.

You survey the room, but disappointingly no cot or bed meets your gaze. Only a knackered old rocking chair on the opposite corner of the room. It’ll have to do, you suppose.
