12231213141.content:
There is a culture somewhere in Hashan you think, that uses a rocking chair as a torture devices. The subject is strapped to the chair and left alone for days. The moment they fall asleep, slumping backwards or forwards in the chair, the chair rocks, inducing the sensation of falling and startling them awake. After a week of sleep deprivation, the subject is usually willing to talk.

You could now confirm its efficacy after a night of half-sleep, precariously propping yourself in positions to distribute your weight evenly upon sleep, only to be awoken from a scant few minutes of slumber by a loud creak and precipitous falling sensation, as your leg shifted or your elbow slipped from the chair arm.

It is well after midnight. The revelry of the tavern has dispersed and the streets are quiet, making you now accurately aware of the pervasive, ever-present background tinkle and gurgle of the cisterns, aqueducts and waterways of Kvoss. What you judge to be every two hours, some vast, distant sluice is opened by some rumbling machinery, sending a roar of water deep underground.

The wooden bars of the chair back dig into your spine. The two beds call to you. After days of travel to get here, how wonderful it would feel to slip between crisp sheets. You could always order Rodrigo awake, send him away on some pointless errand, make him run laps of the area until sunrise perhaps. You glance over and immediately wish you had not.

It is a hot, sticky night, typical for Kvoss. Without the springs, the area would be a desert. With the springs, the area is a sauna. At some point during the night, Rodrigo has evidently kicked the sheets back to feel the air on his skin. His bare, naked skin. The sheets lie tangled about his feet, while the rest of his nubile, nude form is draped... displayed... over the bed. His head lies in a pool of his dark hair spread out over the pillows, his slack expression unbearably sweet and innocent in sleep, like a cherub.

A shaft of moonlight streaks through the tessellated window panels, casting an ornate geometric pattern over his softly rising-and-falling breasts.

You realise you've been staring at them long enough to judge the movement of the moon across the sky.

Rodrigo grumbles and stirs, scratching absently at one breast and rolling on to his side in his sleep. Previously tucked between his soft thighs, his flaccid manhood slips free as he does so, jarring you from your lengthy admiration of his form.

"Get a grip," you whisper to yourself. "He's a student." And one already worryingly forward and precocious. The Order is meant to instill in the recruits the idea of sublimating ones own personal pleasures in favour of a broader love for king and countrymen. True, it rarely works well in wizards. But in the boy it doesn't seem to have worked at all.

You suspect growing up with a body like that in a predominantly all-male environment. No doubt his peers have taken liberties with him over the years, or tried to at least, by guile, force, or magic. Hell, you could list more teachers than you'd like to admit whom you wouldn't trust alone in a room with the boy .

Including yourself, you think with shame, realizing your eyes have drifted back to his resplendent rack. The heat must be getting to you. Or perhaps the distance. Easy to forget ones duty this far from the empire's center.

Channeling a modicum of unaspected energy, you draw the sheets back up his body from the safe distance of the far side of the room. Then you shut your eyes tight and force sleep to come.

--------

"Sleeping beauty awakes," says the voice, half mocking, half admiring. "You really slept there? You must be stiffer than me."

You open your eyes to find...

122312131412.content:
Based on his words, you expect to open your eyes to find your recruit standing there with his morning wood in his hands. You relieved and a little impressed to see he has taken the initiative to garb himself in combat attire, and is busy strapping a greave to his shin.

"Are you going to sleep in all day or are we actually going to go catch this guy?" he says impatiently.

The armour he's donning is the standard issue leathers, and his are unmarred by sword or arrow or flame - he's as green a recruit as they come, despite what his cocksure attitude might suggest. Crafted to fit both sexes, it is delightfully shapeless and sexless, concealing the worst excesses of his curvature, though the shortsword he sling about his waist still seems to hang off his broad hips in a way that can only be described as coquettish. He looks like a girl playing at being a knight, but the first lesson learned as a wizard is the deceptiveness of appearances - you're confident he can handle himself against most humans and beasts.

"Ugh. This is so fiddly. Normally I'd have at least two guys helping me put these on," he says, exaggerating his pout. "You want to help?" he asks, holding out his tassets.

"A master does not play squire to his apprentice," you retort sharply. "Dress yourself. Then you may dress me," you command, ignoring the flicker in his eyes and smile on the edge of his lips.

You rise and stretch, crossing the room to where Scraif lays, unmoved from the position in which you dumped him. A gurgling snore emerges from his wide open, parched lips, about which flies are buzzing. The smell of drink is still heavy on him

A pitiful sight, especially in front of a recruit. The Scraif you knew would never allowed himself, or anyone else for that matter, to drink himself into such a stupor. The years have not been kind to him. Which pused him to drink, you wonder... the loneliness; the work; or perhaps the attitudes of his superiors. Many recruits these days are women, but the upper eschelons of the Order is almost exclusively men (or at least they are men most of the time), and men whose attitudes have not been challenged or changed in hundreds of years. They do not smile kindly upon female underlings - except when having their meals brought to them.

Rodrigo relishes playing squire. You suspect he even enjoys the sharp strike from the back of your hand every time his fingers begin to reach into places they should not go, or linger too long. He is generous with his compliments, his obsequious words seemingly seeking to make amends for his actions during the night, but it is clear his comments on your physical prowess are for his own satisfaction, not yours - the sort of remarks a crass labourer might make to a woman that catches his eye upon the street.

"If you make one more comment about the size of my muscles, I swear I'll birch your hide," you bark.

"Don't make a boy a promise..." Rodrigo titters, dodging out of the way of your backhand.

Even as the last of your armour is donned, Scraif has yet to stir. "Let's just leave him."

"I give the orders here, boy." We should just leave him. "I have yet to be briefed on the mission."

"Oh, I know all about that," Rodrigo replies airily. "As a matter of fact, half the tavern have heard about what we're doing here these last few days. I'd be more than happy to fill you in."

Why does everything the boy say sound like a damn innuendo? "Fine. Let's here it."

12231213143.content:
You haven't made it a step before Scraif's hand snags your hand, soft as silk, tight as a vice. With his unnatural versian strength (unnatural compared to what one might expect from a girl at least), he clings to you like glue even as you try to disentangle yourself. He is still drunk and concussed, barely able to lift his head from the sheets or open his eyes, but his other hand finds your wrist, tightening.

"That hurts," you wince.

"Sweeet Meade," he murmurs in his half sleep. "Always playing the fool... so that we could... be together."

"'Be together'?" The shadowed quilts of the recruit continue to rise and fall steadily, thankfully (hopefully) asleep. "Listen, you sot, the only times we were ever 'together' were when you had me bent over a desk with my pants around my ankles." Oh gods, please let Rodrigo be asleep. "Or have you forgotten all the times you used to birch me raw? I spent most of third year unable to sit down!"

Scraif's mouth twists into a lopsided grin, like a man experiencing the most wonderful dreams. "I r'member... all'v 'em... good times."

"Good times?" you retort, anger rising in you. "I was terrified of you. You used to collar me for the most petty shit - walking on the wrong side of the corridor, not having my robes tucked in - people don't even tuck robes in! It was like you were always there, always watching, lurking behind every corner. Like you were stalking me! Every week after potions class, you'd catch me-"

"-on your way to Professor Erliqium's evocation lesson..." Scraif mumbles, the words spilling from his memory. "Sweet Meeaade... my first...

"You were stalking me!" You grip his fingers, prising them from your wrist one-by-one. He gives a howl of sadness and frustration, burying his head in the pillow. With words laced with venom of tormented childhood memories, you snap, "when I saw you today, I actually felt sorry for you - a wizard stuck in his teenage years, humiliating." With your hand now free, you give his young body an angry, demonstrative jab. "No wonder you haven't aged a day in 20 years. You're still hung up on some stupid teenage crush. You need to grow up."

There is a stifled snicker from the supposedly sleeping form of the recruit. You pull yourself sharply back from your former praeposter, whose face is screwed up in an ugly mask of sorrow.

123.content:
"Only five years old the boy was. Terrible thing when that happened, we were very fond of him."

"What caused the death?" You ask him.

He shrugs a bit, as he looks in the fire. "We don't have a doctor around here, only my wife knows a bit of illnesses. The boy had fever and shriveled all the time. It was a mercy when he died."

"So what happened next?" You ask irritated.

"Martha, you have to understand, was always a bit peculiar. Some of us weren't too sad to see her gone. She moved to the city for a few years and when she came back she had the boy with her. She wouldn't talk about the father. That boy was her every thing."

You are about to make a comment again, when the elder holds up his hand. "I know, I know you want to know what this has to do with anything. I'll tell you. It's Martha you see. When the boy died she had quite a shock. When we hadn't seen Martha and the boy for a couple of days we went inside their cottage. Inside the boy lied on his bed peaceful and Martha was sitting on a chair just staring at the boy. Like she was someplace far away." The elder shrivels. "After that we thought things would go back to normal, but..."

"It just sounds like a mother who has lost her child, cases like that are similar.

"It's not!" The elder shouts pushing his cane into the ground. Realizing what he had done, the fire in his eyes wither down. "I'm sorry, this is just very hard for me. Things have changed around here. Martha isn't herself anymore."

"What kind of behavior?" You ask.

"At first she wouldn't speak with us anymore, she kept to herself. Only time she left her cottage was in the middle of the night. A few of the farm boys have seen her leave. They even heard her cackling as she disappeared into the forest."

"And now?"

"Now she acts perfectly normal. She comes out of her cottage, visits the market stalls, even joining the women gossiping."

"That doesn't sounds suspicious to me, it sounds like she has picked up her normal life."

"Sir, she has never been like that. She was always the odd one." The elder grabs you by your shoulder. "Please just go and talk to her. Maybe you can see what is wrong with her."

You pull away the hand from you. "If that's what you're asking fine, but you know what the fine is for calling us without an emergency." You stand up as to prepare to leave.

The elder nods as he stands up as well. He explains to you where you can find the cottage of Martha. "I have good faith in you, and please try to help my daughter."

You nod as you leave the elder's house. Outside you stare at the dark sky. Some mission this turns out to be, most likely there was nothing and the elder had to pay the fine. But something makes you curious to what has happened.

You could go to Martha's cottage, try and speak to her if she's still up. On the other hand you could talk with some of the villagers, maybe they have more information for you.

A bull had been killed for the purposes of your punishment. The carcass lies in the deepest catacomb of the castle of the Grey Order, putrefying. Its belly has bloated and burst. For six months it has rotted away in total darkness until with the clatter of a key and the screech of iron hinges the door is opened. A wizard enters, his mouth muffled against the thick stench. He holds a flaming torch over the carcass, examining the areas where meat still hangs from the bones. In these areas is a carpet of maggots, thousands wriggling and crawling and fighting over each other for the last scraps of rotted flesh.

He studies them for a long time. From his cloak he takes a pair of tweezers and a glass phial. He plucks one of the squirming maggots from among the others, holds the thin pale body up towards the light to check it before dropping it into the phial.

He walks the catacombs back to the surface, ascending through the boundary between the Colleges of the Grey and Green Orders, and from there climbing the tower to Father Rechard's study, finding the him asleep at his desk. He gently rouses the old wizard. As he leaves, he tips the maggot into the green leather chair that sits across the desk, stands back and utters an incantation.

The maggot squirms, boils and bulges, sprouting limbs, a head. You're pinned to the chair, reeling at... everything. What is this place? What is this thing sitting in front of you?

Slowly it comes back to you. "Oh..." you croak, feeling sick. "I was... right. It wasn't a dream. I am human."

Father Rechard smiles. "Yes, Meade. You have been sent away from us for some time. Do you remember why?"

"I was... being punished... for something..."

"That is how it is," Father Rechard nods sadly. "And why were you being punished?"

Slowly your human memories come back to you, though they are muddled and alien. "I was on a mission.... I... I was trying to help someone," you murmur. It was a thought that had kept you sane during your punishment, at least for the first few weeks, that one thought repeating over and over in your head. "I was trying to help someone, I'm sure of it." Faint memories resurface. "There was a woman... she was in trouble..."

Rechard scowls darkly. The old wizard grows feral, fur bursting from his skin in ugly tufts, his claws digging into the frayed wood of the desk. "You strayed from your post. You were supposed to be protecting your brother, yet you abandoned him when he was relying on you! The pack is only strong when we work together."

It comes back to you. You and Zedicus had been assigned to root out a nest of Dark Stalkers in the tunnels beneath the city of Arundel. It should have been simple - a show of force would have sent the cowardly creatures scurrying back to the deep underdark - yet Zedicus had lost it, become bloodcrazed. He been intent on butchering every last one, firing off uncontrolled spells that injured your guide, a dwarven woman and destabilizing the tunnel. "Still you spout this nonsense! The life of a dwarf is inconsequential compared to that of a wizard. The Colleges can not afford to lose even a single man. Had you not run, Zedicus would still be alive. I thought your punishment would have given you time to consider that... Perhaps another twelve months are in order."

You don't dare speak. The Father's anger seems to ebb away, he sinks back into his chair, an old man once again as the wolf in him retreats. "Get out of my sight," he mutters. "Don't let me see you in this office again."

As you leave, you notice an absence, the loss of a comforting presence in your mind that has existed since the early days of your training. "My familiar? What has become of it?"

"Destroyed. In your absence, it became uncontrollable."

Destroyed... With sudden resolve, you realise your time with the Colleges is over.

"Let's go, Miss Ter," Pegward says, grabbing your arm in a criss-cross manner, not unlike how men would pick up women at the town square. "Captain's right. I don't mind... seeing you like this, but the boys might not be able to restrain themselves. Let's go."

'Boys', you think as she drags you along the screeching planks of ship to the cabin on the opposite side of the captain's. Yet you couldn't shake the feeling that something was off. You could see several of the crew covering their eyes with their small hands, yet the fingers themselves were clearly split as their gaze followed your movement on the ship.

You recognize it almost instantly. It was the stare that your modest friend Louis gave when you two went peeking on girls bathing in the river as teenagers. A stare that typically only shy, young lads would give.

Your thoughts, however, are interrupted by the rapping on the door as your companion reaches her destination. The cabin - if it could even be called that - resembled more of a shack, hastily built with spare wood planks. It looks bizarre and out of place on this ship, you think, as the sound of busybody work behind you begins once the door firmly shuts with a blam.

The inside of the shack is unlike anything you would have imagined for a barber surgeon. The fragrance of various herbs wafts in the air, nauseating you, and numerous tools line the racks on the walls. You could see scissors, thin miniature knives, and other gadgets that you would not recognize despite being in the office of the king's physician many times.

In the middle of the room, near what you think is a bed - it's just a thin, white mattress with no covers or blankets on it - stands another woman, complimenting the rest of the crew. The only difference is that, unlike the young females getting roudy outside, she is closer to your age - somewhere in the late 30s, or perhaps even mid 40s. Her black hair is tied in a knot that cascades down her shoulder, while her breasts clearly strain against the white coat as she reaches down to pick up a strange cylindrical tool, ending in a metallic point. You have to admit that she looked quite beautiful for her age.

"So what's the prob- ah, geez, cover up!" She says, shielding her eyes as she turns around to face you two. Strange. Why does everyone seem to have this reaction? "Pegward, why the hell did you come in here with... I'm married, you know!"

"Sorry," She mumbles in her thick accent, eyes treading downwards. "I kind of ruined her clothes, so... Anyway, I came here 'cause the captain told me to get her checked out. Mind doing it, mate?"

The middle-aged woman slowly retreats her hand from her eyes, though she now looks more upward, as if though only your head comes into her field of view. Slowly, she extends her hand as she speaks, head still positioned the same way as before.

"Ah, hi, it is nice to meet someone as attractive as you. Such a shame that I'm married. My name is Gustavio."

You reach out towards her dainty hand, nearly crushing it. "The pleasure is mine. Pray tell me, are you a physician? I see quite a lot of sophisticated equipment here."

"Physician?!" She recoils, her face scrunching as if though she's hurt. "I am not one of those primitive brutes! My talent goes beyond simple amputations and dental extractions. No, I am a barber surgeon. Here, lie down on this." She grabs you, eyes still averting from your figure, and drags you to the thin mattress, the steps on the wood softly resounding. You lie down, before being promptly covered by a white sheet, thin as a piece of paper. Gustavio becomes visibly relaxed.

"All right. Let me take a look." She says, trotting up to your side while snapping on what appeared to be a pair of gloves. Except, those gloves were of a thin material, and visibly showed her hands underneath them. Quite a peculiar sight to see. "Where does it hurt?"

"The head." You reply, arm pointing directly at the bump, swollen to a large size as it pulsed with the blood flowing through it.

"I see. That is quite a nasty injury. Blunt weapon, probably." She replies, hands carefully prodding over the discolored swelling as if though it was a delicate vase. "I swear, if I find the bastard who would do this to a lady... Anyway, I need to drain the blood from the area. I trust that you are good with that?"

"There is no problem." You see her stretching towards the cylinder with the thin metallic prong on its end. "But are you not going to use leeches or scalpels?"

"Leeches or scalpels? How primitive. It is obvious that I will use a syringe for this."

You feel a slight pinch as something seems to pierce your scalp. A draining sensation washes over, as if though something wave is passing through your body. You feel it stop for a moment, along with a gasp of "Oh, my!", but it quickly resumes and last for a brief few seconds.

"All done." She proudly proclaims, holding up the cylindrical object which was now clearly filled with sloshing red blood - your blood. "Let me rub you with some ointment and you should be good to go."

Her fingers trace your scalp, the cool ointment - apparently made from a variety of herbs, according to her - resting gently on your hand. Your hand traces through your hair, surprised to find that you can feel absolutely nothing. "Absolutely astonishing!"

"Only the best for the very best." The lady bows in a very mannish manner. You wanted have corrected her stance, but there was something that you enjoyed in it. Like a pampered princess, you felt delighted of all this attention thrown to you.

You shudder. When did I start thinking like a girl? You wonder, giving a curt nod in reply.

"Before you go, I would like to ask a series of questions. Why did you come in bare chested?"

"Excuse me if it was inappropriate, but I was soaking wet with seawater." Your gaze shifts to Pegward. "And besides, I have seen your fellows out there with naked breasts. Surely a man can bare his chest once in a while, yes?"

"True. A man surely can. Are you meaning to say you are one?"

You leap to your feet, feeling insulted. "Are you meaning to say I am not?"

"No, no. You do not need to anger. I am simply " She places a palm on your shoulder, forcing you down onto the firm mattress. "I am simply verifying your cognitive capacities. You did take quite a large hit to the head after all."

You nod. That actually made sense. You even feel embarrassed for your outburst.

"Hey, Pegward! She's completely fine now. You can take her to get dressed." She addresses Pegward, who had been standing in the corner attentively looking at you, seemingly worried. How strange. It seems that the entire crew had learnt Tryzantine from one scholar, and every single one of them botched correct pronoun pronunciation. Yet you couldn't help but feel that there was something wrong. Something missing.

-|-|-|-|-


As you walk out of the room, Pegward turns to Gustavio.

"Is she all right, mate?"

"Doubt it. The poor thing took a big hit to the head. Even fancies herself a man, pitiful thing. Listen to me, closely, Edward. Take very good care of her. She's obviously shaken. Any lady would be by this."

"I understand." Pegward guiltily nods his head and trots out the door.

Gustavio sighs, looking at the vial he had deposited the contents of the syringe into. The sloshing red liquid was beautiful, its crimson color staining the glass wall. Without hesitation, he also began walking towards the door.

"And it seems that I must inform the captain of royalty on board."

-|-|-|-|-


Pegward led you out of the shack and into the main cabin. You were wrapped in the "gauze" that the barber surgeon had given you. Why? Who knows, Pegward and Gustavio insisted upon it. You could see numerous empty hammocks swinging, with some of them occupied by sleeping sailors. All girls, of course.

Pegward walks to a particular hammock - seemingly his own - and slides out a large oak chest with a large, unlocked padlock on it.

"The padlock's for decorative purposes." Pegward shrugs, opening the chest. "I trust everyone here. Here, wear this."

You react just in time to catch a cloth. A pink cloth. A pink, gaudy cloth. A pink, gaudy, lacy cloth. A pink, gaudy lacy dress. You unfold it in your arms, staring in shock between the dress and Pegward, as they open in despair.

"You don't mean to give me... this?"

"No need to repay me. It cost me a fortune, and I was saving it for my future marriage, but... I think it would look beautiful on you. And I think the Captain would enjoy it too."

Never mind the fact that she just told you that a dress would look beautiful on you, your heart aches in guilt as you look at it. She was obviously saving it for herself, and yet here you were, taking the most precious thing away from her. A girl and her clothes are inseparable, as your wise father used to say. A sudden idea pops into your wily mind.

"Pray tell, may you not simply hand me your sailor's uniform while wearing this dress instead? I am sure it will go well with your figure."

"You mean... you want me to c-cross... that is completely inappropriate, Miss Ter!"

You nod. A sailor must always be prepared for duty, and wearing a dress would restrict her from that. Yet you know you would definitely look ridiculous in this dress, a shame on your father's legacy. You couldn't wear it, could you?

"I must begin with an apology for the manner of my dress. Your crew were quite insistent." You hold yourself with all the proud bearing you can muster in the pink lacy garment, while at the same time not daring to straighten up too far for fear that your chest will burst out of the tight bodice. The captain's face is red, no doubt with fury. Her posture is rigid, hand clenched on the knob of her door. Her gaze is fixed resolutely at the level of your eyes, eyelid twitching as her attention threatens to waver. "Then I must apologize for the manners of my crew. They dressed you only as they are accustomed to, being ignorant of your ways."

With a guffaw, you exclaim, "you don't mean to say the men of your country dress like this!"

"Not the men but... It's complicated." Luca frowns. "You deserve, and are overdue I suspect, an explanation. Let us talk," she says, stepping aside, barking an order at her crew to return to work as you step inside.

Like the captain herself, the captain's cabin is at first glance an indiscreet display of wealth. Glittering navigation instruments sit upon velvet cushions upon a desk of dark wood. The wall to your right is given over to glass fronted cabinets containing an assortment of maps, trinkets, and trade writs. The left wall contains the captain's bunk. The entirety of the fore wall is a single grand window - thick hexagons of stained glass set in lead, robust enough to endure the waves that crash against them, rhythmically plunging the cabin into emerald darkness.

Yet your eye is more discerning than most, picking out the wear and nicks here and there, the draughty rattle of several of the window panes, signs of fading wealth. Not to mention the dozen or so wooden crates of trade goods that have been wedged in here between the furniture. Only a desperate merchant would sacrifice the comfort of her own cabin to squeeze a little extra gold out of a voyage.

A small stove warms the cabin, a copper kettle whistling away atop it. "Tea?" Captain Luca asks, seating herself at her desk. You nod.

She sets you out a fine (if somewhat chipped) china cup only a little larger than a shot glass and pours you a helping of the brew before filling herself a larger mug. She takes a large swallow with a wince, smacking her lips. You take a sip. For tea, it has a remarkable kick to it, enough to bring tears to your eyes.

"What an interesting blend," you cough.

"Enough to knock the hairs off your chest," Luca remarks. She hesitates for a moment before pouring you another cup. "I trust you can handle your tea?"

Bristling a little, you retort, "My lady, I am the most experienced connoisseur outside of Hashaan. Nearly a fifth of all the tea consumed by Tryzantium passes through my warehouses, I think I can drink a cup or two." You knock back the second glass, spluttering as it seems to sear the back of your throat like whisky. It is certainly unlike any you've consumed before, and rather than invigorating you it sets your head spinning.

As you work your way through a third serving, you notice her studying you over the top of her mug, eyebrows furrowed. Setting aside your cup, you say, "I see my presence on your ship bothers you almost as much as it bothers me. Unsurprising, since your crew is entirely female. You must be thinking of me as like a cat among the pigeons."

"More like a pigeon among the cats. Or a cat among other cats. Whatever you are, it will not bode well for discipline," she grumbles.

"Excellent! Then you will think nothing of returning me to port!"

"I cannot."

"Why-ever not! I am a wealthy man; I must attend to my business.."

"A number of reasons. Firstly, we are a day out of port on an excellent wind; it would take three times as long to crawl back and there is no guarantee how long this favourable weather will last. Much of my cargo is perishable and I cannot afford the delay.

Perhaps the tea has gone to your head, as you reply somewhat curtly, "What part of 'I am a wealthy man' did you not understand? Whatever it will cost you, I will make it worth your while."

"Secondly I have reason to believe your life would be in danger from a murderous cut-throat known as Casario should you return-"

"Never heard of him!"

"-and thirdly because I swore on my honour to the very same cut-throat that I would see you safely to Versiland, a promise I intend to keep."

You raise an eyebrow. "You venturer to Versiland? What a strange coincidence, my bride-to-be-"

"-comes from there? Yes, I thought he might." She looks at you with pity. "I'm sorry to say you've been the victim of a pair of con-artists, men who have seduced and slaughtered their way to infamy and fortune, and only through your sheer luck and-" For a second her eyes flit down to your bare chest. "-charms have you come away unscathed. As I said before, you are deserving of an explanation. How best to explain... Would you like it told to you long or short?"

While a man could garner greater respect from the sailors, they would also be less inclined to the innate tendencies of protectiveness and courtesy around you, and you have heard the tales of what men can get up to with other men on these long sea voyages, even entire crews succumbing to their unsatisfied lusts at a time. The vulnerability of your position is starting to become apparent. Surrounded by nothing but hundreds of miles of open ocean and several dozen sex-starved men, things could turn ugly for you very quickly.

"Most believe you to be a versiland woman. There are only a few of my crew who know of the peculiarities of the top-sider's anatomy, and for good reason. On my last voyage here, there was a mutiny. I had docked at Lightgarde and allowed my men to go ashore as repairs were being made. There, my men found themselves pursued and propositioned relentlessly by your men, wooed and bedded, not that there has ever been difficultly in seducing a seaman. It is a joke of the gods perhaps that, despite our physical incompatibility, the men of our different countries are more perfect bedfellows in their temperament and appetites then the men and women of our own countries.

"In the short few days on land, they experienced erotic delights few men can ever dream of. Once they were summoned back to the ship, the men became rowdy and the mood soured. They wanted to stay to be pampered and gratified for the rest of their days. My rash attempts to quell the men by insulting their manhoods for lying with foreign men only angered them further, until they become mutinous. They attacked me and the few who had enough to lose back home to stand with me."

"Good heavens. And yet you survived and reclaimed your ship. How?"

"Though very little action of my own. There was a stowaway aboard my ship, Lothanova, a young lad that slipped aboard in Versiland and who I had allowed to stay so long as he worked. For whatever reason, perhaps just an excuse to murder as many as he could, he took my side and killed the leader of the mutineers. The rest fled or were captured and thrown in the brig, and I limped back home with a third of my crew remaining. I made certain that those who replaced them were kept in the dark about the topsider's secrets and that there would be no shore leave."

Spotting an opening, you say, "Then you yourself concede that my presence here invites mutiny. The truth cannot be hidden for long and once it is, they will try to turn this ship about."

"Perhaps. Perhaps not." The Captain rises and steps to the grand window that looks out over the water. For all it's backwards layout, the ship at least affords the captain an excellent view of what lies ahead. As the froth of the last wave spills down the glass panels, he stares intently towards the horizon. "It matters little, for in a few hours we will sail beyond the circle of islands known as the World's Teeth and beyond that we will be held fast by the powerful currents of the Maw."

"The Maw!" you exclaim. "Have you gone mad? That's suicide. No ship returns from the Maw!"

"Dangerous, yes. Suicide, no. A skilled captain with experience may pass through it, for the Maw is a drainage channel from one side of the world to the other. I suspect the main reason no ship returns from the other side is for the same reason my ship almost didn't - because no crew wants to."

The Maw is a whirlpool in the sea dozens of miles wide. It's currents flow as fast as a river. Over the captain's shoulder, way off on the horizon, stands the jagged triangular rock of one of the Teeth. If the ship reaches that, there will be no returning home...

1511.content:
The feast is over. The guests flee. With the palace in chaos, you slip away into the King's solar to compose and clean yourself. The screams of noble women still echo down the corridor, but they seem distant as you scrub at the gore that congeals on your arms. The small handbasin soon runs red, though your hands still drip with royal blood. It had been a messy business. For a child, the King had had a lot of blood in him.

For the last few years, you'd watched as your King became someone you barely recognised. As he'd aged and his health had begun to fail, and his children and siblings and lords had begun to squable and scheme and divide up the Kingdom even while he still lived, he became gripped with an obsession - to live and rule forever. It had been an obsession, you regret to say now, that you had facilitated as the monarch's advisor of magic and in the interest of the future stability of the Kingdom. It had been you who personally got in touch with the Fey.

The Fey delegation arrived. They presented their offer to the King, and he sent them packing. But the Fey, being timeless creatures, are patient. When the King lay on his death bed, they returned .The King would receive their boon - eternal, undying youth - and in return, the elven forests would be allowed to spread, unchallenged, into human lands. This time, he accepted. His decrepit body was renewed into that of a healthy, young child.

In just a few months, the wilderness swallowed up nearly a third of Tryzantinium, and the oncoming winter showed no sign of slowing it down. In places, the elven borders spread faster than people could flee. Those trapped by the encroachment were transformed into mindless beasts or worse. Swiftly and efficiently, the new forests were dividing the human kingdom up into neat parcels of land, cutting them off from the capital before engulfing them.

Everyone could see it was an extermination. The King's advisers beseached him to break his bargain. In reply, the King had them hung. To break the deal would be to kill the king, and to suggest such a thing was treason. For with his childlike body had come a new personality; petulent, wanton, and cruel, like a child, but with the mind and appetites of a grown man. As the forests encroached around Lightgarde, the refugees began to flood in. The King, terrified of angering the Fey, executed anyone who resisted the wilderness. His sons fled, fearing his madness.

You should have acted sooner, made an end to the mistake you'd first made in involving the Fey, yet you didn't, partly out of concern for your family but your own skin too. Outside the King's protection, both the magi and the church would hunt you to the ends of the world. So you waited, hoping somebody else would act.

This evening the court had sat down to feast. As one of his last remaining advisers, you were seated at the King's table, even helping the childlike sovereign up into his chair now that it was too big for him. A prisoner had been carried in for judgement, naked except for chains. Johan Sellwin. He had been a Baron and a man once, until the forests had taken his land and most of his humanity. The short, red fur that covered his body was scorched in places by the fire they had used to burn their way out. His tail quivered between his legs as he begged for his life.

The King's mood darkened as he listened to the beast's pleas. When Johan ventured that aid be sent to recover his holdings, the King flew into a rage. "Skin him! I want his pelt! His family too!"

With a sudden sense of inevitability, you took a carving knife and drove it through the King's heart.

A group of armoured guards rattle down the corridor outside, bringing you back to the here and now, causing you to glance up at the door you forgot to lock. They're hunting for you. They pass by, but the odd sense of light-headed detachment you felt since killing the King begins to fade. Now you must focus on getting yourself and your family as far away as possible.

Before you could move, with five pops of displaced air, the council of Magi appeared in the room, surrounding you. Everything went black.
...
...
...
"Why is he just standing there with his eyes closed?"

"He thinks we're here to kill him."

"Kill him? Hah! I'm here to shake his hand," the Crimson Magus exclaims, thrusting his hot, leathery palm into yours. "I've never shaken hands with a Kingslayer before. What an honour! The way you set him up, earned his trust all those years, then tricking him into the body of a defenseless child. You, sir, are an inspiration. Though a little preemptive moving in, I might say," he said, gesturing around the solar. "You're not King yet."

You pull your hand free. "I wasn't planning on killing him. I didn't plan any of this! And I certainly don't want to be King."

"Actually that is something we must insist on," the Light Magus says, drifting forward. "There's never been a wizard sit the throne before. Such an arrangement would benefit us."

"You want to put me on the throne?"

"Yes. It may be the only way to save this Kingdom."

"It'll never work," you shake your head. "The Church will never go along with it. Nor the nobles."

"True," the Magus nodded. "However..."

The mountains themselves are home to the Draconians and what remains of the Dwarves.
To the south is the vast, hot continent of Nagra, covered in arid plains and teaming jungles, home to the Nagrandii.
Dotted all over the place are the Elven Forests. Elves are generally isolationist and non-aggressive unless pushed, but have been becoming increasingly belligerent with the weakening of humanity.
Underneath all of this is the Underworld, a vast network of caverns and tunnels home to many undiscovered races. The Dwarves have recently been pushed out of their underground cities by the Vorelves, corrupted, carnivorous Elves.
Parallel to all of this is the Demon netherworld, a parasitic dimension sometimes referred to as Hell. Demons feed off the mortal races, and sow discord among them in the way a farmer sows oats.

Technology has remained at a vaguely medieval level for thousands of years thanks to a pervasive anti-technology field that blankets the entire world, causing the workings of advanced technology to malfunction and fade from memory. Certain areas have managed to advance to a level comparative to 21st century Earth however. Fashion design continues to invent, driven forward primarily by elven fashion scientists, and has long since discovered both the zipper and exciting underwear.

The world has three moons: A red one, a white, and a black one.

1553311.content:
29-3BCE (Before Circean Era)
Harald, the inbred King of Tryzantium, descends into madness and paranoia. Many lords take the opportunity to stake their independence from the tyrannical ruler, and the once mighty Kingdom of Tryzantium fragments. By 3BCE, it is a shadow of its former glory.

13 BCE
Prince Ivar of Tryzantine is born to King Harald the Mad.

3BCE
Janus Meade is born.'

0CE (Circean Era)'
Circe Sunstorm, already a living Saint of the church, dies in defence of the Grey Gate against the Elemental Chaos. She holds the Gate for three days until reinforcements arrive, fighting not only with the blessings of the Goddess but also the powers of a sorcerer, which she has concealed and suppressed all her life.
With the arrival of the human armies, she uses the last of her energy to transfigure the warriors into powerful bestial forms, allowing them to win the war against the Elemental Chaos.'
Circe is regarded as a martyr and a new era, The Circean Era, is begun in her honour.'

1CE
The veterans of the War of the Grey Gate return home. Though expecting to be welcomed as heroes, many face prejudice or enslavement for their transfigured forms.'
In light of the heroism of Saint Circe, the church ceases its persecution of female magic practitioners. Concerned that the church is on the verge of welcoming wizards into its ranks, vastly bolstering its power, the Magi open the colleges to female wizards for the first time.'

2CE
King Harald the Mad launches his war of reconquest against his lost lands. He suffers a series of humiliating defeats before being captured and beheaded. Ivar is crowned and continues his father's campaign, quickly proving himself a capable but ruthless leader. He offers special dispensation to all non-humans that fight with him. Many of the Grey Gate veterans flock to his side.

3CE
Orc warlocks attempting to emulate human wizardry accidentally unleash a portal storm across their lands, through which the infinite hordes of hell begin to invade.'

4CE
A beautiful, mysterious woman by the name Cl'ona arrives in Ivar's court. Though she offers no proof of a noble lineage, her beautify, manners, and charisma entrance the young King. They are soon wed, and their union is a loving, passionate one.

6CE
After many years of fighting, the Tryzantine Reconquest ends with Tryzantium having taken back most of its lost lands. All combatants are granted full rights as citizens, much to the dismay of many lords. Ivar continues to fight minor uprisings from angry vassals for the rest of his reign.'

9CE
The Orcs continue to fight their hopeless battle against the infinite hordes of hell. The idea that they might be losing finally penetrates their thick, collective skull and they flee (or at least fight backwards) into the Kingdom of Horr. The peaceful Horrians are outmatched and, in a last hope, activate the Sceptre of Horr, blasting apart their lands and transforming the male population into half-demon succubi that fight off the Orcs. The women of Horr are cast out, and form the Horrian Remnant in Tryzantium lands.
With the need to house the refugees, attempts are made to reclaim many of the old settlements taken by the wilderness, with promises of financial and military aid for the settlers. This reclamation project is swiftly forgotten, leaving the remote settlements to fend for themselves.'

11CE
Janus enlisted into the Study of magic. The Philosphers' Stones are stolen by goblins in his first year, and the Tryzantine economy crashes shortly after as vast quantities of counterfeit gold begins to pour in.'

12CE
An obsidian meteorite impacts in Hashian lands, throwing a cloud of activated obsidian into the air, inducing the Great Shift. The strict caste system crumbles as the Hashians are bodyswitched at random.

14CE
Despite many years of marriage, Queen Cliona has yet to bear the King a child. Upon inspection by a physician, the reason becomes apparent - Cliona is in fact an elf, and a male one at that, his true gender hidden by glamour. Ten years prior, he had been ordered to infiltrate Ivar's court and assassinate him before he could unite the humans, though fell madly in love with his intended target.
Ivar kills the physician, the physician's assistant, and Cliona. The dead Queen is stricken from all records, and the merest mention of her in the presence of the King is a death sentence. Ivar sinks into a deep depression that lasts many years, and his attitude towards non-human races sours considerably.

18CE
Janus graduates to journeyman wizard.'

27CE
Janus leaves the service of the magi to start a new life as an adventurer, becoming a deserter and fugitive in the process. Though he has many heroic deeds, he also develops an extensive criminal record and is eventually thrown in jail to be hung.

47CE
A group of infamous adventurers including Janus are recruited to steal back the philosophers' stones, on the promise that their criminal past be wiped clean should they succeed. Against all odds, they do and Janus is pardoned for desertion. He becomes an independent wizard, court advisor to the King on all things arcane, and a shrewd businessman.

1553322.content:
Once the most powerful species, the human races have lost much over the past hundred years, weakened by a series of cataclysms and in the case of Tryzantium, a procession of corrupt, ineffectual, and/or insane monarchs and an infighting nobility.

Kingdom of Tryzantium
The Kingdom lays claim to the verdant central plains, an area of rolling hills and lush woodland, with hot summers, mild winters, and an abundance of rain in between. The hub city of Sentral sits at the heart of the kingdom, thriving even as the borderlands fall to wrack and ruin. Built beside the great river Sene and upon a confluence of leylines, it is headquarters to the monarchy, the Faith, and the Colleges of Magic.

The holy armies armies of the Faith and the ranks of human spellcasters fight to keep back the enemies of mankind and the wilderness that encroaches further every day. Despite their valiant efforts, the greatest human kingdom is failing and fracturing. Many of the barons expected to swear fealty to the king have begun to revolt under the weak monarchy, in addition many wizards, warlords, and mercenary groups have tried to carve out their own areas. These uprisings have severely depleted the military needed to defend the borders.

The Hashaan
An isolationist race of humanity from the far East. Their strict caste system now faces imminent collapse following an incident of mass bodyswitching that encompassed their entire civilization, an event that came to be known as the Great Shift. They are now beset by civil war and anarchy.

In recent years, a meteorite of obsidian collided with the continent, blasting clouds of activated obsidian into the air that enveloped the lands of the Hashaan, swapping the souls of every man, woman, and child. The change tore apart their ancient caste system, sparking a civil war between those who would reaffirm or destroy the old system according to whether it would benefit them in their new bodies. Those once-powerful individuals who now find themselves as women, children, or a member of a lower caste desperately rebel against those now in power, while a third faction attempts to do away with the caste system altogether.

Horrian Remnant
The female refugees of the destroyed Kingdom of Horr, cast out when the male Horrians were warped into demonic warrior women.

Nagrandi
The dark-skinned Nagrandi hail from the arid, southern continent of Nagrand. They worship more gods than can be counted.

Steppe Nomads
Horse-riding nomads that live on the north-eastern steppes.
They have fought an all-out war with the local centaur clans for the last century, a conflict which began following a minor skirmish, when the nomads coaxed their horses to mount the centaur women of their beaten enemies, an unforgivable act which forever united the clans against the nomads.
The nomads are reviled by all settled people due to their endless raiding.
1553322.title: Humanity

15533221.content:
The talent for wizardry is rare in humans, occurring in roughly 1/666th of the population. Nonetheless, an experienced, fully-trained spell-caster can be the equal of an army - as such they are a resource tightly controlled by the government, the Church, and the Council of powerful Magi that oversee the development and deployment of all magic-users. Trained to fight and die defending humanity, wizardry is as much a military discipline as it is academic.

The study of magic as performed by humans and semi-humans, often referred to simply as The Order, is split into five sub-orders of Colleges. The most powerful individuals of each Order make up the Council of Five Magi. The Council constantly struggles to keep the lesser magic-users in check, and will mercilessly quash any signs of dissent.

The Five Orders
College of the Crimson Order
Study the Lore of Pyromancy and Demonology. Can conjure fire and summon demons.
A demon that has been summoned into the world must first be shackled and bound before it can be of use, lest it run amok. The Crimson College often holds elaborate parties where it's students practice their acts of bondage on lesser demons, serving girls, and each other, involving judicious application of leather and extracted, processed tree sap. The other Colleges are never invited, much to their chagrin.
Wear robes of red and black.

College of the Golden Order
Study the Lore of Alchemy. Can transmute objects and are master craftsmen of enchanted items. Can transmute themselves into a combat form of living metal.
Wear yellow robes often singed, sooty and stained from their study.

College of the Jade Order
Study the Lore of Life and Beasts. Are wizards most attuned to nature. Have power over nature and can summon thorns and briars out of the earth to attack their enemies, command beasts, or call on elemental powers to aid them.
Jade wizards are masters of shape-shifting, taking on animals forms for combat or travel. However, a transformed wizard will always have a distinguishing trait that they carry with them through all their forms, be it a birth-mark, eye colour, or their human voice.
The colour of their robes is green.

College of the Grey Order
Study the Lore of Necromancy and Vicissitude. Can reanimate corpses and cast curses of decay. Vicissitude resembles orcish fleshcrafting, granting the user power over flesh and bone, molding it like a sculptor molds clay. They can use these powers to fix bones and repair wounds.
Grey wizards are granted two forms: a monstrous form which is generally used in combat, as well as a blood form, which turns the user into a mobile pool of blood.
The colour of their robes is dark grey. It helps hide the stains.

College of the Light Order
Study the Lore of Souls. Capable of manipulating the very minds of beings - befuddling them, changing them, even extracting them entirely. Light wizards can move souls from one body or vessel to another, and as they age the most powerful of their Order are awarded the honour of transferring their souls to a younger body.
Are exceptionally dangerous and deceptive, but regarded favourably among the common folk simply because they wear robes of pure white and often cast illusions of great beauty on themselves.

Wizard's Toll
"Power corrupts. Magical power corrupts magically. "
- Albert Einstein

Although wizards are functionally immortal (but age slowly and can be killed), the continuing practice of magic exacts a payment on the body and mind. With every spell cast, a wizard becomes degraded somehow, less-human, eventually reaching a stage of inhumanity where they must be hidden from society or euthanized. The speed of deterioration can take as long as several centuries or as short as mere minutes, depending on a number of factors.
Each wizard's Toll manifests differently, but the Orders tend to progress along similar lines:

Crimson Order: The wizard gradually takes on a demonic appearance. Their behaviour grows increasingly depraved as their moral sensibilities decay. Ultimately they resemble nothing more than natural demons (in so much that a demon can be called natural) in both body and mind, and are often Bound by other Crimson Order wizards once they become a danger to themselves and others. Many, mistaken for demons, are simply banished to hell.
Golden Order: Their flesh is progressively replaced by metal or mineral, and over time they resemble sculpture or machinery more and more. While often still animated, their sense of self erodes to the point will not act unless directly ordered to or operated by somebody else.
Jade Order: As their Toll progresses, Jade Order wizards grow distant to human affairs and closer to nature. They spend longer and longer periods in their animal or plant forms. Ultimately, the distinguishing trademark that each wizard carries between forms disappears, marking the point when the human form and mind is irretrievably lost.
Grey Order: The body gradually takes on the appearance of a walking corpse. The wizard develops a desperate hunger to feel the warmth of life once again, manifesting in several possible ways, not worst of which is cannibalism. In the final stages, the blood clots in the veins, the flesh begins to rot and drop off the bones, and the wizard is humanely incinerated.
Light Order: The wizard's physical form fades away, until only their spiritual essence remains. As the toll progresses and their hold on the physical world weakens, their attunement with magic increases but so does their vulnerability to obsidian. Light order wizards risk being drained inside obsidian or other soul-catchers, their soul trapped inside the rock forever in an existence worse than death. To protect themselves against this, a Light wizard will often attempt to secure themselves to the physical world by binding their soul to an item, animal, or human, or transferring it entirely to a new host.

Sorcerer
Sorcerers are a rare type of wizard able to cast the spells of all five Orders. Sorcerers are always the seventh son of a seventh son, though not all seventh sons of seventh sons are sorcerers.
While they have almost limitless potential, Sorcerers rarely achieve greatness. Lacking a strong allegiance to any particular College, they are seldom given entry to any of the inner sanctums, where each Order's most powerful and secret spells are kept.
Additionally, the Magi work personally to curtail the training of Sorcerers, as a master of all five Orders would be a dangerous rival to even their combined power.

Familiars
Magic-users often keep animal companions, otherwise known as familiars, that have been magically bonded to them in a process called familiarization. Familiars absorb a fraction of their master's Toll, suffering the same deleterious effects and helping to extend the wizard's lifespan.
Additionally if the familiar is a magical creature, its master is able to perform any spell or ability the familiar knows. This rule applies even to shape-shifted wizards. For example, if a Crimson Order wizard were to familiarize a Jade Order wizard in the form of an animal, he would gain access to any and all spells known by the Jade wizard.
Despite the Magi's attempts to outlaw the taking of other spellcasters as familiars, very few wizards will baulk at the opportunity to familiarize a sorcerer, as doing so would give them access to the spells of all five Orders.

Female wizards
The acceptance of female wizards is a recent development, brought about only by the desperate need for spellcasters in these dark and troubled times. Change is slow to be accepted by the long-lived, stubborn-natured wizards, and many wish to return to the old ways, where any woman found practicing magic would be bound, burnt, familiarized or worse.
The forbidden, female-only study of witchcraft, a different branch of magic altogether, is still very much alive and persecuted brutally by the wizards, as it has been for thousands of years.

Binding
If a Wizard fails training, or is expelled, or goes rogue and is caught, they may be Bound. Obsidian manacles are affixed to the wizard's arms, legs and neck, and siphon away his or her powers until they are gone.
Binding is also the most effective way of a rogue wizard avoiding detection.

Enchanted items
A spellcaster may enchant an item, such as a wand or sword, giving it certain attributes or allowing it to performing a spell on command. While the initial Toll cost of creating such an item is much higher than casting the spell once, the benefit of an enchanted item is it can cast the same spell an unlimited number of times without accruing any further Toll. Because of this, most spellcasters enchant items with spells that they use frequently.
Enchanted items can be used by anybody, regardless of magical talent, and many are now in the hands of collectors.

Anti-magic

Witch-hunters
The rules governing the study and practice of magic are strict, and deserters are not uncommon. Many wizards go rogue, seeing the crumbling of the empire as an opportunity to claim personal power, and seek to establish their own towers and territories out on the borderlands.
Witch-hunters are men and women whose bodies have been fused with obsidian weaponry and augmented with clockwork prosthesis, allowing them to hunt down and kill rogue magic-users. The exact details of their creation and the extent of their capabilities are unknown; as such they are greatly feared.

Untouchables
Almost as rare as wizards, Untouchables are individuals who are supremely magically ungifted, meaning they cannot be affected by any spell. Their immunity to magic is a characteristic much desired by the Study, who employ them to keep a watchful eye on the students.

Hashaan assassins utilise a unique form of shadow magic. They are masters of disguise, deception, and misdirection. They swear allegiance to a feudal lord, acting as assassins, thieves and spies.

Assassins have an array of mystical abilities, though it is not easy to separate fact from fearful rumours. It is said that they can merge with shadows, walk up walls and float on night winds.

1553322111.content:
The Church of the Triune Goddess

Though many illegal cults exist within its borders, the official state religion of the Kingdom of Tryzantium is the worship of the Camenae. It worships a single powerful Goddess, the All-Mother, Camanae, creator of the world and mankind, who is a triune godhead composed of three aspects - The Maiden, The Mother, and The Crone. The Goddess is often prayed to by her Individual aspects ('Mother protect me', 'Crone guide me') or as a whole, often referred to as Carmen in her singular form.

As much matriarchal as the Orders of Magic are patriarchal, the Church is led almost exclusively by women. It extols what it regards to be feminine virtues: purity, peace, and the power of creation. While not misandrist per se, the church holds that men are imperfect souls, in need of guidance, created to serve, fight, and die for the glory of women and that, through religious worship and sacrifice, devout men might be purified and reborn in the next life as women, perfect souls. Men are regarded as pitiable, innately sinful creatures, useful yet disposable.

Despite its alleged mission of peace, the Camenae church is capable of fielding vast armies and has an ancient, bloody relationship with magic users and the nation of Ordania that continues to this day.

The Goddess' holy fire is a entrancing gold-and-pink flame.

The Goddess is not above rewarding good behaviour, bestowing holy blessings on its most faithful.
Armour of the Goddess - the worshiper's body becomes wreathed in holy flame, which will block all demonic and magic assaults and deflect most physical attacks. The fire may be thrown offensively. It will however, burn through any clothing and turn armour to bubbling slag, necessitating that the worshiper live their life naked.
Aegis Wings - the devout sprouts a pair of angelic wings. They are large enough to envelop themselves and others, shielding them from harm. In addition, they can fly.
Halo of Judgement - the worshiper's head is surrounded by radiant light, granting them the ability to read thoughts and see past sins.
Glorious Aureola - not to be confused with glorious areola. The believer's body is surrounded by a luminous cloud. People close to the devout experience feelings of spiritual ecstasy and can be motivated to commit acts of great personal sacrifice.

Mirroring their Goddess, their ranks are split in three - maidens, mothers, and crones. Maidens are those that work in the field, often fighting on the front lines. Mothers are involved in day to day running of the church, tending to the flocks and dispensing justice where needed. Crones maintain the archives of the church, and tend to the dead.

Ranks
Mother Supreme
Mother Superior
Grand Great Mother
Great Mother
Mother
Sword Maidens
1553322111.title: Tryzantium: Church of the Triune Goddess

15533221112.content:
The Uncounted Gods

On the continent of Nagra, the Nagrandians worship thousands of Gods. Unlike the all-encompassing, powerful nature of the Triune Goddess, these deities are small gods, little more than powerful spirits that dwell within idols, totems, masks or fetishes and embody some aspect of their worshipers' lives. There are gods of cleaning, gods of the water well, hearth gods of making bread, even specific gods for which animal one might wish to hunt that day. One wonders how they keep track of them all!

At times of crisis or during special celebrations, these spirit may be called upon or may itself choose a mortal vessel in which to inhabit, so that they might dwell within flesh-and-blood, and walk among their mortal followers. During this time, they might be compelled to perform acts according to their role. The human vessel in which they dwell may undergo significant remodeling during this time in order to fit its role.

These Gods are the figures around which their society structures itself, with each individual clan or faction giving fealty to one or many gods.

Remarkably, this system is rather democratic. Should the worshipers find their deity to be lacking in the performance of its duties, they may decide to have it removed from power. If this passes, the spirit is "emptied out", its soul forcible extracted from its spirit form, leaving only the mindless shell of its power. Candidates wishing to fill the role of the god may then step forward and, should they be worthy, their soul is transferred into the God-shell, and they gain all the powers and responsibilities that come with it.

The Church of the Triune Goddess has sought to get their hands on an example of one of these God-shells for centuries, so that they might transfer the souls of one of their faithful into the Nagrandian god's form and from there influence the worship of the heathens towards the worship of Camenae.

The Orders of Magic have also desired to acquire such a thing, primarily as they have always been rejected by the gods for their arcane practices, and would like to create their own divine ally.
15533221112.title: Nagrandian Gods - the Uncounted Gods

15533221113.content:
In the way that many versian things resemble their mundane counterpart, the versian god known as The Triumvirate or the All-Father mirrors the Triune Goddess in many ways. When physically manifest, He bears a striking resemblance to Camenae's divinely feminine form, almost identical in fact save for His manner of dress, His swaggering masculine presence, and the majestic cock that hands proudly between His curvaceous thighs.

Like the Triune Goddess, The Triumvirate is composed of three aspects: the Youth, The Sire, and The Sage, each part embody a part of a man's life. Though each form a singular being, they often appear to act independently and are often prayed to individually - 'Sire guard me', 'Sage teach me'.

The Youth
Seen as the virginal young man, or boy, who has not yet awakened into manhood. He embodies adventurousness, ambition and new beginnings, youthful ideas and enthusiasm. To a Tryzantium local, He resembles a young, pretty maiden, though one strangely sporting a bust lip and bruised knuckles, with a cocksure air. At times he wields a wooden sword - a toy, but one capable of ending any who might laugh at this 'girl'-playing-as-a-warrior. At other times he wears the paychwork armour and second-hand weaponry of a young warrior being sent away to their first battle.

The Sire
The next phase in a man's life, The Sire embodies virility and conquest, consolidated power and authority, and the gaining of knowledge. Though a symbol of idealised manhood to the Versi, to a Tryzantium local He would resemble a haughty amazonian woman in her prime years, garbed in full plate armour and wielding a huge double-headed battleaxe that she hopefully won't cut herself with. He is large breasted and broad hipped, though in truth the broad hips exist to make room for the massive, meaty versian dick that sits between his legs.

Virile and amorous, tales are told of the many times he has shapeshifted into alluring forms to seduce his conquests. He is said to be able to impregnate anyone and anything, and his children are beyond counting.

The Sage
The Sage embodies the final stage of a man's life. He is a wise man, representing knowledge, darkness and eventually death. He has lived her life to the fullest and has gained the knowledge of a lifetime. He is there to guide the Youth and advise The Sire when He needs it. He is the waning moon, the chill of winter, the dying of the land.

He resembles an old woman, often robed and hooded, clutching a tome of ancient lore or staff.
15533221113.title: Versi Gods - The Triumvirate

1553322112.title: People

155332212.content:
In wizardry, spells can be channeled through either a verbal incantation or a physical motion (such as a gesture of the hand), or through a wand or staff. Wands are able to channel spells directly, bypassing physical and verbal components and conjuring the spell direct from the wizard's mind. This is vital for when a wizard is indisposed to speak or perform the intricate motions required for a spell, such as when in an animal form.

Without a wand at hand, a wizard runs the risk of becoming trapped in a form and will often secret their wand into a safe place before transforming, ensuring their ability to transform themselves back into human form.

Wands and staffs also help in aiming projectile spells, such as fireballs, and to hide the spellcaster's intent from their opponents.

Wands and staffs can be enchanted like any other item, and owners will often equip them with basic,commonly-used offensive spells, such as the standard fireball.

In addition to channeling, some spells require components that must be met in order to be cast. These may be as simple as an ingredient, such as eye of newt, that is consumed upon casting. Some are more complex. For example, the reverse self-transmutation used by Gold Order wizards to transform from an inanimate form to their human form requires them to be in contact with human flesh upon casting, and additionally they must be in possession of 100% of their body. The loss of an arm for example, will make them unable to revert until their arm is recovered.

While most Orders have their own set of spells castable only by themselves and sorcerers, there are a number of spells common to all Orders:

Common Pool Spellls

Low level spells
Invisible hand - allows you to manipulate objects from a distance with unseen forces.
Erase - removes writings of either magical or mundane nature from a target, erasing Symbols, Runes, and Sigils.
Tongues - this spell grants the creature touched the ability to speak and understand the language of any intelligent creature, whether it is a racial tongue or a regional dialect. The subject can speak only one language at a time, although it may be able to understand several languages. Tongues does not enable the subject to speak with creatures who don’t speak. The subject can make itself understood as far as its voice carries. This spell does not predispose any creature addressed toward the subject in any way. Tongues can be made permanent with a permanency spell.

Mid level spells
Familiarization - a spell that binds an animal to the wizard. The animal becomes the wizard's new familiar, sharing in its Master's toll and surrendering any magic ability it has.
Symbol of Silence - When scribed on an object or person, a Symbol of Silence mutes any noise the target makes. A wizard affected in this way is unable to cast spells with vocal components.

High level spells
Splice - fuses any two creatures or things. The outcome of fusion depends on the ability of the caster, though many result in abominations with (fortunately) short lifespans.
Permanency - This spell makes certain other spells permanent.
155332212.title: Wizard spells

1553322121.content:
The Crimson Order studies the lores of Pyromancy and Demonology. Formidable in battle through their mastery over fire, their combat capabilities are enhanced by their ability to summon demonic minions.

Pyromancy
A Crimson wizard can create, grow, and mould fire into whatever shape or size they desire through a simple act of willpower. They can turn the smallest spark into an all-consuming conflagration or create terrifying beasts of flame that chase down their opponents and sow terror into the most stalwart of armies.
Manipulating fire comes at a cost; the fuel that sustains the magic fire comes directly from the wizard's body, drawn from their own energy reserves. Overexertion in the use of pyromancy can leave the wizard physically exhausted and emaciated.
This energy usage encourages wizards to stock up on this 'fuel' by building fat reserves. Master pyromancers are well known for their great girth, and often have to be carried into battle on litters.

Demonology
Summoning a demon, especially for the first time, is a dangerous and difficult procedure. A demon's physical form must be shackled and bound to anchor them to this world. Additionally the allegiance of the demon must be gained lest it wreak untold destruction. The easiest means of doing so is by entering into a pact with the creature, receiving its temporary servitude in exchange for something offered by the wizard, usually in the form of sustenance whether that be blood, flesh, or souls. So long as the wizard maintains his side of the bargain, demons are physically incapable of breaking the terms of the agreement.

Alternatively a demon can be dominated, its mental defenses beaten down through pleasure and pain. Once broken, a demon may be cajoled into forming pacts that it otherwise would never make; i.e. offering its servitude to its master eternally in exchange for nothing.

To this end, Crimson wizards are experienced in the application of pleasure and pain through torture and (usually) sex. As such these wizards are allowed to live relatively unhindered lifestyles, freely practicing their arts of ecstasy, torture, dominance, and submission. They are not required to submit to the libido-sapping effects of the lech. In order to further their study, crimson wizards are expected to spend at least one year as the opposite sex, jokingly referred to as a 'gap year' by male wizards.

The Crimson College frequently holds great masked balls where it's students may practice their acts of bondage on lesser demons, serving girls, and each other.

They wear robes of red and black.

Fireball - a basic fireball spell
Invoke minor demon - can summon imps, gremlins, and hobgoblins
Invoke demon - summons a demon of average power.
Invoke archdemon - summons a powerful demon to beat people up for you.
Pleasure - the wizard's touch induces sensations of great ecstasy.
Pain - the wizard's touch induces sensations of unbearable agony.
Demon form - the wizard adopts the physical manifestation of a summoned demon as his or her own, gaining its appearance, attributes and powers.
Shadow assassin - A spell used by female wizards. Following sexual intercourse, a female wizard can induce an accelerated pregnancy resulting in the birth a creature of shadow. This "shadow baby" resembles the "father" and will perform a single task, including assassination, without fail, before fading away.
Hell jumping/ Fel walking - temporarily shifts you into the demon's netherworld before bringing you back. Due to spatial differences in the dimensions, moving only a short distance in the netherworld will cause you to have covered a large distance once returned to the real world, making this a very efficient way to travel, except for the hordes of soul-consuming demons that lurk on the other side. Statistically speaking, is still the most dangerous way to travel.
Summon portal portal - produces a stable portal to the demon netherworld, allowing unlimited two-way travel between realms. Generally not advisable.
Invoke Djinn - summons a demon lord of near limitless, reality-bending power. In return, the wizard's soul is cast into the deepest circle of hell to suffer in infinite agony. The wizard's body is transmuted into a vessel for the demon, often something small and innocuous like a box or lamp. The Djinn can be commanded by anyone holding its vessel to do almost anything. However, while it must obey, it is a cunning and deeply malevolent entity and will attempt to twist and pervert any command it is given. In effect, only the truly insane have ever performed this spell and few Djinn vessels exist. While Djinn may be given unlimited commands, nobody has ever made it past three wishes with their mind or body intact.

Toll
With the progression of the toll, the wizard's behaviour grows increasingly depraved as their moral sensibilities decay. They tend to gravitate towards one or more of the Six Sins: Lust, Greed, Gluttony, Sloth, Wrath, and Pride.
In addition, the wizard gradually takes on a demonic appearance. Ultimately they resemble nothing more than natural demons (in so much that a demon can be called natural) in both body and mind, and are often Bound by other Crimson Order wizards once they become a danger to themselves and others. Many, mistaken for demons, are simply banished to hell.

College
1553322121.title: The Crimson Order

15533221211.content:
The Gold Order study the Lore of Alchemy. The physical laws that govern the universe bend to their will, allowing them to transmute objects, themselves, and manipulate metal in much the same way that pyromancers manipulate fire. They covet gold because this soft metal can be manipulated with ease, and because gold is the only element that can not be magically transmuted (except through the three philosopher stones). They are master craftsmen, producing many arcane devices and enchanted items. They are also great merchants and financiers, operating a banking system that rivals that of the goblins. All for the purpose of accumulating gold.

In battle, gold wizards may transmute themselves into nigh-invulnerable metallic combat forms. This is not an ability shared by all however, and those without it simply wrap themselves into skins of liquid metal.

The Gold Order eschew the mysticism and arcane rituals of the other orders, preferring a down-to-earth, practical magic built on rigorous study, trial, and error. They wear yellow robes that are singed, sooty and stained from the aforementioned errors.

Manipulate metal - beneath their touch, metal runs like liquid, forming itself into shapes as the wizard desires. Different metals are easier to control than others, with gold being a delightfully soft, pliable metal.
Rusting grasp - any iron or iron alloy item you touch becomes instantaneously rusted, pitted, and worthless, effectively destroyed.
Make whole - completely repairs an object made of any substance, even one with multiple breaks, to be as strong as new.
Self-transmutation - the wizard attains a metallic form resilient to physical damage, disease, drowning, poison, stunning, and all spells or attacks that affect physiology or respiration, as they have no physiology or respiration to effect. They are however vulnerable to spells which would otherwise affect metal (such as rusting grasp), conduct and can be immobilized with electricity, and must be in contact with living human skin to resume their human form.
Imitate object - the wizard is able to imitate perfectly any non-living object. The wizard adopts any magical properties, abilities, or limitations of the object, and cannot cast any spell except the counter-spell. The wizard may speak; the counterspell to return to human form is vocal.
Animate objects - the wizard imbues inanimate objects with mobility and a semblance of life.
Petrify -
Exchange properties - the wizard may swap the properties of any two objects, for example he or she may turn swap the properties of a human and a statue, turning the stone into living flesh and the human into stone. Requires the wizard to be touching both items.

Toll
Their flesh is progressively replaced by metal or mineral, and over time they resemble sculpture or machinery more and more. While often still animated, their sense of self erodes to the point where they will not act unless directly ordered to or operated by somebody else.

College
15533221211.title: The Golden Order

155332212111.content:
Jade Order wizards tend to fall into two opposing camps, which may come to define their personality. In one camp are those who believe it is their solemn duty to protect and nourish life. They tend to be compassionate and kind, defending those who can't defend themselves and helping others to grow.

In the other camp are those who believe that all life is in a constant fight for survival, that only individuals of strong body and mind have a right to live. They tend to be ruthless and cruel, exploiting those they see as weak and discarding them when they become a liability.

Spells
Animal sight - the wizard is able to enter the mind of a simple creature, see through its eyes, but cannot directly influence its actions.
Creeping tendrils - summons vines from the ground that move to the wizard's will
Growing strong - calls forth accelerated plant growth even in the most inhospitable environments. Fruiting plants will put forth a bountiful crop.
Animal growth - a chosen animal grows to twice its normal size and eight times its normal weight
Imbue life - the wizard may donate a portion of his life force, invigorating the recipient with youth.
Adaptive Cocoon - the wizard is immobilised in a tough, protective cocoon. This cocoon can withstand great extremes of heat and cold but may be pierced by blades. Inside the wizard undergoes a metamorphosis into a form suitable to survival in the outside environment.
