15533223.content:
"God is dead. God remains dead. And we have killed him. How shall we comfort ourselves, the murderers of all murderers? What was holiest and mightiest of all that the world has yet owned has bled to death under our knives: who will wipe this blood off us? What water is there for us to clean ourselves? What festivals of atonement, what sacred games shall we have to invent?"
- His Divine Materials, Volume VII

The Tyrians of old were human, though history has painted them with such grandeur that they often have been beyond human - a conceit that they themselves fell to and which was to be their undoing. They created what is still seen to this day as the model for a lawful, learned society. With their vast, calculating intellects they mastered everything they set their minds to - their understanding of magic, mathematics and metallurgy unequaled even in the centuries since their dissolution. Their Artificers created devices of such fabulous intricacy that still stand as wonders to this day.

The most well known of their creations were the Automata. These clockwork golems performed all manual labour in their empire(allowing their creators to commit themselves to mental pursuits); enforced laws equally and absolutely among all citizens, and defended their borders from jealous rival states, of which there were many. Many of these Automata still defend Tyrian relics and ruins after centuries despite the efforts of salvages to steal and reprogrammed them to serve new masters.

For all their power and knowledge, the Tyrians remained envious and greedy for more, until they even sought to claim the secrets of godhood itself. Luring their patron deity, Tyr, from the heavens, they struck him down, believing that through the dissection of his corpse they might learn the science behind the spark of the divine.

Yet a god does not die easily. Tyr suffered beneath their scalpels for seven days as their greatest scientists and arcanists took him apart piece-by-agonising-piece. On the final day, his defiled body finally gave out and rose again within the Graveyard of the Gods as a grim, undead revenant. The twisted god lay claim to the souls of all Tyrians and their descendants, to be trapped and tortured in his realm for all eternity upon their deaths.

The notes of the dissection were written within seven volumes, His Divine Materials, detailing each day's findings as well as a describing the scholars' descent into madness. They are among the most profane books ever written and merely to touch them is said to forfeit ones' soul to Tyr.

The complete disintegration of the Tyrian Empire came swiftly, over just a few decades, as the population fell into morbid despair. Their wealth was frittered away on offerings to Tyr and vast necropoli built to appease him, to no avail. Realising themselves to be irredeemably damned, the people split into ever more desperate factions, each with its own promise for escaping eternal damnation.

The Necrontyr
With what little they had gleaned from the dissection of the dead god, the faction that became known as the Necrontyr imbued themselves with necromantic energy so that their souls would be sealed within their bodies upon death. While it saved them from Tyr, it also permanently denied them any afterlife at all. The Necrontyr now shuffle about the ruins of their empire within their rotting shells, attacking any who come close.

The Chronotyr
"How do you do, fellow kids?"
A second faction sought to avoid death entirely by reversing life itself. Again, their experiments were only partially successful. The Chronotyr are born old. As time goes on, these toothless old men and women age backwards, becoming young adults, children, and finally newborns, before being unbirthed. It is unclear what becomes of their souls after their unbirthing, though they do not arrive at the realm of Tyr.
The few Chronotyr that exist live in human lands. They tend to hide their heritage, lest they be shunned (no family would ever knowingly contaminate their bloodline with the Tyrian's curse). Except for a sweet spot around middle age, fitting in is quite a challenge, as they come across as either very immature elders, or suspiciously world-weary youths.

The Automatyr
Seeing the living death of the Necrontyr as no better than the torture of the afterlife, the faction that came to be the Automatyr transplanted their souls into the clockwork minds of their own golems. While certainly succesful at avoiding death (so long as their inanimate bodies are maintained), the fusion of mind and machine was not always a comfortable one. Many Automatyr found themselves still bound to the last instructions given to their machine bodies, or forced to obey the commands of any new master.
Realising that these trapped, obedient souls could be ordered to divulge the secrets of the once powerful civilization, the Automatyr were hunted and rounded up as prized artifacts by collectors. To avoid this fate, many hid their true natures. When you meet an Automata in the street, you may wonder if what looks out at you from that ceramic mask is more than mere machine intelligence.

The Impostyr
The Impostyr are a faction that have spread far and wide, secreting themselves into all races and cultures. Their aim is to hide themselves from their god, so that upon death he will not know to claim them, and will be free to venture on to the afterlife.
When an Impostyr is born, the truth of their heritage is concealed as quickly as possible. Many of their methods are severe, including disfiguring the face and mutilating the body into an unrecognisable form. As they mature, Impostyrs are taught the history of their heritage and their curse, and the grave importance to always keep it hidden. They fabricate new identities, while further altering and augmenting their bodies with surgical techniques and grafts, imbuing themselves with the humors of inhuman races, or using magic to change completely, though even that is not enough to break the curse. They keep moving, always changing, even becoming other races to throw off the scent of their bloodline.

There are those that still kindle the embers of hope that one day a hero will break their curse and allow them to reclaim their bodies and lands, though it would take the power of a god.
15533223.title: Tyrians/Necrontyr/Chronotyr/Automatyr/Impostyr

155332231.content:
Erolus

Erolus is a nation that was recently founded. Known as the melting pot of human culture Erolusians pride themselves in science, magic, and agriculture. The people of Erolus are also fervently religious. They don't serve one god or goddess, but all of them. This is especially true of the Goddess of Tryzantium and Ordin of Ordania. Many people who visit the nation assume that the reason why Erolusians do this is that they are literally in the middle of the two nations. Others say that Erolusians are the few people that adhere to the scriptures of where the two deities are husband and wife. Regardless, Erolusians make it their duty not to anger the gods lest they themselves get cursed with some horrible curse.

Erolusians are also known to capture werewolves and other lycanthropes. Erolusians train lycanthropes by placing silver collars around necks. Many of the other nations question the sanity and ethics of such practices. Other races believe that out of all human ethnicities, Erolusians are just plain bonkers. They even claim that the ruling monarch is a certified psycho, which is true. Upon ascending the throne the king and queen are blessed with an overabundance of knowledge. The intellectual overflow gradually causes the monarch's mind to become warped. If a monarch's sanity reaches a point where they go feral or where they start talking backwards they are mercifully killed to alleviate them of their burden.

Erolusians also experiment in advancing the fields of magic. As a result they have pioneered the road for other magic users to emerge. Out of the new magic careers created: druids, spell fencers, telepaths, summoners, mediums, and magic berserkers are the most notable. There are also rumors of a new order or two of wizardry are currently being researched. The advance of such magical fields have ensured that the monarchs can better control their psychosis. Some monarchs even become telepaths so they can peer into the minds of others.
155332231.title: Human nations: Erolus

1553322311.content:
Bishan

Bishan is a country located near the mountains. They are on the border of many of the Western and Eastern nations. As a result they are the trade capital of the world. Unlike other nations the people of Bishan tend to have different body types depending on what region of the country they are from. Bishanites who dwell in the mountains tend to be extremely muscular. The Bishanites who dwell within the cities and near the caves tend to be extremely fat. No one is why a nation would have these extreme body types existing at the same time, but researchers are startled that Bishanites have longer lifespans than most humans. Some conspiracy theorists claim that Bishanites have discovered the secret to immortality.

Over the years the Bishanites have created their own form of entertainment. The fatter Bashanites have invented the sport of sumo wrestling. So far the sport is only popular in Bashan. The muscular Bashanites have invented the art of dragon and monster taming. Many nations are intrigued that this group of Bashanites can successfully train monsters or even dragons who are known to have a god complex so large that they demand to be worshiped as such. When it comes to foreigners it is said that the new immigrants slowly grow into one of the two body types depending on where they move to.

Chapter originally by MysteriousZ
1553322311.title: Human nations: Bishan

15533223111.content:
The national myth of Ordania's birth dates back to time immemorial, where the Goddess and Ordin lived happily as one, their followers living perfect lives under the blessings of both gods. This all came to an end with the Trouble In Paradise, a minor squabble between the two gods which escalated into the War in Heaven, ending with Ordin and his followers being cast out into the wilderness. They ventured forth to form their own empire, settling a harsh land of taiga and tundra.

Ordania has grown mighty in the eons since, but it still holds to its bitter grudge against Tryzantium. Like many a bad break-up, Ordin and his nation remain defined by their hated ex, and vice versa, and the two nations remain strangely linked, often reflecting the other like mirror images. Despite their ancient kinship, glaring similarities and mutual enemies, the two empires have been at war with one another for centuries, only recently forming an uneasy peace.

Ordanian males tend to be rugged, hairy, and humourless. They leave the business of state to the womenfolk.

The Brotherhood of Ordin revere the manly god Ordin. A boys-only club, The Brotherhood's view on women is that they should be subservient to their husbands and fathers, seen but not heard (ideally not seen either), allowing the men to focus their time on more important matters, such as practicing the art of combat and nude wrestling, combing each others beards, and admiring your best friend's muscles. Wives are expected to remain chaste during their husbands' long hunting trips and military campaigns with the lads.

Ordin's holy fire is a black-and-blue flame, and his favoured form is a bear.

The Noble Court

Queen Agatha the Ruthless: Unlike other nations it is the queens of Ordania that pass the laws and handle the politics. Queen Agatha is an imposing woman with pepper-gray hair. She's not a dedicated follower of Ordin but, enforces his laws when it serves her purpose. It is also said that Agatha loves to gamble behind closed doors at the late hours of the night. She is also known to cheat to ensure that she wins. She often uses her prize money to increase the size of the Ordanian army or to purchase unclaimed territories.

King Franklin the Large: A true follower of Ordin and the high bishop of the brotherhood of Ordin. Like many in the brotherhood, Franklin believes that women should only be responsible for making laws, cooking, making clothes, playing female only sports, or supporting the royal army either by magic or as a foot soldier to serve the generals, even though there are female commanding officers in the army. Over the years Franklin became more of a glutton. For every child his wife bore he gained a hundred pounds or more. He has no shame in his size because he considers fat men to be extremely manly in the eyes of Ordin.

Jillian the Wanderer: Technically the heir of the Ordanian throne, she loves seeing new lands. As the eldest daughter of the king and queen she often goes on long expeditions. Recently she never came back from her recent expedition. It is unknown if she is dead or if she kidnapped.

Roberto the Pervert: Most commonly called a playboy, Roberto has been given Ordin's Enriching Blessing. Roberto used to be a quiet individual, but his mother insisted that he receive the blessing so she could get him to marry Isabella of Tryzantium. His father objected at first until Agatha persuaded him that the Ordanian throne needs an emergency heir in case Jillian is dead. After receiving the blessing Roberto has been trying to woo over any woman he finds. As a result he is locked in a cage and guarded by two heavily muscled guards. Any woman who tries having sex with Roberto is made sterile as a result.

Amelia the faithful: As a royal princess Amelia has been fascinated by the church. Due to her being a female she can only serve as a temple maiden/priestess. As such she must dress in scanty clothing since it is a requirement for all females who serve Ordin. Her mother objects to this and demands that she learn how to rule Ordania if her plans for her first emergency heir backfires. Agatha even threatens to banish or kill Amelia if she doesn't comply.

Bartus the Fearless: Bartus is only a year younger than Amelia. Unlike his older brother Bartus is loud and brass. He care about building his extremely muscular frame and fighting in wars. He is by far his mother's favorite son. Not only knowledgeable in war, but politics too. She even put him in charge of searching for his elder sister. Agatha hopes that he can meet a woman that shares his interests and who is also a princess.

Princess Cassandra: The youngest member of the royal family. She is a youthful trouble maker and is constantly disciplined by her parents.
15533223111.title: Human nations: Ordania

choices: Ordanian sports. Both men's and women's sports
155332231112.content:
Even though women act as rulers in a political sense they are forced to learn politics while men can have more time having fun and waging war. It doesn't help that most noblewomen of Ordania enjoy writing harsh laws that make the suppression worse. In this way the king of Ordania doesn't have to worry about ruling since politics is considered women's work. Instead most kings spend their time waging wars, serving as the head of the brotherhood or both. Women who are allowed in the army are only allowed to do so since many men believe that such women make great fodder. If a woman is a commanding officer she is usually well-versed in magic. Also women who use magic are considered valuable to the army since they can use their magic to heal the greatest generals in a pinch.

Stuffed Bears: A recent trend among priestesses who serve Ordin is the creation of stuffed bears. Even though they may look like adorable teddy bears they are sacred objects of worship, image of their god. It is not uncommon to see Ordanian churches filled with these plushie idols. Destroying one with ill-intent is punishable by death or transformation. It is also said that Ordin himself may appear in the form of a man to observe the creation of these soft relics, but if spotted by the clergy he will automatically take the form of a bear.

Magic: Most magic practitioners in Ordania are women. Men who learn magic only learn a few healing spells and spells to enchant their on weapons in combat. Men who only use magic in combat and don't use forged weapons is usually looked down for such unmanly behavior.

Celebrations: Whenever there is a successful hunt, war campaign, or sacred holiday Ordanian men will gorge themselves. Though most Ordanian men are extremely muscular there are a few who use such celebrations to purposefully get fat. Ordanian men who get fat are said to be extremely strong. That's because they borrow some exercises that sumo wrestlers in Bishan use to exponentially increase their muscle mass and the application of strength tonics to their food.
155332231112.title: Other facts about Ordania

1553322311121.content:
The Occult Combatant Command, commonly referred to simply as the Command, forms the spellcasting arm of the Ordanian military. Overseen by a council of five Archon, the command is divided into five Academies tasked with training and deploying the next generation of wizards. The archon report directly to Queen Agatha who wields their forces with her characteristic ruthlessness. The Command is more militant even than the Order; the academy training is brutal and its soldiers are often stationed on the frontlines. Though immortal, their brash, aggressive use of magic quickly takes its toll on their bodies and most live short lives. It is predominantly made up of women, though restrictions have been relaxed in recent decades in order to compete with Tryzantium.

The Command and the Order hate each other. Even when their goals are aligned, they will go out of their way to sabotage each other. Gifted children are so rare that the two institutions often launch raids into the other's country to kidnap promising recruits. Even after graduation, the Command and the Order will do anything to get wizards of the opposing side to defect, as doing so grants them their enemy's arcane secrets. If they cannot turn them, they will simply kill them.

Academy of Peace
Whereas Tryzantium wizards summon demons to do their bidding, Wizards of Peace (otherwise known as Aqshy Wizards) prefer the creation of pacts with them, offering part of themselves or a pledge of loyalty in exchange for diabolical boons. Through this exchange, Aqshy wizards can achieve great and terrible heights of power very early in their careers. They are frontline troops, terrifying to face, invulnerable to bludgeoning, stabbing, burning, drowning and poisoning, wielding great strength.
Over time, the Faustian pacts accrue and turn rotten, requiring the wizard to surrender more and more of themselves to stave of the demons waiting to collect. Ultimately a Aqshy wizard has nothing left to bargain with and is dragged to hell piece by piece.
They are led by Archon Matryona Solovieva, a cunning wizard who sold her soul simultaneously to seven demons, and is unable to die until they can agree which one owns her.

Academy of Plenty
Resembling huge, animated statues of granite or bronze, the Wizards of Plenty (otherwise known as Chamon Wizards) stand as living monuments to the strength and glory of Ordanian manpower. They operate the labourcamps which make up much of Ordanian industry, churning out war-machines and armaments through oppressive slave labour. Even after the laborers bodies are exhausted, their work is not done, as they are transmuted by their wizard overlords into useful items.
It is said that Queen Agatha owns a chain-link shirt, each link representing a life lost in the labour camps.

Academy of Truth
Known as Wizards of truth or Hysh Wizards,, nobody quite knows the limits of the Truth Wizards' powers, for they are state-sanctioned reality warpers. Once they have performed their work it is for all intents and purposes as though they have done nothing at all, as though things have always been that way. Enemies of the state are rendered non-persons by Queen Agatha, and can be written out of existence altogether. They are regarded with great fear, both within and without the country.
In reality, the Academy of Truth does very little, as even Agatha herself fears their power, only calling upon them very rarely. Rewriting even a minor aspect of reality is a staggering complex feat with potential for unforeseen consequences. Their main function is in terrifying the peasants into obedience through fear of being erased from history, or worse.
The Wizards of Truth reside in a foreboding granite citadel, cataloging every past and current event in great libraries. They are capable of creating demiplanes and alternate realities in which they rigorously test the effects of a reality warping spell before implementing it. These pocket dimensions are stored inside huge tomes

Academy of Agitators
The white wind of Hysh constantly swirls unseen around Agitator Wizards like a hurricane, whipping up the emotions of all who are around them into a frenzy. With their mere presence, Agitators can stir farmers into a mob or reduce hardened armies to fearful cowards.
Before the Agitators were brought to heel by Agatha, they were a constant nuisance, often insiting the serfdom into riots. Things have quietened down since. The Agitators situate their Academy far away from anything in a serene valley, as too many of them together in one place tends to destabilize kingdoms.

Wild Lodge
The Wizards of the Wild Lodge are an anarchic lot, allying with Queen Agatha only when it suits their interests. They overflow with ghyran, the wind of life, invigorating all around them. This nature magic compels them to travel and fight and love life in all its forms. However the eternally building life energy must be expended regularly, else the Wizard explode, turning everything in a 1000 foot radius into verdant forest. Siring or gestating offspring is an effective expenditure of life energy. Animal familiar can absorb excess ghyran, but after a point the excess life energy will cause them swell to many times its size.
The most effective way to expend a build-up of ghyran is for the wizard to split in half, duplicating themselves. These duplicates have the same personality and memories but lack the original's magic power and are thus usually casually thrown away on suicidal missions and doomed battles.
If there is anything Wild Wizards love more than a fight, its experiencing a fight from multiple different bodies consecutively. It is not unheard of for a Wild Wizard to transform and split herself into a whole cavalry regiment, both riders and horses.
The Wild Lodge itself resembles a log cabin atop a pair of giant chicken legs, constantly roaming the wilderness.
1553322311121.title: Ordanian Arcane Academies (work in progress)

1553322311122.content:
The Brotherhood see the male form as an aspect of Ordin himself, and to revel in ones own physicality is in itself a form of worship. Adherents love greeting the world bare-chested and dripping with holy oils, displaying their keenly honed bodies, though furs (especially bear) are an acceptable substitute in polite or foreign company.

Within the Brotherhood are many sects. Not least among them...

The Ursine Orthodoxy
The scriptures speak of how the original settlers slept alongside and suckled hibernating bears to survive the first winter in the harsh landscape. The Ursine Orthodoxy see in bears the true essence of Ordin. Most live out in the wilds, attempting to become one with the bear community, which they usually achieve by being mauled and consumed by them. Remarkably some survive to live among them.

Bearzerkers
Zealous devouts often taken from the ranks of the Ursine Orthodoxy, they charge headlong and armourless into battle, tearing apart the enemy with metal claws.

Sect of the Reunion
The followers of the Reunion seek to orchestrate the reunion of Ordin and Camenae. To this end they "accidentally" schedule His holy festivals to coincide with those of the Goddess, sabotage Her relationships with the other gods wherever possible, and steal Her divine relics in the hope that She will have to call round to Ordin's place one day to pick them up.

Sect of the Rebound
The followers of the Rebound seek to help Ordin move on from his lost love. To this end they scour the world in search of the perfect woman for him to fall back on.
1553322311122.title: Forms of Ordin worship

1553322313.content:
The nation of Erolus is well known for almost all of its population being psychologically insane. It is also said if a foreigner spends too much time in Erolus their sanity will erode and they'll become crazy. If such a thing happens they are likely never going to leave and will instead permanently move to Erolus.

Godly Reincarnation: Erolus is the only nation with the knowledge of how to reincarnate a god or goddess. However a certain number of sacrifices are required along with a suitable vessel. It is said that the mind of the deceased god or goddess merges with the mind of the vessel. It is usually said that reincarnated gods and goddesses act differently than they have before. The types of sacrifices heavily relies upon the god and their worshipers. On a side note their is a secret sect that only exists within Erolus that consists of both priests of Ordin and priestesses of the Goddess Carmen respectively. They claim that there is a prophecy that the only way for Carmen and Ordin to truly unite as a couple is reincarnation. For vessels a Tryzantium prince and an Ordanian princessmust be used as the vessels. It is believed that the vessels' experiences of the opposite kingdom would unify the two religions and make them one. To this day this secret sect waits for the chosen vessels to meet in real life. Once that happens the prophecy will be ushered into being.

Anthro Acceptance: Since Erolus is full of psychos of all flavors it is not uncommon for anthros to get along peacefully with the other races who live in Erolus. Slowly but surely the monarch is heeding the whim of interracial marriage between anthros and non-anthros.

Magic: Erolus is constantly inventing new fields of magic on a biyearly basis. Erolus is also known as the breadbasket for magic. Some religions in Erolus have their clerics learn various spells. This development is rumored to have caused the Goddess Maira and the God Epsilon to begin dating each other. The ironic thing is that they have barely known each other and only have recently met.
1553322313.title: More on Erolus

155332232.content:
Mosians: Mosians better known as giants are a subrace of humans known for their unusually large stature. Legends say that Mosians achieved their great height through an ancient incense found in a temple of unknown origins. However, the incense was was more of a curse for it caused some of the other races and animals to mutate or grow larger. It was said to be so bad that the Mosians had to cast a spell to lift their continent into the sky. Nowadays the Mosians have become mere fables, but that doesn't discourage greedy treasure hunters from trying to find a way to their realm.

Surmians: Surmians are a subrace of humans who mutate upon being blessed by their god, Suruma. This blessing is done through a special war ceremony. Though they are bestowed with great power the price comes with a toll on their body. Surmians who have mutated to the point that no mutation is a hallmark of another racs. Their appearances have caused them to be shunned by the other races in Tamoria and their god laughs at their dismay.

Lorocans: Lorocans are said to be a subculture that live in Erolus. They are natural born shapeshifters who take on an animalistic form. Whoever is bitten by a Lorocan is cursed to live their life as a beast. The only cure is to beg for a special elixir from the Erolusian monarch, a noble, or the Lorocan that inflicted the curse. Ironically most Lorocans are nobles, who visit other kingdoms. If the inflicted fails to find an elixir within three months than their whole family will retroactively obtain the Lorocan curse.
155332232.title: Other human subraces

1553322321.content:
The Versi are a curious race of humans that originate from the vast, distant continent of Versiland. It is theorized by scholars that Versiland exists somewhere on the underside of the world, as it can only be reached by many months of sailing across the open ocean, or by traversing a network of deep underground rivers and caverns for days.

The tales that come from Versiland are often so ludicrous that it is yet unclear if the Versi travellers are making them up, or if the continent was created by the gods as some counterbalance to the normal order of things (or perhaps simply as a joke). In Versiland it is said that rain falls up into the sky, fire is cold, and plants eat animals. Their dragons burrow beneath the ground and breath out torrents of water, while fish fly through the air on scaly wings.

Whether or not these stories are true remains to be seen, but the Versi themselves are undeniably an oddity. While on the face of things, they appear completely human and divided into the normal sexes of men and women, as the gods intended, things are very different once one looks under the covers.

Versi males, while certainly sporting a perfectly natural penis between their legs, resemble women in every other physical aspect - soft skin, delicate features, and breasts. Yet their mannerisms and lusts remain that of a typical male, albeit they are attracted to the body-type of a typical Versi female... which just so happens to resemble that normally expected of a man.

Versi females are large and muscular, bearded, and have a completely serviceable vagina sitting beneath their hairy bellies. Their temperament is again at great odds to their appearance - being equally as demure, caring and sensitive as the most feminine lady. The two sexes mate very similarly to our own and the females bear their children for nine months.

Versi diplomacy remains a messy affair even for our most veteran diplomats, riddled with misinterpretation and faux pas. It is important not to let appearances deceive when dealing with them. Versi men - though outwardly beautiful - are as fond of a lewd joke or brutal sport as any man, while Versi women - while physically intimidating - shun such activities in favour of crochet, flower arranging, and puppies.

Always remember that they themselves are as dumbfounded by our gender roles as we are of theirs and, as a man, be aware of any signals you may be giving off to Versi males, lest they misconstrue and respond to them as they would romantic advances from a Versi female. Remember, do not:
- laugh too heartily at their jokes.
- touch your hair.
- touch them.
- compliment their appearance or physical prowess.
- make eye contact for longer than 0.34 seconds.

Lest you want to be seen as an incorrigible flirt.
1553322321.title: Human subraces: The Versi

15533223211.content:
Demigods are a race of humanity who are the result of the gods having one night stands with their human worshippers. Demigods are immortal just like the gods, but their powers are miniscule compared to the gods themselves. When a person first meets a demigod they mistake them for ordinary men and women. It isn't until a demigod first uses his powers that ordinary humans realize the subtle difference.

All the demigods in the world live on the island of Patrinor. The rulers of the island are the first demigods and demigoddesses to have been born. They refer to themselves as the royally divine. Outside of Patrinor demigods can blend in with other human cultures. However, all the offspring of a demigod are demigods, since the god gene is always dominate.
15533223211.title: Demigods

choices: More members of the Royally Divine
155332232111.content:
The royally Divine are the oldest demigods in the history of Tamoria. Despite their advanced age, like all demigods they appear as men and women in their their mid-twenties. With that in mind they often wear regal clothes to distinguish themselves from the populace and their offspring. It is not uncommon for members of the Royally Divine to visit other human nations to scout out potential demigods. The Royally Divine feel that taking a census of the world's number of Demigods to prevent other nations from getting too powerful. If a nation is said to have too many demigods the Royally Divine would send storytellers to entice the demigods to move to Patrinor. If a demigod refuses to move to Patrinor, which rarely happens, the Royally Divine would create a quest that would leave the demigod on a perilous journey.

The Royally Divine is one of the largest families in the world. It is said that the family literally doubles in size on a yearly basis. In fact many demigods are able to hangout with their great-great-grandfathers as if it was nothing, which is often the case due to their immortality. With that being the case Patrinor magically expands daily to fit the needs of the populace. Here are some of the most well known members of the Royally Divine:

Rikor the Magnificent: The first demigod in history and the eternal king of Patrinor. As the first and only king of Patrinor he is constantly monitoring the demigod population. In the past he traveled across the world, but now he wisely governs his people. He rarely let's non-demi-gods into his kingdom and when he does it is only those who are great heroes.

Amilia the Blessed: Queen of Patrinor and the first demigoddess in history. She continually updates the Chronicles of the Royally Divine which lists all the members of the family and their accomplishments. Every year she usually gives birth to a child or two due to her constant lovemaking to her husband, Rikor. Officially she has 60 children and 150 grandchildren. However, those numbers are subject to change annually.

Absalom the Massive: The world's largest demigod. Absalom used to be an adventurer, but has since let himself go. He currently weighs 2,500 lbs. Despite his size Absalom is an expert in combat and moves quickly for a demigod of his size. Thanks to his immortality his weight isn't an issue. It is also stated that his excess weight has made him more powerful.
155332232111.title: More about the Royally Divine

155332232113.content:
Besides Demigods there are other human subraces in the world.

Zorsks: An extinct subrace of humanity. They are large and stocky and have blue skin and short stubby tails. One prominent feature is their razor sharp teeth. Though it can be said that this offshoot of humanity are mainly carnivores is truly inaccurate. Their sharp teeth help them bite into certain food, like coconuts with ease. Besides being omnivores it is said that their bodies absorb magic. Other theorize that Zorsks need to eat magic as part of their diet.

It is said that the gods hunted them down due to their magical immunity. Some gods, such as Ordin and Camenae, abhor any group of people who like the Zorsks. To such gods Zorsks are a freak of nature that shouldn't be allowed to exist. Though that was years ago, those same gods still despise magic as well as the magically immune. If this subrace ever made a come back it would be at the practitioner's peril.

Gorshas: A subrace founded by the first of his kind, Gorshan. These people appear as normal humans, but if angered or startled they will hulk-out and beat anyone they see to a living pulp. Many who live in Gosha settlements seek to live in absolute peace lest they risk being a hulking monster for the rest of their lives. Some Gorshas want to be in their hulked-out form permanently. These Gorshas claim to have complete control over their emotions and can benefit others with their immense strength. Whether this is true is still being studied by magicians and scientists to this day.

Mutanoids: A subrace of humanity who randomly develop powers as early as age 13. Some of these people look like normal humans and can blend in with society, but others have exotic appearances and are shunned. Though treated better than anthros, many in society despise them for no apparent reason. A Mutanoids powers are always random and could change if they need to adapt to a situation.
155332232113.title: More human subraces of Humanity

15533223213.content:
When Casario and Lothanova first made the perilous journey from Versiland as young men, they discovered to their delight that the kingdoms of the top siders were easy prey for conmen such as themselves. In Versiland, they had been petty swindlers. Up above, they found that even the most powerful of men could be disarmed with a flutter of eyelashes, and that high born women would lower their guard, naively inviting them into their bedchambers. They occasionally work together on their scams, and are now folk heroes down in their native lands for the tales of their daring swindles.

Casario  
Aliases: "Cassie", "Lady Casandra"
The son of travelling verci actors, Casario grew into a serial womaniser, having a new woman in each town. Being particularly attracted to married women, he left behind him a string of scandalous affairs, bastard offspring, and broken marriages until the day that he was caught in bed with the wife of the local patrician. Casario was imprisoned, tortured, yet managed to affect his escape. Hounded by the patrician's men, he stowed away on a boat to the furthest away place he knew, Tryzantium.

Up above, he became unstoppable. Through flattery and seduction, he wormed his way into the hearts and homes of numerous powerful men, often finding work as a handmaiden for their wives. While gently rebuffing the advances of the husband with feigned flirtation and empty promises of future trysts, he quickly gained the friendship and confidence of the wife, before having his way with her once alone, willingly or no.

As he grew more confident, he set his sights on a new goal - to seat his offspring on the thrones of the world through the seduction and/or impregnation of as many noblewomen as possible. To this end, he adopted the guise of a high born woman, Lady Casandra, to get close to his prey. Further, he has acquired a number of potions with the power to switch the sexes, which he intends to use on any lord or king he can.

In appearance, Casario is sultry and curvaceous to the point of wantonness, with broad, swaying hips and a generous bust enhanced by the corsets and ribbed, tightly laced gowns he wears in the role as Lady Casandra. He is witty and flirtatious to men he can use, though firm in rebuffing them should their amorous advances get close to discovering the meaty Versi cock hidden beneath his skirts. His original hair was brown, though he has since shaved it down, wearing an assortment of expensive wigs depending on the social occasion or preferences of his target.

Despite their superficial resemblance to Verci women, Casario has no interest in men, finding their penises repulsive. Indeed his greatest fear is that one day he will caught and violated by one of the many angry husbands left in his wake.

Lothanova  
Alias: "Little Lotte"
Son of Verci traders who ventured to Tryzantium, Lothanova found there was far more money to be made in cat burglary and highway robbery. "Little Lotte", as he came to be known by the public, is now one of the most infamous "female" criminals of the modern age, getting away with (literal) murder more through his looks than any particular skill.

Lothanova is petite and slender, with modest breasts and an intentionally demure style of dress. His eyes are large, innocent and sky-blue; his face so sweet that it would make your teeth turn black; and his hair is long, butter-yellow curls tied back by a big blue bow. In his role as "Lotte", he is shrinking and shy, right up until he draws his concealed, serated blade and cuts your throat.

Lothanova's weakness is his love of drink. The wealth he steals is wasted on alcohol and he soon becomes boastful of his crimes the drunker he gets. Another problem is his monstrously large dick, which he struggles to conceal beneath is skirts and which has a habit of getting in the way during the feats of agility required for cat-burglary. Unlike Casario, he is attracted mostly to men due to their superficial resemblance to Verci women.
15533223213.title: Versi: Cassie and Lotte

155332232131.content:
Eli Cerci   has served as the Versi consul to Tryzantium for six years. In that time has only met King Ivar face-to-face once briefly on his first day. This is largely due to the logistical impossibility of transporting an army between Verci or Tryzantium, thus they are regarded as a non-threat by the king and entirely ignored diplomatically.

The other reason is the Queen. As Eli has the outward appearance of an Uplander female, he exists on the Queen's radar as a threat to be kept away from her lecherous husband.

Life in the consulate, which is manned solely by himself, is lonely and quiet. Only very occasionally is Eli called upon to settle the odd trade dispute between the kingdoms or to resolve the many rape allegations leveled at Versi men by topside men hoodwinked into bed. For the most part, he has little to do. Never able to stray far from the consulate in case something does happen, he is confined to the castle, where to his horror he is constantly invited by women of the royal court to evenings of needlecraft, afternoons of gossip-filled walks through the flower gardens, and babyshowers, neither unable to decline without committing a diplomatic faux pas nor explain to them the details of Verci biology and gender roles. To them, he is 'Elizabeth', a somewhat sullen young woman evidently in need of a man judging by the way 'she' gazes longingly after the men as they depart on hunting trips or war campaigns.

Eli yearns to be treated as the man that he is - to drink and fight and die on some valorous quest. But for now he is trapped trying on fine dresses and shoes.
155332232131.title: Versi citizens: Eli Celci

info.brief_description: Transformation in a world of wizardcraft and witchery
info.description:
Behold the ancient and mystical realm of Tamoria, where evil sorcerers lurk down every alley and magical talking swords are an endemic pest. Where humanity stands as a glorious beacon of sensibleness against a world of weird, dangerous races and beasts, holding back the wilderness with might and magic.

Chief among the human realms is the Kingdom of Tryzantium. Its greatest defenders are The Orders of Magic, militant institutions of arcane learning, and the Church of the Goddess, unyielding warriors of faith.

A truly ephemeral place, a serf should be happy if he makes it to the grave with the skin he was born in. Alas, such an achievement is a rarity in a world that abounds with ancient transformative relics, anomalous potions, competing werewolf and vampire plagues, witches with nothing more than human-to-newt spells in their repertoire, teratogenic mushrooms that warp the flesh, and powerful gentry who find you far more useful as a shire horse or hound than a miserable menial bondsman.

Regarding the information chapters, don't worry much about adhering to them, they're just there for ideas. The setting is a familiar fantasy one, only slanted towards perversion and transformation. :)
